TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 134 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans- Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans- Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines would inevitably result in:
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia.
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans-Australia Airlines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TEAGUE

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 19 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the plan to obliterate the traditional weights and measures of this country does not have the support of the people;
That the change is causing, and will continue to cause, widespread, serious and costly problems;
That the compulsory tactics being used to force the change are a violation of all democratic principles.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the Metric Conversion Act be repealed to ensure that the people are free to utilise whichever system they prefer and so enable the return to imperial weights and measures wherever the people so desire;
That weather reporting be as it was prior to the passing of the Metric Conversion Act;
That the Australian Government take urgent steps to cause the traditional mile units to be restored to our highways;
That the Australian Government request the State Governments to procure that the imperial and metric systems be taught together in schools.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COLEMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 307 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
A substantial contribution to Australia's economy by the payment of taxation and to the quality of life of fellow Australians, is made by parents in the work-force who have pre-school children.
Taxation relief for adequate child-care is necessary to enable these parents to avail themselves of child-care facilities in order to take paid employment.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that tax-payers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other tax-payers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security: In relation to the income test for a pension or benefit, is interest on an investment regarded as income even if that interest is at a rate less than the current inflation rate? If so, does this mean that some pensioners are not receiving their full pension because they receive interest payments which do not even retain the original purchasing power of their investment? Is the Minister or his Department investigating ways in which this type of injustice can be prevented?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact contained in the honourable senator's question, that income from investment is included as income for the purpose of the income test, is of course true. Income from whatever source is taken into account in applying that test. To adopt any other course would, of course, be very unfair. For example, where a pensioner earns money from personal exertion it would be very unfair to treat the income from that less favourably than the income received by another pensioner who is fortunate enough to have investment, superannuation or other income. There is a uniform treatment of cash income.

ANSWER.PARA: The point which is made by the honourable senator is an important one and it underlines why this Government has placed such a high emphasis on the control of inflation which it regards as important to pensioners, as to all other members of the Australian community. It is a fact that, given inflation, those people who have saved and invested in fixed income investment do lose a proportion of their capital through the process of inflation. That is one of the reasons why the Government regards inflation as an evil which it is important to reduce as far as possible. The plight of those pensioners who have saved and put money away for their old age and who see their savings eroded by inflation is a plight shared by widows and other people who are in the same position. As I said before, I trust this will mean that the Opposition will take note of what has been said by the honourable senator and will place equal emphasis on the control of inflation in any policies it puts forward for consideration by the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is it a fact that the Victorian health authority has informed the Royal Talbot General Rehabilitation Hospital at Kew that funds for capital works to the value of $2.5m designed to provide facilities intended to reduce the dependence of patients on institutional care will not be available for at least five years due to lack of Commonwealth funding? Does not such a policy indicate a less than warranted attention to disabled persons in this, the International Year of Disabled Persons?

—I have no information as to whether a Victorian Government authority has given particular information to the Royal Talbot General Rehabilitation Hospital at Kew in relation to its capital works program. I can say that this Government has been careful to pass through to States large amounts of general revenue through the agreements that have been made between the Commonwealth and the States. It is up to the States to make their own priority judgments as to how they spend that money. If there is to be a delay of five years, that reflects decisions made within the States and is not a question of the Commonwealth not making money available.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL CONSULTATIVE COMMITTEE ON OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to the ministerial statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions. In particular, that review proposes to abolish the National Consultative Committee on Occupational Safety and Health. Does this decision indicate a callous and, in view of the negligible savings involved, thoroughly unnecessary disregard for the industrial safety of working Australians? Alternatively, in view of the fact that the Committee has not yet been properly established-indeed, it has never met-is this purported abolition of the Committee simply nothing more than a political stunt or a confidence trick?
—The answer to the first question is no. The answer to the second question is no.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport: Will the Minister investigate the difficulties currently being experienced by industry in northern Tasmania in getting goods transported urgently, particularly to Sydney, by the monopoly Australian National Line run? Will he use his best endeavours to arrange for an extra vessel to clear the backlog of cargo? Will he use his best endeavours to ensure that while ANL is permitted to have this run it provides the service required and not just the service that suits it? Is the Minister aware that yet another Tasmanian business is to close sections of its operations because of ANL frustrations? Is there anything this Government can do to ensure that ANL carries out its functions more effectively?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided me with some general information with regard to this area of concern raised by Senator Archer. One recognises that this is of great interest to him and to all other Tasmanian senators. In the peak March season some difficulties were experienced by the Australian National Line in moving cargoes from Tasmania to Sydney. These were compounded by industrial difficulties and delays at Port Botany. In recent weeks ANL vessels have experienced further delays because of action taken by maritime unions. ANL is aware of the seriousness of the problem. The maritime union strikes came at a time when the capacity of ANL was already stretched to the limit by the high demand and congestion at other ports. ANL has maintained personal contact with clients to keep them informed of the efforts being made to overcome the backlogs and to ascertain the individual shipper's specific priorities. For its part, ANL has publicly announced that it will bring extra tonnage into the northern Tasmanian trade to clear backlogs. It aims to use a Lysaght vessel and the Brisbane Trader to alleviate the present very difficult situation, particularly in the Sydney area.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators will be aware that from 26 May maritime unions again imposed bans on ANL ships. This will add to the existing difficulties created by the unions earlier this month when ANL shipping from Tasmania was stopped for six days. The Minister understands that the maritime unions intend to delay Tasmanian shipping for another six days. ANL has requested the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the maritime unions to exempt Tasmanian shipping from the stoppages, in line with ACTU policy that special consideration ought to be given to the Tasmanian economy during national shipping strikes of this kind. ANL on the whole does give Tasmania excellent service. The Minister believes that the criticism of the Line is unfounded, particularly as recent backlogs are largely due to factors outside the Line's control. The Minister is not aware that any Tasmanian business is to close sections of its operations because of ANL frustrations. However, I am sure that the Minister would be pleased to hear from Senator Archer as to any particular details he may have of a particular case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations: Why has the Government abandoned the industrial relations policy which it advocated so strongly during the last election campaign and which called for the facilitating of union amalgamation procedures and the introduction of sensible and moderate secret ballot legislation? Why has the Government shelved the proposed amalgamations Bill which had bipartisan support from both the unions and the employers, and also from the former Minister for Industrial Relations? Why is the Government determined to introduce a Bill on secret ballots which is totally opposed by both the unions and the employers, who all believe that the legislation is unnecessarily confrontative and unworkable? In particular, why does the Government appear to have dismissed the possibility that secret ballots can and often will endorse a strike, thereby lending it legitimacy and causing the Government great embarrassment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall try to answer this question, being mindful of the prohibition of debating matters during Question Time. Of course, the matters raised in the honourable senator's question will be debated in this chamber shortly. A Bill concerning this matter was introduced into the House of Representatives on 14 May and is, I understand, on the program to be dealt with during the current sittings. The honourable senator has raised a number of questions suggesting an abandonment of industrial relations policy. Of course, the Government sees the Bill not in those terms but rather in terms of its fulfilling the Government's industrial relations policy advocated during the 1980 election campaign.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the two matters raised by the honourable senator, which, it is true, is not to be dealt with in the legislation which is to come before us, is the question of amalgamation. There was an indication in the House of Representatives on 18 September last year of the Government's objective of encouraging the formation of industry-based unions. That is the established policy of both Government parties and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. There has been work, in consultation with the National Labour Consultative Committee, on amendments to the amalgamation provisions of the Act on the basis of a criterion of the community of interest of unions desiring amalgamation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not in the legislation.

—It is marvellous how much help one gets in answering these questions. I started my reference to this matter by saying that it was not in the legislation. The reason it is not in the legislation-this was raised in the honourable senator's question-is that the Government parties wish to give consideration to the full implications of that legislation before it is introduced. Hence, it is still receiving consideration within the Government. That matter is simply postponed. It is not being brought forward at this stage.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to the other matter raised by the honourable senator, which relates to secret ballots, honourable senators will be aware that at present a discretion is vested in the Commission to order secret ballots. The effect of this legislation will be to give people at the work place a right to obtain a secret ballot. When they have a secret ballot and they indicate that they do not wish to participate in industrial action they will get some protection against the pressure which might otherwise be brought to bear on them if they did not wish to participate in industrial action.

TALK.START.PARA: —What if they go the other way?

—Both by interjection and in the original legitimate question raised by Senator Chipp, I was asked: What happens if the ballot goes the other way? Of course, there must be a possibility that the people who seek a ballot will find that the ballot supports industrial action. I can only suggest to the Senate that in those circumstances we will at least know the facts of the matter, which is not the case at present. If we know that there is substantial support, that is a quite different situation from a situation in which the people at the work place do not wish to indulge in the action which is being sought by unions or by union officials. Therefore, whatever concerns might be expressed about the legislation, it will establish a position where the facts are known. That might reduce some of the rhetoric of debate and introduce a willingness to tackle the real facts at the heart of any particular dispute.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Australia has nominated the Kakadu National Park, the Great Barrier Reef, Willandra Lakes and the Sydney Opera House for inclusion on the World Heritage List. When will these nominations be considered, and is there any indication that they will be accepted?

—I understand that Senator Neal is correct, that these four great Australian assets are to be nominated for the World Heritage List. I also understand that a very considerable amount of work has to be done in preparing each nomination, as each nomination needs to be accompanied by a considerable amount of documentation, which takes some time to prepare. I do not know exactly when the applications will be in and when the processing will be complete. I have an idea, although I will need to check it, that some of the applications will be in in the imminent future. If it suits the honourable senator's convenience, I will obtain specific information for him and make it available as soon as possible.

—Has the Minister for National Development and Energy seen a report by the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors, comprising Australia's major construction companies, which alleges that Government estimates of the value to Australia of the resources boom are more than double the true figure? I ask him whether he agrees with the assessment in the report that none of the following projects is likely to go ahead in the foreseeable future: All coal to oil conversion projects; all shale to oil conversion projects, including the Rundle development; the $2,000m caustic soda plant planned for Queensland and mentioned by that State's Premier as a definite project but which, in the words of the Federation's report, has not even yet been realistically discussed.

—I have not seen the statement and I cannot comment on it. I think this Government indicated that there was a list of some $33 billion worth of projects Australia-wide that it considered were about to go ahead. A test of its modesty or extravagance is that I drew the attention of this chamber to the publication over the New South Wales Minister's name of a list for that State alone amounting to $23 billion. It is quite clear that New South Wales regards the Australian figure as modest indeed.
—It could be pre-election optimism and post-election pessimism on both parts.

—Apparently Senator Button is saying that neither the public nor I should take notice of the publication of the New South Wales Minister because it would be election propaganda or optimism. That list exists. The list of $33 billion is, by contrast, extremely modest. I do not believe that one can say that synthetic oil production will not go ahead. There are a number of co-ventures--
—One can say that it will not go ahead for a very long time.

—Senator Walsh should remember that what he said is that Rundle is dead. The Labor Party spokesman, whose policies he is supposed to support, said the very contrary to that. It is very important for people who take notice of these interjections to know that that is so. I have no reason to believe that progress will not be made on the various matters. I will look at the statement and give it some study. If any further comment is necessary I will make it to the Senate.

—This is a question for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Is it a fact that when the Labor Government ended national service the practical result was that the former employment protection afforded under the National Service Act was removed, to the very real disadvantage of many, including those in the Federal Public Service whose seniority and prospects for promotion have been impaired in a way not intended by the government of the day?

—I think I have to point out to Senator Bjelke-Petersen that this is not strictly an area of concern for veterans. I will refer the question to the Minister in charge of the matter and obtain a reply for her.

—My question is directed to Senator Guilfoyle as a member of the ministerial committee reviewing Government functions. When the committee said that the interest subsidy for the Australian Wheat Board 'is to be reduced by one percentage point', was it the intention of the committee that the Wheat Marketing Act would be amended to ensure that the subsidy was reduced, or was it the intention of the committee to coerce the Reserve Bank of Australia into increasing the Rural Credits Department interest rate? If it was the latter, why did the committee report and the Prime Minister refer only to the Wheat Board when several other authorities also borrow from the Rural Credits Department?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Questions on this matter were answered earlier in the week and it was made clear that the Treasurer had written to the Governor of the Reserve Bank drawing his attention to the decision that was announced by the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee. The intention of the review committee was to see that there was a reduction of one per cent in the interest adjustment that covered the difference between the cost of borrowing from commercial sources and the cost of Reserve Bank Rural Credits Department finance. The committee, in its statement, did not address itself to other commodities; but, of course, other commodities would be involved in the matter covered by that decision. The Treasurer, in drawing the Reserve Bank's attention to it, has said that the Reserve Bank will be free to make these adjustments as it sees fit. We expect to ensue from that over a period the placing into effect of the review committee's decision.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. To use the Minister's phrase, if the Reserve Bank does not see fit to increase the rate, as she now claims was the intention of the committee, how do the committee and the Government propose to implement the decision that the interest subsidy 'is to be reduced by one percentage point'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have nothing further to add--
—No, you never have.
—Order, please!
—How much would have been saved--
—Order! Senator Walsh, cease interjecting. You asked for information; listen to it.
—I am not getting it, though.
—Order, please!

— I have nothing further to add to the statements that were made earlier this week by the Treasurer in which he gave information of his communication with the Reserve Bank and which I stated on his behalf in this place. Today I have referred also to the matters in the review committee's report. I have nothing to add to the information that I have already given.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I preface my question by saying that the saving of certain coins can become a money-making matter for the Government because many people both in Australia and overseas would save Australian coins if special ones were produced at certain times relating to certain occasions, which is something that the Canadian Government has recognised for many years. I ask: Has the Government considered altering the Acts which relate to the pressing of coins so that, say, $5 or $10 commemorative silver coins could be pressed at appropriate times? Will the Government examine the feasibility of altering the size of all Australian coins, except perhaps the 1c and 2c pieces, to make them more in keeping with their present value and more in line with coin sizes in most other areas of the world?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — There is considerable interest in coin collecting throughout the world, and I think there is renewed interest in this country. We have only to recall the experience with our gold coins and the pressure to produce more of these at the time that release was made. I should think the Treasurer would be very interested in the suggestions made by Senator Townley with regard to pressing further coins and making them more widely available for collection. I will also ask him to give a response to the suggestion with regard to the feasibility of altering the size of our coins and the introduction of other coins into our currency. I will see that early information is given to Senator Townley on these matters and, if there is any response from the Treasurer that would be of public interest, I shall see that that is made.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, concerns our relations generally with Latin American countries which have more or less dictatorship control, but specifically with Bolivia which is on the threshold of another internal army power struggle. My question is prompted by earlier questions by Senator Evans and Senator Chipp about whether we should attempt to apply moral persuasion, if not industrial sanctions, to countries which are not following democratic forms of government. Has the Minister any specific information on current trade union civil rights in Bolivia? Can she obtain a response from the Department of Foreign Affairs as to whether countries such as Bolivia, Uruguay and, possibly, Chile are recipients of any United Nations funds to which Australia is a major contributor? If they are, do we contemplate applying sanctions to such countries which are not adhering to the United Nations charter in relation to political freedom?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer to the Foreign Minister the several questions raised by Senator Mulvihill. With regard to United Nations funds and the imposition of sanctions regarding such funds upon the countries named by him, I would have to receive advice from the Foreign Minister before I could make any comment on the matter. With regard to the more general question, I will see what response is forthcoming from the Minister.

—I ask the Attorney-General whether he heard on the AM program this morning a certain tax avoidance expert blatantly boasting that he would still be able to work out schemes to circumvent the new tax avoidance legislation which was introduced yesterday by the Treasurer, Mr Howard. As tax dodging or cheating is costing the Australian people many millions of dollars, what steps can the Government take to impose severe penalties upon such tax avoidance advisers, who are specialising in cheating the Australian people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —One must bear in mind that there is a distinction, albeit often very blurred, between tax avoidance and tax cheating. The word 'dodging' can no doubt apply in both instances. Nevertheless, from a legal point of view, there is obviously such a distinction and we must bear that in mind. For a long time now a view has been held that there is a being known as 'tax evoision'. Perhaps that covers the blurred ground. That is where we have had the major problems. The question deals in broad terms. Undoubtedly there is a great deal of activity in this area which blurs into the area of cheating the public in a broad sense, if not in a purely legal sense.

ANSWER.PARA: At the end of last year the Government introduced the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Bill 1980, which is now law and which was designed to deal with companies and trustees that enter into arrangements to reduce their capacity to pay tax. That legislation affects also those who advise them on paying tax, and a very severe penalty is involved. I can assure honourable senators that, from the reactions we had at the time and have had since from the tax avoidance industry of this country, there is very great concern about that piece of legislation and very close attention is being paid to its provisions. I also emphasise the legislation introduced yesterday by my colleague the Treasurer, which will provide penalties for people whose schemes are struck down by its application. Those penalties involve the payment of double the tax avoided by such schemes. Also, a proposed amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act, which will be debated in the Senate perhaps later today, will ask the courts to pay regard to the object and purpose of legislation rather than its literal interpretation. The combination of all these moves represents a very formidable package, already in effect or in the process of being introduced, of measures designed to deal with the problem which is concerning Senator Young and indeed all other members of this Parliament.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was about to ask a question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, but it is in the nature of a supplementary question following the answer just given by the Attorney-General, so I will direct it to him. I direct his attention to a headline in the Age this morning, 'New move on tax law-Judges will be told to take new approach'. The article goes on:

QUESTION.PARA: The Federal Government will direct the High Court to adopt a fundamentally different approach . . .

What enters my mind-I ask the Attorney-General whether it is correct-is that the Government is about to interfere in the deliberations of the High Court. Is the Government about to do to the High Court what it has done at length with the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission? Are we to infer that all the previous decisions of the High Court in this area have been made at the suggestion of the government of the day? How can the Attorney-General explain what I consider to be an intrusion?

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that Senator Georges direct that question to his colleague Senator Evans. I am sure that he would get an even more forthright reply than I would be able to give on the subject. The particular matter is contained in a Bill which I introduced yesterday and which is to be debated in the Senate today. If Senator Georges wants to raise any opposition to the proposal, he should raise it in that debate.
—I have a supplementary question.
—Direct a supplementary to Gareth.

—I could. I would possibly get a better answer. I did not get an answer from the Attorney-General. All he did was to push aside what I consider to be a valid point. Is the leading article in the Age correct? Is the Government about to direct the judges of the High Court? I cannot see how that can be interpreted other than as an intrusion into the deliberations of the High Court and an attempt to influence its judgment.
—Of course it is, in the right direction.
—It is an intrusion. You lawyers ought to get together. If you cannot get together, in future I will direct my question to you, Mr President.

—A Bill has been introduced into the Senate to provide, in the Acts Interpretation Act, the overriding method by which courts are to approach the interpretation of statutes. That is a decision which has to be made by this Parliament, not by the Government. Whatever the Parliament decides on the matter, the courts are bound to abide by those decisions. They still have the ultimate right of interpreting what this Parliament says about the way they should interpret statutes. They have the right to interpret and they will always have that right. This Parliament has the right, within its powers, to lay down what the law should be.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, is about the pensioners of Australia. Can the Minister say whether there is any validity in the claims espoused by some sections of the media that up to 300,000 pensioners could be worse off under the Government's new health policies?

—I have had a number of questions addressed to me on this subject, and I can understand that it would be raised by a number of honourable senators because of some reports which have been circulated and which may, and I am sure will, frighten some pensioners unnecessarily. The fact is that with respect to pensioners who are eligible for the pensioner health benefit there is absolutely no change. Of course, they are the great numerical bulk of pensioners.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. Was not this question asked and answered yesterday? Because of the uncertainty of the Government, is it not being repeated often so that eventually somebody will believe it? It was asked and answered yesterday.
—Questions as such must not be repeated.
—With all due respect, Mr President, my question was based on reports in the media today. I cannot see how that could have any relation to yesterday.
—I shall listen to the reply.

—I intend to respond quite briefly because I canvassed in the Senate as recently as yesterday a number of the relevant points I would wish to canvass. I am sorry that there have been further reports today. I have not seen any newspapers this morning. As I pointed out yesterday, a very substantial number of the estimated 300,000 or so pensioners who are not pensioner health card holders are over the age of 70 years, are not subject to means tests and have substantial other income. A great proportion of them are also insured. All of those who are currently carrying private health insurance will be financially better off in the next financial year because they will qualify for a taxation deduction. I am sending information to all of those pensioners. I will make sure that all such pensioners get a direct communication from me so that there is no lack of proper information in their hands and so that they are not subjected to unnecessary concern. I am sure that that will be the wish of all honourable senators in this place.

—My question is to either the Minister representing the Treasurer or the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. I ask the appropriate Minister whether, as a result of the joint statement by the two Ministers on 18 September last year, film deduction investment was to be available in the year of income in which the investor invested money in the production of a film and whether the scheme commenced from 1 October 1980. Is the Minister aware that the investment that has occurred in the industry based on the Ministers' statement at that time has created employment opportunities for camera crews and others engaged in film production work? Is the Minister now aware that, as a result of the Government's about-turn by indicating in its legislation introduced last night that deductions are not to be available until the year in which the relevant film has been both completed and used to produce income, many of the films now in production will crash, thus creating economic difficulties in the industry and causing further unemployment? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government last year established a program which rejoices in the acronym NIEMS, the National Industry Energy Management Scheme, which is aimed at bringing to the attention of industry the desirability and practicability of making very substantial energy savings. The experience of those who have ventured on this path shows that the average industry can save between 20 per cent and 30 per cent of its energy costs by adopting appropriate measures. The NIEMS program has a system whereby the Government will provide advisers to go into buildings or factories and to do an energy audit upon request. ANSWER.PARA: I repeat two things. The belief throughout the Western world is that affluent countries can save up to 30 per cent of energy without affecting living standards. The speeches read as follows-
Petroleum (Submerged Lands-Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1981

The package of off-shore legislation passed in May last year included the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Act 1980. That Act has not been proclaimed yet but since its enactment it has become apparent that some amendments of a mainly technical nature to it and to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 are required before the 1980 Act is proclaimed. The Bill introduces the necessary amendments. As part of the off-shore constitutional settlement it was agreed that Commonwealth off-shore petroleum legislation would apply beyond the three-mile territorial sea and that State legislation would apply in the three-mile territorial sea. The Commonwealth Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Act 1980 implements this agreement by amending the Commonwealth Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 so that it would no longer apply inside the three-mile territorial sea. The 1980 Act contains a scheme for transitional arrangements, agreed on between the Commonwealth and the States and the Northern Territory, under which existing permits straddling the boundary of the territorial sea are to be split into two permits. The two new permits, consisting of a Commonwealth permit and a State permit, are to cover those parts respectively under Commonwealth jurisdiction and under State jurisdiction.

The 'Scheme for Transitional Arrangements', which appears as Schedule 4 of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Act 1980, was drafted in close consultation with the States on the basis that State action to implement the off-shore constitutional settlement in this regard would take the same form as that adopted by the Commonwealth, namely, by amendment of the State Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967. Subsequently, however, it was decided that for constitutional reasons the State Acts should be re-enacted with the necessary changes, rather than merely amended. The Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Act 1980, which was drafted to refer to the 1967 State Acts as amended from time to time, should therefore be appropriately amended so as to make it clear that it refers to the State Acts as proposed to be re-enacted.

The opportunity is being taken in this Bill to extend the application of the off-shore petroleum legislation to the continental shelf in the Coral Sea area. This is one of the last areas of Australian continental shelf virtually unexplored for petroleum. It is considered to be prospective and the petroleum industry has expressed keen interest in exploration there. This new area will be bounded to the west by the existing Queensland adjacent area boundary, to the south partly by that boundary and partly by the parallel of latitude 25 degrees south, and in due course will be bounded to the north by the seabed boundary to be established when the Torres Strait Treaty enters into effect, and to the east by seabed boundaries under negotiation with Solomon Islands and France.

The Coral Sea area is thus one of considerable dimensions and most of it is sufficiently distant from the Barrier Reef to permit exploration activities to be undertaken in those areas. In regard to the areas adjacent to the Great Barrier Reef region the Government is very mindful of its undertaking to protect the reef and it has therefore been decided that no commitment will be given to issue exploration permits within 30 miles of the reef, and furthermore that all exploration proposals within the new area will be subject to the closest scrutiny under the Commonwealth environment legislation. In this respect it is very relevant to point out that all islands and cays in the area are excluded from the ambit of the Bill. In the second reading speech for the introduction of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) legislation in 1967, it was indicated that when, at some future time, the legislation was extended to the Coral Sea area, administration of the legislation in that area would be carried out by Queensland. This Bill therefore provides that for the purposes of the petroleum legislation the area is to be administered as if it were part of the Queensland adjacent area. Thus the new area will be covered by Commonwealth legislation alone, with day to day administration being carried out by Queensland, but with the Commonwealth, through the joint authority arrangements, having overall responsibility for the area and the final say in major decisions which, of course, will include drilling proposals.

The Bill also amends the boundaries of the Queensland adjacent area in the Torres Strait area. There are several anomalies in that boundary and the requirement to amend it at this stage arises out of the fact that, when the boundary was established in 1967, it intersected the Australian territorial seas of five islands in the Torres Strait resulting in some areas of territorial sea of those islands lying outside the Queensland adjacent area. This has not been a practical problem to date. However, under the provisions of the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act, legislative powers are to be granted to States only in territorial seas which lie within adjacent areas immediately before that Act comes into force. It is therefore necessary to amend the Queensland adjacent area boundary to encompass these territorial sea areas, to ensure that State legislative powers are extended to those areas. When the Torres Strait Treaty is ratified, the adjacent area boundary will be amended to correspond to the treaty seabed line, which is considerably further south than the present boundary. The Australian territorial sea around Australian islands north of the seabed line will continue to be covered by the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act. As an interim measure, the adjacent area boundary has been amended so that it accords also with the limits of areas of Papua New Guinea territorial sea.

Turning to the provisions of the Bill, Part II of the Bill amends the 1967 Act. The main provisions in this Part, apart from some drafting amendments, are the amendments in clause 6 designed to allow an offence against the Act to be tried summarily without a jury and the re-drawing of the boundary of the Queensland adjacent area in clause 8 for reasons which I have already explained. Part III deals with amendments to the 1980 Act. The main amendments here are the extension of the legislation to the Coral Sea area by clause 10 and the re-definition of State Acts contained in clause 13. I have already mentioned the reasons for these amendments. Clause 11 is a drafting amendment clarifying the meaning of the provision and clause 12 contains certain technical amendments, as explained in the explanatory memorandum, designed to ensure the proper continuity of titles during the transition period. Part IV of the Bill contains a consequential amendment of the Coral Sea Islands Act 1969 resulting from the extension of the off-shore petroleum legislation to the Coral Sea area. The Bill also tidies up certain drafting errors of a typographical nature in the 1980 Act and these are contained in Schedule 2 of the Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Registration Fees) Amendment Bill 1981

This Bill is subsidiary to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands-Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1981, introduced earlier. The amendment contained in the Bill clarifies a legal point that became apparent during the drafting of the complementary State legislation. The effect of the amendment is to ensure that the relevant provisions of the legislation will apply to transfers of title held by several corporations where two or more of the corporations are related and not only to cases where all the corporations are related. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Minerals (Submerged Lands) Bill 1981

This Bill, and the associated Bills, will provide a framework for the exploration for and production of minerals other than petroleum on Australia's continental shelf beyond the outer limit of the three mile territorial sea. The Bills are part of the agreed arrangements on off-shore mining in the context of the off-shore constitutional settlement. The arrangements for off-shore petroleum were dealt with in the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Act 1980 passed in May last year. The minerals Bills were also prepared in close consultations with the States and their extensive experience in the administration of mining operations made a valuable contribution in this regard. The provisions follow closely the principles agreed in regard to off-shore petroleum mining.

There is increasing interest world-wide in other mineral resources of the seabed. Deposits so far identified include construction materials such as sand, gravel, limestone, et cetera; detrital minerals such as tin, gold, platinum, diamonds; and the beach sand minerals such as magnetite, ilmenite, rutile, zircon, monazite; and phosporite. Deposits of this nature have been identified on the continental shelves of many countries. The value of production of minerals recovered from the seabed so far is however small when compared with that of off-shore oil and natural gas.

There has not been much activity in mining for other minerals in Australia's off-shore areas to date and the constitutional uncertainty may have been a contributing factor in this regard. There are three off-shore exploration permits current at present, two off New South Wales and one off Queensland, but no production licences have yet been granted. There are, in addition, several on-shore coal leases in New South Wales which extend off-shore and some of these subterranean mining operations are carried out as extensions of on-shore operations. It is also understood that in Tasmania there may be some subterranean mining of tungsten from on-shore.

There is as yet no Commonwealth legislation to cover off-shore minerals other than petroleum. However, in this respect the Australian Minerals and Energy Council agreed in 1978 that mining titles for off-shore minerals could be issued under the respective State laws. The Commonwealth stipulated, however, that this procedure was without prejudice to any future arrangements and the operators involved must be prepared to accept the risk that any title so granted may not be considered valid. The Commonwealth undertook to transition such titles when new legislation is enacted. The Bill contains transitional provisions to deal with such titles.

As I have already mentioned, the arrangements for off-shore minerals being given effect to in this Bill follow closely the arrangements for off-shore petroleum. I shall not repeat the constitutional history or the history of the negotiations with the States which were outlined when the package of off-shore Bills was introduced in May last year. The basic agreement between the Commonwealth and the States on off-shore mining, including petroleum, included the following:
all off-shore mining would be conducted in accordance with a common mining code;

Commonwealth legislation would apply beyond the three-mile territorial sea and State legislation within the three-mile territorial sea, but for reasons of administration all underground mining extending from on-shore will be excluded and controlled by State legislation;
there would be joint authorities in respect of all mining operators beyond the three-mile territorial sea consisting of the relevant Commonwealth and State Ministers;

the joint authorities would be responsible for major matters relating to titles, for example, granting or refusal, renewal, transfer, farmins, et cetera. The view of the Commonwealth Minister would prevail in the case of disagreement;
the States and the Northern Territory would have an active role in the day to day administration of the legislation.

The original agreement between the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Premiers left the question of royalties for off-shore minerals for further consideration. Following further consultation with the States the arrangement embodied in the Bill is that royalties will be shared 60/40 between the States, including Northern Territory, and the Commonwealth in the same way as applies to petroleum. The sharing arrangement is intended to apply both beyond and within the three-mile territorial sea and also to underground mining extending from on-shore.

The States and the Northern Territory will retain all fees received from title holders and applicants for titles. This is seen, at least in part, as a recompense to the States for the administrative expenses; as in the case of off-shore petroleum the States and the Northern Territory will undertake the day to day administration and will be the primary point of contact between the industry and the governments.

Turning now to the provisions of the Bill, the off-shore mining agreements I mentioned earlier are given effect to in the Bill and in particular I refer to Part II of the Bill where the establishment, functions and procedures of the joint authorities and designated authorities-relevant State and Northern Territory Minister-are set out in detail. Part III deals with the application of laws in the area adjacent to States and Territories and the principle embodied in this Part is that the laws of the State or Territory should apply in the off-shore area adjacent to that State or Territory for all purposes connected with the off-shore mining of minerals.

Part IV of the Bill is the actual mining code. The Bill provides for a two stage system of titles. An exploration title, referred to as an 'exploration permit', may be followed by a production title, referred to as a 'production licence'. In addition, provision has been made for a 'works authority' which will authorise a title holder to have access to areas outside his title area to carry out operations or to construct works associated with operations in the title area.

The Bill provides for the granting of an exploration permit to an applicant. Such a permit grants its holder a right to explore for minerals in an area not exceeding 500 blocks, that is an area of approximately 575 square miles. The initial permit term is two years, and there is provision for renewals, for periods of two years each, subject to the permittee's compliance with the permit conditions and the legislation. Upon each renewal the permittee must relinquish at least one quarter of the area previously held. Because of the many unknown factors in off-shore mineral technology it is not possible to specify precise permit conditions in this Bill. The joint authority will therefore determine the conditions of each permit according to the circumstances of the case. In this respect the possible effect on the environment will be given full consideration under the Commonwealth Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act which, of course, applies in relation to decisions taken by the Commonwealth; and it is anticipated that the States will exercise similar control in respect of the three-mile territorial sea area.

A permittee may apply for a production licence, covering no more than 50 blocks, that is an area of approximately 58 square miles, of his previous permit area. A person who is not a permittee may also apply for a licence over an area that is not the subject of an exploration or production title. A licence and subsequent renewals may be granted at the discretion of the joint authority for periods each not exceeding 21 years. It is a requirement of production titles that a holder shall annually expend on exploration or recovery operations an amount calculated at $5,000 per block, that is for a maximum licence area of 50 blocks a total of $250,000 must be spent each year. If, however, minerals are recovered in the licence area the value of the minerals recovered is offset against the required expenditure. The joint authority has a discretion to grant an exemption from this provision to deal with a situation where the level of expenditure required may be too high.

It is an important feature of this Bill that applicants, permittees and licensees will be required to provide adequate information and reports, including samples where appropriate, on exploration and production activities. The overall geological knowledge of the seabed obtained is important to the Government in its systematic assessment of mineral resources. The information will be publicly available after a short period of confidentiality and this is expected to make a valuable contribution to other potential explorers. In accordance with the Convention on the Continental Shelf there is a provision in this Bill for the joint authority to consent to mineral exploration in the course of scientific investigations. The Convention also requires that operations on the continental shelf must not result in any unnecessary interference with navigation, fishing or the conservation of the resources of the sea and seabed and this is covered in the Bill.

Included in the Bill are provisions for the making of operating and safety regulations. The Bill, as does the petroleum legislation, gives the designated authority the power to issue direction on any matters with respect to which regulations may be made. Approval of the joint authority is required for directions of a standing nature. Included in this Bill are transitional provisions which enable holders of current State off-shore titles granted under arrangements I have already mentioned to apply for comparable titles under this legislation. The grant of such a title will be subject to such conditions as the joint authority thinks fit but it is intended to match as far as possible the conditions of the current titles for the unexpired portions of their terms. The Bill provides for the normal requirements associated with mining administration such as keeping a register, the appointment of inspectors, and for courts of competent jurisdiction for the prosecution of offences and other proceedings. There are also the usual provisions in the Bill for the joint authority to grant variation, suspension of, or exemption from conditions of a title, and for the surrender and cancellation of titles.

The provisions in the associated Bills deal with money matters and for that reason have to be contained in separate Bills. The Royalties Bill imposes an obligation on licence holders to pay royalties. As I have mentioned before the off-shore minerals industry in Australia is in a very early stage of development and the economics of developing off-shore minerals deposits are largely unknown. For that reason it is felt that flexibility is required in the setting of royalty rates and the Bill provides that the rate is to be set by the joint authorities in relation to specific minerals. Once, however, a rate is set and the determination published in the Gazette, it is intended that it will apply uniformly in all off-shore areas. However, to cope with situations where a particular operation may be uneconomic the joint authority is given the power to reduce the royalty. Uniform criteria would be applied in the exercise of this power. The joint authority is also given power to determine the landed value of a mineral and the quantity of a mineral recovered for the purpose of determining the amount of royalty payable by a licensee.

The Exploration Permit Fees Bill, the Production Licence Fees Bill and the Works Authority Bill impose annual fees in respect of these titles. The annual permit fee is $10 per block or $300 whichever is greater, the annual licence fee is $100 per block, and the annual works authority fee is $10 per hectare. The Registration Fees Bill imposes a fee on the registration of an instrument by which an interest in a title is assigned or dealt with in some other way. The fee imposed is 1.5 per cent of the value of the interest with a minimum of $300. In certain special cases the maximum fee payable is $3,000.

The legislation provides a framework for the off-shore mining industry, which I feel sure will grow in importance in the years to come. At the same time the legislation illustrates yet again the success of the Government's co-operative federalism policy where the legal powers and responsibilities of the Commonwealth and the administrative experience of the States are combined for the mutual benefit of both and for the good of Australia. It is intended that once this Bill, and the associated Bills, are passed the States will introduce complementary legislation to apply in the three-mile territorial sea area and so give effect to the agreement for a common off-shore minerals code. The Commonwealth legislation will be proclaimed to come into effect after all the States and the Northern Territory have their own legislation in place. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
