PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Evans) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to insurance intermediaries.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard, noting only as I do so that this is a long overdue reform measure, that it is based on recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission, that the Government's failure to act in the face of an escalating series of broking-house collapses is assuming positively scandalous dimensions, and that I hope that the Government's mind will be so concentrated by the introduction of this Bill that it will take the initiative on the issue early in the Budget session. If it does not, I give notice that the matters in issue here will be pursued very vigorously indeed.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to establish a statutory framework for the regulation of the insurance broking industry and the activities of insurance brokers and agents.

Legislation of this kind has been long awaited by the public, by this Parliament, by State governments and by the insurance broking industry itself. The fact that it comes before the Senate as a private member's Bill is itself an indictment of successive Liberal governments which have failed to introduce such legislation despite overwhelming evidence of the urgent need and the manifest enthusiasm of the community generally for it.

In presenting this Bill to the Senate, I wish at the outset to pay a particular tribute to my colleague, Ralph Jacobi, the honourable member for Hawker, without whose tireless pursuit of legislative reform of the insurance industry this Bill would never have seen the light of day. The report of the Australian Law Reform Commission on Insurance Agents and Brokers, tabled in this Parliament on 16 September 1980, and on which this Bill is based, was the result of a reference to the Commission in 1976 which was itself made largely in response to repeated requests by Ralph Jacobi. The Government's responses to periodic questions and speeches from Mr Jacobi on this subject have become almost ritual in their evasiveness. The introduction of this Bill represents a declaration that we can wait no longer for the Government to act.

At the outset, a clear distinction must be drawn between insurers on the one hand and insurance brokers and agents on the other hand. The Life Insurance Act 1945 and the Insurance Act 1973 regulate the operation of insurers, both life and general, through the administrative supervision of the Life Insurance Commissioner and the Insurance Commissioner respectively. The present Bill is concerned with brokers and agents and not with insurers, although their financial relationships are necessarily closely intertwined.

Insurance brokers have been usefully defined as persons who 'acting with complete freedom as to their choice of undertaking, bring together, with a view to the insurance or re-insurance of risks, persons seeking insurance or re-insurance and insurance or re-insurance undertakings, carry out work preparatory to the conclusion of contracts of insurance or re-insurance and, where appropriate, assist in the administration and performance of such contracts, in particular in the event of a claim' (United Kingdom, Department of Trade, 'Insurance Intermediaries', Command Paper No. 715 (1975) page 8). The key distinction between a broker and an insurance agent is that, whereas a broker possesses an ability to act with complete freedom as to the choice of the insurer with which he arranges his client's insurance cover, an agent is normally committed to the promotion of the policies or interests of one or a limited number of insurance companies.

According to Australian Bureau of Statistics figures published in 1979, there are more than 550 insurance broking houses in Australia, employing roughly 5,600 individuals. Approximately 10,000 agents sell life insurance on a full time basis and there are in addition large numbers of part time insurance agents, the majority of whom arrange insurance solely for purposes connected with their main occupation. At present, a large number of insurance agents incorrectly and often misleadingly describe themselves as insurance brokers and it is part of the purpose of this Bill to ensure that the terminology is correctly applied. Accordingly, Clause 30 of this Bill makes it an offence for any insurance intermediary other than a registered broker to describe himself or his business in a way that would lead a person into believing that he was an insurance broker.

In recent years the insurance broking industry has become infamous for the dramatic collapses of broking houses. Hardly a month goes by but we read the headline 'another insurance broker in liquidation'. This is not a new phenomenon. The law Reform Commission report itemised 27 insurance broker insolvencies in New South Wales and Victoria between 1969 and 1979 with estimated losses totalling $7.3m. The Commission was unable to obtain information in relation to 17 other cases of alleged insolvency. Estimates for 1980 and 1981 put losses at around $7m for the two year period, making the total estimated losses-and this must be regarded as a conservative figure in the absence of systematic statistics-$14m over the 12 year period 1969-1981.

I shall cite some examples to remind honourable senators more vividly of the problems. In January 1979, Cyril Stanley Pty Ltd collapsed with debts of $1.9m and an estimated deficiency of $619,000. In May 1979 the Hamilton Group of Companies became insolvent with an estimated $400,000 owed to unsecured creditors. In 1980 six Western Australian broking companies collapsed with outstanding debts totalling well over $3m. Those companies were Douglas Insurance Brokers Pty Ltd, John D. Seale and Co. Pty Ltd, Ibis Holdings Pty Ltd, Morley Insurance Brokers Pty Ltd, Dyson Insurance Brokers Pty Ltd and Town and Country Insurance Brokers Pty Ltd. Over the past 18 months, the total number of broker collapses in Western Australia has risen to at least 12, and , as recently as March, Beneficial Insurance Brokers Pty Ltd of Perth went into receivership with an estimated premium shortfall of $1m.

In New South Wales, 14 insurance brokers have stopped trading in 18 months. Of these perhaps the most notorious is the One Stop Insurance Shop broking group. The New South Wales part of this operation went into liquidation in March of this year with debts of $1m and the same amount was owed when One Stop Insurance Shop Pty Ltd in Victoria went into provisional liquidation. The Queensland affairs of the company are also in the hands of a liquidator. The collapse of the One Stop operation affected some 34,000 policy holders throughout Australia and led directly to the collapse of Australian Premium Financing Company Pty Ltd which had financed those operations.

Also in March of this year two Victorian brokers folded up. Anthony H. Bown and Associates Pty Ltd went into liquidation with debts of $320,624 and-perhaps the worst case of all-Kinloch (Insurances) Pty Ltd was placed in the hands of a liquidator in March 1981 with estimated debts of $3m after a premium turnover estimated at $6m annually.

The catalogue of disaster goes on. Let us look at those who really suffer when a broker becomes insolvent. If an insurance broker fails, a policy holder who has in good faith forwarded his premium to the broker may find that, owing to the broker's failure to forward the premium to the insurance company, he is uninsured. In such circumstances, the policy holder must-unless the insurer accepts the loss-pay a second premium in order to maintain his cover. Worse still, if a claim arises in the period between the collapse of the broker and the payment of a second premium, the policy holder is, subject to the benevolence of the insurance company, completely uninsured. It must be said that insurers have tended increasingly in recent years to maintain cover where a initial premium has been paid to the failed broker, but it is obviously undesirable for the policy holder to be thus dependent on the whim of the insurer.

Equally, an insurance company may have forwarded funds to the failed broker in settlement of a claim and these moneys may have been mixed with the general funds of the broker instead of being transferred to the insured. Again the insurer and insured face a dispute as to who is liable to bear that loss and, on the general common law principle that the broker is the agent of the insured, it will most often be borne by the insured. An examination of the accounts of insolvent brokers shows that insurance premiums received by the broker but not paid to the insurer usually form the greater part of the debts owed by the broker. When a broker becomes insolvent, it is the practice-although it is not clear what is the strict legal position-to treat such premium moneys as being available for the general creditors of the broker and not as being available only to the insured persons who have paid the relevant premiums or those insurers who have extended the relevant cover.

I need elaborate no further to show how utterly unsatisfactory the current position is and how urgent the need for regulation of the broking industry in the interests of the public and creditors alike.

The need for regulation of agents and brokers has long been recognised, both in overseas and State jurisdictions, and by all sections of the community involved with the broking industry. The Queensland Insurance Act 1960-1976 provides for the licensing of insurance brokers and for their regulation and supervision by the State Insurance Commissioner. In the United Kingdom, the Insurance Brokers (Registration) Act 1977 established an Insurance Brokers Registration Council together with detailed regulation of the financial affairs of brokers. Following a report in 1975, the New Zealand Parliament enacted the Insurance Law Reform Act 1977 which contains provisions concerning responsibility for the actions of insurance agents.

I would remind honourable senators that the Whitlam Labor Government had, before its sacking in November 1975, prepared draft legislation for regulation of the broking industry. The proposed legislation would have established strict guidelines as to the skill and educational qualifications for insurance brokers and would have provided for renewable licenses to be issued by the Insurance Commissioner. As with so many other worthy Labor legislative initiatives, that particular proposal was nipped in the bud by Mr Fraser's successful grab for power.

Since then, we have observed a dizzying series of somersaults by the present Government. In April 1976, the then Minister assisting the Treasurer, Mr Robinson, announced that the Government would introduce legislation for the licensing of insurance brokers. On 11 March 1977, however, the Government reversed its decision and announced its intention to pursue a scheme of self-regulation. The decision to reject legislative regulation of the industry was allegedly made on the basis of the complexity of the proposed legislation, in that it was 'an overkill situation of using a sledgehammer to crack a walnut'.

In February 1979, the Treasurer, Mr Howard, announced that he would seek the Government's approval to develop legislation for a voluntary regulation arrangement for brokers. Six months later he had changed his mind again. The Government refused to grasp the nettle, claiming that there was no consensus among the various bodies representing insurance brokers on the form of controls that might be introduced. The Treasurer proposed to wait until the Law Reform Commission's report was tabled.

One might have been forgiven for expecting that the tabling of the Commission's report would finally have stimulated some action. Great was our disbelief when, upon the tabling of the Law Reform Commission's report in September 1980 after over three years of the most extensive consultation with hundreds of representatives of the broking industry, consumer groups, business, legal and other interests, the Treasurer announced that as a first step in the Government's consideration of the present report, he proposed to seek the views of insurance industry organisations and other interested parties.

The report's recommendations, with which I shall deal in more detail shortly, were clear and unequivocal. That the Government should propose further consultation when presented with a complete blueprint for reform shows how pathological is its capacity for vacillation and how feeble its commitment to the regulation of business in the public interest. This is yet another area-like trade practices, company law and family law-where the need for national regulatory legislation is almost universally acknowledged, but this Government, obsessed by the deregulation ideology which has characterised the whole razor gang performance, continues to shirk its responsibilities.

It should be noted here that the Government cannot even claim in its own defence that the insurance broking lobby is against such legislation. For many years now the various bodies representing insurance brokers-notably the Confederation of Insurance Brokers of Australia, the Insurance Brokers Association and the Insurance Brokers Council of Australia-have been calling for legislation to regulate the broking industry. Those bodies impose their own stringent regulations upon member brokers and have long been concerned that the public and the industry itself are poorly served by the spectacular crashes of broking companies. While there has been disagreement over the degree to which any regulatory body should be controlled by the industry or by the government, there has been a striking unanimity in the calls for compulsory registration of brokers, for professional indemnity insurance and for implementation of the Law Reform Commission's other recommendations.

The frustration at the Government's inaction has been felt in other places. Western Australia recently introduced its own legislation, the General Insurance Brokers and Agents Bill 1981, and the New South Wales Government gave notice as recently as 21 May that it was preparing legislation which it would introduce unless the Federal Government took decisive action. The New South Wales Minister for Consumer Affairs, Mr Einfeld, stated on 5 March 1981 that he completely supported the principles inherent in the report of the Law Reform Commission and the Commissioner for Consumer Affairs, Mr Gallagher, repeated last week that the Federal Government's failure to take action would inevitably compel the New South Wales Government to move in this direction. In the last fortnight, the Victorian Minister for Consumer Affairs, Mr Ramsay, has added his voice to the call for national legislation, repeating the urgent request made by the Consumer Affairs Ministers from all States in November 1980 that the Federal Government implement the Law Reform Commission proposals.

It would, in the view of the Opposition, be most unfortunate if the States were compelled to enact their own legislation to meet this need. There is already far too much non-uniformity in areas of commercial regulation which cry out for a uniform national approach. There can be no doubt about the Commonwealth's power to legislate in this area: section 51 (14) of the Constitution gives the Commonwealth Parliament power to make laws with respect to 'insurance, other than State insurance; also State insurance extending beyond the limits of the State concerned'. This power covers all private insurance except insurance offered by a State instrumentality within the boundaries of its home State. Equally, there should be no doubt about the Commonwealth's responsibility to enact such legislation. It is, I repeat, an indictment of the present Government that a matter of national public importance should be forced to run the gauntlet as a private member's Bill instead of being introduced with the full weight of the Government behind it. I now turn to consider the provisions of the Bill.

In September 1976, a reference from the then Attorney-General, Mr Ellicott, required the Australian Law Reform Commission to report on the adequacy of the law governing contracts of insurance, having regard to the interests of insurer, insured and the public. In late 1978, in the course of its investigations, the Commission published a discussion paper which included tentative proposals for regulatory control of insurance agents and brokers. These proposals provoked vigorous debate within the insurance industry, particularly amongst agents and brokers, and in order to facilitate the early legislative resolution of the problem, the Commission decided to report separately on the regulation of insurance agents and brokers in advance of completing the full reference on insurance contracts. The Commission's report was completed in January 1980 and tabled in the Federal Parliament on 16 September 1980. A draft Bill was appended to the Commission's report and that draft is, with the insertion of penalties for offences created by the Bill, reproduced in this Bill.

I should stress here that the Opposition is committed to the implementation of the Law Reform Commission's draft legislation in its present form. Apart from the fact that we strongly endorse the substance of those recommendations, we consider it inappropriate that any tampering with the Commission's draft should take place, at least before Parliament has had an opportunity to consider those recommendations in their original form.

The Commission alone has had the benefit of consultation with all interested groups, of expert research and advice and its own careful deliberation. It would make a mockery of that process if personal preference-or the demands of one or other lobby group-were allowed to interfere with the finished product. After three years of internal study, the Commission is better placed than anyone to come up with sensible workable solutions. Before proceeding to matters of detail, I should indicate the scope of the proposed legislation. As an exercise of the constitutional power of the Commonwealth, this Bill when enacted will have national application without the need for complementary State legislation. It is anticipated that the Queensland and Western Australian legislation dealing with this subject will be repealed. The legislation is to apply in respect of insurance offered by friendly societies and to funeral funds insofar as they constitute a form of life insurance. It does not extend to health funds registered under the National Health Act 1953 nor to contracts of re-insurance. Clauses 6 to 8 of the Bill deal with these matters of scope. I would also point out that the Bill binds the Crown in right of the Commonwealth or a Territory and, except as otherwise provided in the Bill, binds the Crown in right of a State.

This Bill is concerned with the regulation of the activities of insurance intermediaries. There are three main types of insurance intermediary: insurance agents, insurance brokers and loss adjusters. The Law Reform Commission concluded that the need for statutory regulation of loss adjusters had not been demonstrated. Accordingly, this Bill applies to agents and brokers but not to loss adjusters.

The distinction between an agent and a broker has already been described. Broadly speaking, an agent acts on behalf of one or a small number of insurance companies, arranging contracts of insurance and settling claims as the agent of the insurance company or companies. The broker, on the other hand, is not-unless he acts under an agreement known as a 'binder'-the agent of any insurance company but rather acts as agent of the insured in arranging a contract of insurance with whichever insurance company he chooses. This Bill provides (clause 11) that all insurance intermediaries (which term is defined for the purposes of this Bill to exclude loss adjusters) other than registered insurance brokers are deemed to be insurance agents.

The provisions of the Bill relating to insurance agents can be briefly summarised. First the Bill clarifies the confused state of the common law by making the insurer responsible to the insured or intending insured for the conduct of his agent or employee (clause 10). Thus the insurer is liable for any loss or damage caused by the conduct of his agent which is relied on in good faith by the insured, whether or not the agent acted within the scope of his authority or employment. Any agreement which seeks to limit this responsibility is void and it is an offence to make or offer to make such an agreement.

Secondly, the Bill makes it an offence for an agent or employee of an insurer wilfully and with intent to deceive to misrepresent the effect of, or benefits available under, an insurance policy or to misrecord information on a proposal or claim form or to advise an insured or intending insured to do so (clause 12). Thirdly, the Bill confirms the common law agency principle that the payment of a premium to an insurance agent by an intending insured discharges the insured's liability to the insurer (clause 13) and the payment by an insurer to an agent of claim moneys does not discharge the insurer's liability to the insured (clause 13 (2)). It should be noted that in view of the safeguards already referred to, the Law Reform Commission concluded that occupational regulation of insurance agents was unnecessary, at least at this stage, and the Bill accordingly makes no such provision.

Turning now to insurance brokers, the major structural impact of this Bill is the introduction of a statutory system of broker registration. The Law Reform Commission concluded that the risk of broker insolvency and of consequent harm to the insuring public-so graphically illustrated by the string of collapses in recent months-could only be reduced by compulsory registration and the imposition of clear standards of financial probity, to be enforced through periodical audits and independent inspections.

Clause 17 of the Bill accordingly prohibits the conduct of an insurance broking business-whether in life insurance or general insurance-unless the individual or corporation concerned is registered by the Life Insurance Commissioner or the Insurance Commissioner as the case may be. Registration must be effected annually and may be cancelled on the broker's application or if the broker or a director, employee or agent of the broker is convicted of an offence relating to insurance or an offence of dishonesty where the Commissioner is of the opinion that the offence renders the person unfit to carry on business as an insurance broker. Heavy penalties are prescribed for the carrying on of a broking business without registration or after suspension of registration.

It should be emphasised that the responsibility for registering insurance brokers is placed upon the existing statutory Insurance Commissioners and not upon a panel or other regulatory body comprising industry representatives. The Law Reform Commission considered the options fully and had no hesitation in recommending that an expert and disinterested body-namely the offices of the Life Insurance Commissioner and the Insurance Commissioner-should be responsible for the administration of the legislation, rather than members of a relatively small occupational group who might have a direct or indirect personal stake in the outcome of decisions as to registration or suspension (Law Reform Commission report paragraphs 124-127). Clause 32 of the Bill provides that the Commissioners' decisions are subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The Bill contains a number of specific provisions regulating the conduct of a broking business. First, a registered insurance broker must pay all moneys received by him on account of another person (whether premiums from an insured or claim moneys from an insurer) into a separate account to be called the 'insurance broking account' (clause 21). Unless the written consent of the relevant Commissioner is obtained, the only permitted withdrawals from this account are for payment to the person entitled to the money or for investment in prescribed securities. All moneys received by a broker on another person's account, and any securities in which such moneys are invested, are subject to a trust in favour of the person entitled to them. This is an important provision which will give a considerable degree of protection to those entitled to the moneys received and invested by a broker.

Secondly, a registered broker must comply with certain disclosure requirements. As soon as practicable after arranging a contract of insurance, the broker must give the insured and the insurer particulars in writing of any remuneration or other benefit received by the broker in relation to the contract and must inform the insured of the name and a place of business of the insured (clause 25). A broker must, before doing any business as agent for an insurer or under a binder, inform the intending insured that in effecting the contract of insurance he will be acting as agent of the insurer and not of the insured (clauses 25, 15 and 16). A registered broker is, furthermore, subject to the same penalties as an insurance agent for wilful deceptive conduct in relation to a contract of insurance or an insurance claim (clause 12). Finally, a registered insurance broker is prohibited from describing himself or his business in a way that would lead a person into believing that he was an insurer or mislead a person as to the nature of his insurance business (clause 23).

As regards financial regulation, the Bill provides for regulations to be made for the inspection or audit of the books, accounts and records kept by registered insurance brokers (clause 33). Clause 17 (1) (b) of the Bill makes it compulsory for an insurance broker to maintain with an approved insurer professional indemnity and fidelity guarantee insurance. Clause 27 complements clause 17 by providing that moneys paid to a broker under a professional indemnity insurance policy are not available on the insolvency or the winding-up of the broker for division among the creditors of the broker generally but must be paid to the person whose claim against the broker was subject to the indemnity. Clause 26 prohibits an insurance broker from receiving from an insurer any gift, gratuity, benefit or other reward except as remuneration for services in arranging an insurance contract or settling a claim. Similarly, an insurer is prohibited from paying remuneration to a broker at a rate which varies according to the number of contracts, the total amount of premium or the total sums insured.

The Bill also clarifies the legal position as between insurers and brokers. It leaves essentially unchanged the common law principle that it is the insured, not the insurer, who is responsible for the conduct of a broker. This responsibility stems from the broker's role as agent of the insured and not the insurer. The Bill, however, makes two important statutory exceptions to this rule. First, by clause 13 (1) the Bill provides that the payment of a premium to a broker discharges the insured's liability to the insurer in respect of that premium. Conversely, the payment to a broker by an insurer of moneys intended for the insured does not discharge the insurer's responsibility to the insured in respect of those funds. The rationale for this statutory re-allocation of financial responsibility is that it is the insurer, not the insured, who agrees with the broker on credit terms and acquiesces in a broker's temporary treatment of premium or claims moneys as his own. Furthermore, it is the insurer, not the insured, who is in the better position to know the overall payment performance of a broker and to become aware of his impending insolvency.

The second exception to the rule that the broker is the agent of the insured is established by clause 14. This provision makes the insurer responsible for the conduct of a broker in doing business under a binder, that is, in circumstances where the broker has the authority to enter contracts of insurance on behalf of the insurer or to settle claims as agent for the insurer.

Finally, clause 29 provides that neither an insurance broker, nor a director, employee or agent of an insurance broker shall be an insurer or a director or employee of an insurer. Conversely, no insurer or director or employee of an insurer may be an insurance broker or a director employee or agent of an insurance broker.

The Law Reform Commission deliberately chose to make no recommendation regarding penalties for offences under the proposed legislation. The penalties contained in this Bill are based on the penalties imposed for equivalent offences in the Companies Bill 1981, the Securities Industry Act 1980, and the Insurance Act 1973. The method adopted in the Companies Bill 1981, has, as far as possible, been followed, namely that a graded scale of penalties has been employed in order to ensure comparable penalties for similar offences. For the information of honourable senators, with the concurrence of the Senate I incorporate in Hansard a table setting out the scale of penalties in the Companies Bill 1981, and the offences to which each penalty applies. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Wool Industry Amendment Bill 1981 is to facilitate the rotation of the Market Support Fund which is a levy struck on wool growers of 5 per cent of sale proceeds which has been collected ever since 1974 and which has now accumulated to some $350m or $400m. Since there is no clear need for or justification for the indefinite additions to this Fund the amending Act of last year made provision for the payments to be returned to wool growers on a first-in, first-out basis as roughly a seven-year revolving fund, with payments made by growers in one year being withdrawn seven years later.

SPEECH.PARA: When the original legislation was introduced by the Labor Government in 1974 the clear intention and the understanding-it was my understanding and I believe the understanding of everyone who took a serious interest in it at the time-were that the Fund would ultimately revolve, although no provision was made for that in the original legislation. The legislation of 1974 which first struck the levy was, of course, associated with the historic decision of the then Labor Government to guarantee and to fix a seasonal minimum reserve price, a policy which successive conservative governments over more than two decades had refused to implement but which I note with some satisfaction they have subsequently retained.

The amendments contained in the Bill before us primarily facilitate the operations of the rotation of that Fund and the disbursement in this financial year of some $46m to growers. However, the second amendment in the Bill requires disclosure of pecuniary interests by members of the Australian Wool Corporation in line with a recent and welcome Government policy of enforcing a higher degree of disclosure of pecuniary interest and possible conflict of interest upon members of statutory corporations. The only real regret the Opposition has about this is the Government's refusal to impose upon itself and its own members the standards which it imposes upon statutory authorities under its control.

The third provision is to increase by two the membership of the Australian Wool Testing Authority. I would like to make some comments about that. This legislation to add two members to the Australian Wool Testing Authority was introduced seven days after the razor gang decision to sell the Authority was announced. People not familiar with the method of operation of this Government might find that very hard to believe. It is in fact the epitome of policy-making on the run whereby one policy, this policy to increase by two the membership of the Australian Wool Testing Authority, was run over on the way to the starting blocks by the razor gang decision to abolish and sell the Wool Testing Authority. Most people would be amazed if that sort of thing happened in a banana republic, but in the banana republic of Malcolm Fraser it is such an everyday occurrence that it scarcely attracted any attention. The fact is that the legislation, according to the Government's declared policy intention, is obsolete before it is even introduced into the Parliament, let alone passed. The razor gang report said:
We propose to offer as a going concern . . . the Australian Wool Testing Laboratory and some Commonwealth equity in the Wool Stores.

Notwithstanding the characteristic obfuscation and prevarication from the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, the intent clearly stated in the report was to sell the Wool Testing Authority. The implications of that go well beyond the fact that the Government has contradicted one of its own decisions even before the decision that was contradicted came into the Parliament. It contradicted a policy in advance. The Minister for Primary Industry was a member of the ministerial review committee. Was he not aware of the implications of that razor gang decision? Even allowing for the fact that the report in toto was little more than an exercise in political stunting hastily put together, this matter reveals more clearly than has ever been revealed previously the fundamental incompetence of the Minister for Primary Industry. He ought to be an object of ridicule. He has certainly been an object of hostility from the wool industry over the last few months. He ought to be an object of contempt and ridicule from the whole population. In fact I am tempted to believe that agriculture would be better off if the undertaker were still in charge of it.

The two proclaimed objectives of the razor gang report in toto, provided the cash was securely locked up, were, firstly, a reduction in government expenditure and, secondly, a desire to dispense with superfluous government functions and authorities. The amount of money saved, of course, was insignificant. The gross saving, according to the Government's estimates, is an amount of $560m over a period. That makes no allowance for the new cost which will be incurred by the transfer of a number of government responsibilities to the private sector. It may well be that the net savings to Government revenue, pursuant to the razor gang decisions, are negligible or even negative.

But if the Government was seriously interested in saving the taxpayers' money, why did it not look at some of these things: The Northern Territory railway getting $430m-it was known even before the decision was made that that railway could make no contribution whatsoever to its capital cost and that it is money down the drain; $220m for a new Parliament House; $80m for Casey University; $20m for the Prime Minister's 707s; $12m for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting; $360m promised before the last election for various airport works; $120m in 1981 dollars for the Burdekin Dam; $2m for a Canberra racetrack, because the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is a motor racing freak; $500,000 for that Liberal Party propaganda outfit called the Government Information Unit; and the unknown cost of a VIP trip to Armidale by the Prime Minister last Thursday to buy a bull! Of course, the so-called parliamentary security imposed within the last three years, which is probably costing about half a million dollars a year, is a manifestation of the Prime Minister's desire to live out his military command fantasies, a desire in which he was given an excuse to indulge after the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation planted that bomb in the rubbish bin outside the Hilton Hotel.

What is the common thread about all these major and minor, ridiculous and important, areas of government expenditure which were sacrosanct? What is the common thread? They are all Malcolm Fraser's pet projects. That is the common thread. Nothing to which the Prime Minister had given his personal support or about which he had a manic obsession-to borrow a phrase from one of his back benchers-was to be touched by this ministerial review committee. I have not even mentioned the host of irrational, inefficient tax dodges which he promised prior to the last election and about which we will be saying much more in the next couple of weeks, provided the Government does not use the guillotine in the Senate too severely.

I return to the Australian Wool Testing Authority. Bearing in mind that the proclaimed primary objective of the ministerial review committee was to cut government expenditure-even though it did not live up to that proclaimed objective-there was nothing to be gained financially by the Government by selling the Wool Testing Authority. No government money goes into the institution. It returned a profit of $1.2m in the last year which was paid to the Australian Wool Corporation, of which the Wool Testing Authority is effectively a branch. So there was no recurring cost to the Government in allowing the Authority to continue to operate in its present way.

It may have been misinformed that by selling the Authority, as the Government intends to sell a number of other capital items, it could have received a short term revenue boost. That does not apply in this case either because if the Authority is sold the proceeds will be paid into industry trust accounts which effectively will still be Wool Corporation money and not government money. That fact was brought out by the honourable member for Canning (Mr Bungey) on 13 May by way of question to the Minister for Primary Industry. Was the Minister for Primary Industry so fundamentally ignorant of the operations of his own Department that he did not realise that if the Authority was sold the Corporation, and not the Government, would receive the proceeds?

The second declared objective of the ministerial review committee was to dispense with superfluous government functions and responsibilities. It might have seemed superficially that the decision to dispose of the Wool Testing Authority at least met that objective. However, after the decision was announced it prompted some very hostile criticism from rather surprising political quarters. Probably the most significant criticism was that from Mr Ian McLachlan, who happens to be president of the Wool Council of Australia, who is also a long-standing director of Elder Smith-Goldsbrough Mort Ltd and who is, I would take for granted, a member of the Adelaide Club, certainly a member of the Adelaide establishment and a member of one of the old, Australian, pure merino grazing families. In other words, he is a pillar of the Adelaide establishment. In criticism of the Government, Mr McLachlan is reported in an article which states:
Private enterprise had a poor record in wool testing . . .
The private sector had been involved in the wool testing field three times in the past.
It had not only failed on each occasion, but also had threatened the quality and standards of objective measurement of the Australian Wool Clip, he said.

Mr McLachlan said the proposed sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority appeared to be for 'purely cosmetic reasons' with the main advantage to Government being a reduction in public service staff numbers.

That article comes from the Weekly Times of 6 May 1981. That is a sample of the sort of criticism which the Government rightly received, not from members of the Labor Party or even from people who are associated with, sympathetic to or vote for the Labor Party, but from pillars of the agricultural establishment who are normally politically aligned with the governing parties. I repeat: Was the Minister for Primary Industry so fundamentally ignorant of the functions of his own Department and of the political realities of the agricultural sector that he was not aware of the implications of this decision? Of course, that sort of criticism very promptly provoked a backdown. The Minister was questioned again in the House on 14 May by Mr Falconer. He said that the Government had no intention 'simply to sell the Australian Wool Testing Authority to the highest bidder'. He added:
That body will be set up either as a wool testing house or as a foundation . . .
That is a theme which he followed up in a Press statement issued the next day, 15 May. A few extracts from that statement include:

There will be no rush into selling the AWTA. In fact, the final decision on the sale of the Authority will be determined by the Minister for Primary Industry in conjunction with the Australian Wool Corporation.
The fundamental aim is to ensure that the AWTA continues to operate in precisely the same way as it does today.
The Government believes--
and this is crucial-
that this can best be achieved by the establishment of a special Foundation that will continue the present functions of the Authority.

In other words, having been finally made aware by Mr Falconer, Mr McLachlan and the honourable member for Canning, among others, of just what the razor gang had proposed to do the Minister, in order to extricate himself from the embarrassing position into which his own fundamental incompetence had thrust him, was committing the Government to establishing yet another foundation or statutory authority to administer the Australian Wool Testing Authority. That is a complete contradiction of the second proclaimed objective of the razor gang review. Government policy now is that an institution which had operated as a segment of the Australian Wool Corporation is be be hived off and another authority is to be established. Of course, it will not be called a statutory authority. For cosmetic reasons it will be called something else, but that is what it will be. The last sentence of that ministerial Press release states:
There is no inconsistency between the Government's plans for the future of the AWTA and the announcement in the Committee's report.
That is pure newspeak. One can only speculate whether comments such as that are a result of Mr Nixon's breathtaking audacity or his cerebral handicap. I move:
At end of motion add ', but the Senate calls on the Government not to proceed with the sale of the Australian Wool Testing Authority as announced in the Review of Commonwealth Functions'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Wool Industry Amendment Bill 1981. I note that amongst other things the previous speaker, Senator Walsh, indicated a measure of concern about the capacity and the work of the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon. My only comment is that in primary industry and indeed the community at large the Minister is held in the highest regard. I believe that his performance is stamping him yet again as one of the best performers in this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk briefly about the Bill because it is a significant Bill. It brings into operation the determination of the industry and this Government that the Market Support Fund should start to revolve. The Bill provides the administrative arrangements necessary to bring about distributions from the Fund. It had long been responsibly determined that the Fund, which was the base for the real and effective operation of the Australian Wool Corporation in the market-place, should attain and be held at a sufficiently high level so that the Corporation could work in the market-place. Indeed it has worked in the market-place in a responsible and effective manner. I believe it is generally conceded that a figure of some $350m might be a proper figure for such a reserve. That amount, of course, has since been passed. The Fund stands significantly in excess of $400m. The time certainly is ripe for the revolving of the Fund to take place.

I think that in a debate such as this some comment should be made about the operation of the Australian Wool Corporation. The capacity of the Australian Wool Corporation to function is largely brought about by the existence of this Fund, amongst other things. The Fund has been in operation since September 1974. It has made a significant contribution to the wool industry in Australia. It has been significant both to the producer of wool and to the user. The producer has succeeded in reaching in the open market-place a price level which, in the main, is as high as humanly possible in all the circumstances. But more importantly, from the point of view of the producer and the user, it has succeeded in the objective of establishing a marketing system for wool which not only has relevance to the level of price but also, more importantly, has relevance to the stability of price.

This particular effect of the operation of the Corporation has been of great significance in building up a real measure of confidence in the user industry. Indeed, sometimes individuals in various areas of primary industry have been criticised for involvement in quite massive statutory marketing organisations. The suggestion is that such involvement relates, of course, to some form of socialisation. I think the comment should be made that the survival of the individual-indeed, primary industry in this country largely comprises individual enterprises-in the world in which we live, a world in which a great deal of government to government trading and authority to government trading takes place, is in no small measure determined by his ability, capacity and determination to be involved in a large operation in which he has a significant say in the marketing field.

As I have said, the Market Support Fund was established in September 1974 with the purpose of being the basic operating fund for the Corporation in the market-place. Wool growers have contributed to the Fund through a 5 per cent deduction from gross wool receipts. A further 3 per cent is deducted for research and promotion and that amount is matched by the Government. I think a measure of congratulations should be offered to the industry itself. Over the years it has been able to support not only in a very real sense its research and promotion but also, in a total sense, its marketing procedures and methods. This industry has ridden the tides of problems in the economic world absolutely under its own steam. It has accepted the responsibility to operate by itself and for itself. The real implementation of this marketing system and indeed, many other changes in the wool industry was preluded by the introduction and finally, acceptance, of the scientific measurement and description of wool. These measures made the system which now operates and which is consistently being improved a real possibility.

The wool industry in Australia is virtually as old as the continent itself. It is an industry in which Australia produces the most and the best in the world. It is an industry which I believe has a significant place in the history, the character and the development of this country. It has contributed very significantly to both extensive and intensive grazing of Australian pastures. It has been significant in developing new systems of land utilisation and stock management. The wool industry has seen the introduction of an extensive range of chemicals and it has been involved with the introduction of many new and important pasture types.

The payments to be made in this revolving scheme are to be made on a first-in first-out basis. The controlling authority will be the Australian Wool Corporation. The brokers and registered agents will handle the actual detail. For the Fund to revolve a fairly complex set of administrative arrangements must be implemented. That, of course, is the basic object of the legislation before us today. Detailed work will remain the responsibility of registered persons, including wool brokers and wool merchants who are registered with the Commissioner of Taxation as collectors of levy or tax. If a registered person ceases to be registered-that of course can occur in some circumstances-then the Corporation has the responsibility of making the payments that are applicable.

The legislation defines the sale of wool as the point of receipt of proceeds for the wool involved. That clarifies a matter that may have caused confusion in the wool futures market and markets of that type.

I will not dwell on this legislation at great length. Perhaps a comment should be made about one or two of the matters raised by Senator Walsh. Sometimes in this sort of circumstance an emotional concept enters into the discussions which in reality has very little, if any, background. Senator Walsh devoted most of his time to the actual proposal to sell the AWTA. Of course, no one in this industry has anything but praise for the Australian Wool Testing Authority. It is certainly not the determination of the Government to sell this body in any unwitting or irresponsible way. It has been clearly demonstrated that this matter will be decided between the Australian Wool Corporation and the Minister. Indeed, so it should be. The Australian Wool Corporation-the industry-funds, runs and, indeed, in a real measure is responsible for the standards of, the Authority.

Senator Walsh was concerned that it could not be seen as a vast cutting exercise in government expenditure. Not everything that is to occur as a result of the razor gang exploit, as it has been described, will be a significant cutting of expenditure exercise. The whole work of this committee has brought a bit of reality to the philosophy of free enterprise. Indeed, it has to be seen to relate to the philosophy and purpose of free enterprise and to put responsibility referable to the States and other areas where it should be. This is a significant objective of the razor gang exercise. It is quite crazy to assume that the industry itself or the Government would allow any falling away of the standards of specification of wool under any system that may evolve from the present circumstance. If, for instance, wool testing becomes an area operated basically by private enterprise, that enterprise would be crazy to enable its testing to be found to be failing--

TALK.START.PARA: —It failed before on three occasions, Senator, and you know it.

—This private testing already exists in New Zealand and in the United Kingdom. I say again that it would be a crazy organisation that would see fit to test a product, whatever that product might be, and then be found to be testing the product incorrectly or adversely. That would be the absolute signature of its own doom. I do not believe that is the object of any enterprise. I hope it is not the object of any enterprise, government or private.

SPEECH.PARA: I just wish to make the point that the legislation provides the administrative capacity to put the revolving part of the fund into operation. It creates effectively a range of administrative procedures that will enable this to be done. So far as the wool testing authority is concerned, it has to be recognised that there is no mention of haste, no rushing into a sales situation. The decision has been made for reasons other than ones of pure cost saving. There is a determination to observe that whatever happens in this transfer, the Australian Wool Corporation and the Government will be in close co-operation, consultation and understanding. There can be no doubt that the objectives of this Government in relation to this industry relate to the permanence and development of one of the most basic industries in this country. I support the legislation.

The Wool Industry Act 1972 preserved and continued in existence the Australian Wool Testing Authority as a body corporate, which operates within the scope of the Australian Wool Corporation's responsibilities.
Current statutory functions of the AWTA are described in Section 57 of that Act as follows:

''(a) to carry out tests, by means of facilities provided, and equipment and materials supplied, by the Corporation, of wool and other fibres, whether natural or otherwise, and wool products and similar products made wholly or partly from other fibres; and
(b) to issue certificates and make reports in respect of tests carried out by the Authority.''
In carrying out these functions the AWTA provides services to a number of key client groups, namely:
woolgrowers, brokers, auction and private buyers and merchant topmakers
wool scourers, carbonisers, fellmongers and combers
textile processors, manufacturers, retailers and importers
architects, builders and public purchasing institutions
Section 58 of the Wool Industry Act 1972 defines the Authority's powers to perform its functions as follows:

''The Authority has power to do all things necessary or convenient to be done for or in connexion with, or as incidental to, the performance of its functions and, in particular, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, has power:
(a) to enter into agreements to carry out tests with persons desiring the tests;
(b) to advertise its services; and
(c) to charge for its services such fees as it determines.''

In exercising these powers in relation to the establishment and management of its technical operations, the Authority has complete independence. However, the Act provides that the Corporation may issue directives to the Authority on other matters. In this regard, such direction has been minimal and then only related to major administrative policy issues. Consistent with the relevant Ministerial statements, both the Corporation and previously the Australian Wool Board have encouraged the Authority to manage its own affairs and to establish its own commercially oriented policies and strategies, to the benefit of the wool industry.
AWTA Objectives
In performing its functions, the AWTA's primary objectives are:
(1) to maintain a national and international reputation for technical expertise and commercial independence;
(2) to provide accurate, impartial and efficient testing services, as required by the wool industry and textile industry, at a minimum cost;

(3) to maximise nett income to the Australian woolgrowing industry, by encouraging the optimum application of objective measurement by woolgrowers, brokers, buyers and both local and overseas processors.
These objectives are completely consistent with the objectives of the Act, the expressed policies of the Corporation and the views of the wool industry sectors for whom services are provided.

Raw Wool Testing Activity
For the fourteenth consecutive year, the AWTA has exceeded the previous year's record total number of bales core-sampled for testing.
The new record achieved in 1979-80 was 4,030,458 bales, which represented an increase of 10.2 per cent over the previous year.
Within this overall growth trend, there were a number of significant and compensating changes in levels of activity. In particular:
Presale Certificate sampling increased by 12.3 per cent to new record 3,443,024 bales;
Post Sale Certificate sampling decreased by 16.6 per cent to 264,523 bales;
Conditioning Certificate sampling increased by 14.1 per cent to 266,897 bales;
Futures Certificate sampling decreased by 67.9 per cent to 677 bales only;
Guidance Report sampling decreased by 64.4 per cent to 4,794 bales; and
Sundry sampling, for a variety of special testing requirements, increased by 109.9 per cent to 50,543 bales.
As reported in previous years, the continuing growth of Presale Certificate testing activity has been the key factor causing those decreases in activity which have occurred.
Presale Certificate Testing

During 1979-80, Presale Certificate testing was by far the most significant activity conducted by the AWTA. Whilst woolgrowers are the major users of this service, it is also being used extensively by private treaty wool merchants, who re-offer their purchases to the wool buying trade on a sale-by-sample basis.

It is now recognised that substantial price differentials exist between tested and untested wools and that these more than offset the cost of testing small lots. Consequently, there has been an increase in the testing of 1, 2 and 3-bale lots, which is illustrated by the overall reduction in the average lot size of bales tested prior to sale, as the percentage of the clip tested has increased.

The rapid development of this service since the early 1970's has been due, in particular, to the growing recognition within the wool industry that significant financial benefits were available to all sectors of the wool handling and marketing chain, arising from the flexibility generated by introducing large-scale objective measurement into the primary selling system.
Testing for Wool Buyers
The continuing growth of Presale Certificate testing has diminished the level of testing for wool buyers, after sale.

Post Sale Certificate testing is now limited, almost entirely, to those bales sold traditionally by the woolgrower, since the buyer of a Presale Certificate tested lot automatically receives the relevant Certificate for use in his subsequent sales transaction.
Futures Certificate testing has reduced to levels which are practically insignificant, following the decision by the Sydney Exchange to accept Presale Certificates.

With most auction wools tested prior to sale, buyers now have a reduced demand for Guidance sampling. However, the Authority has noted an increased level of testing in this area, particularly with respect to samples drawn from non-auction wools and submitted by clients for testing.
Condition Testing of Scoured and Carbonised Wool

The testing of scoured and carbonised wools for regain/ moisture content and the issue of Conditioning Certificates was the principal activity conducted by the Authority from the time of its establishment in 1957 until 1963-64, when the sampling of greasy wool for wool buyers accounted for more bales.

During 1979-80, the total activity in this area was an all-time record, with 266,897 bales being sampled for certification. This surpassed the previous record total established in 1971-72 and placed Conditioning Certificate testing second only to Presale Certificate testing, in terms of bales sampled.
Textile Testing Activity

As reported in previous years, the AWTA Textile Testing Division has been active in endeavouring to encourage a broadly based clientele for the wide range of services available. Prior to 1977-78 its principal client, the Australian Wool Corporation, accounted for more than half of its total revenue.

Since that time, the number of industry testing clients has steadily increased and now includes local manufacturers, importers, retailers, architects, public purchasing agencies, hospitals, government departments, building companies and the general public. As a result, industry clients accounted for 61 per cent of total revenue during 1979-80.

Nevertheless, testing for the Corporation continues to be very important. It includes the check testing of imported wool packs, routine quality control testing associated with the maintenance of Woolmark and Woolblendmark standards and other testing associated with the Corporation's technical and promotion activities within the wool textile industry.

The continuing growth experienced throughout the year is considered to reflect an increasing awareness of the value of textile specification and quality assurance testing as consumer protection demands increase.
AWTA Technical Status

Throughout 1979-80, the AWTA's technical status continued to be ratified by independent external authorities, both nationally and internationally. On the basis of rigorous inspection of facilities and operating procedures and/or following successful participation in inter-laboratory testing trials, the Authority continued to be:
listed as a Public Conditioning House, by the International Wool Textile Organisation (I.W.T.O.);
recognised as a calibrated Member of the Airflow and Projection Microscope sections of the International Association of Wool Textile Laboratories (Interwoollabs);
registered for raw wool testing by the Australian Wool Measurement Standards Authority (A.W.M.S.A.), which is controlled by the Department of Primary Industry; and
registered for Heat and Temperature Measurement and for Physical and as Textiles, by the National Association of Testing Authorities (N.A.T.A.).

In addition, the new interlaboratory testing and inspection scheme, initiated by the Authority and now involving the eight major, independent laboratories throughout the world, was re-endorsed by the I.W.T.O. and has enabled Interwoollabs to withdraw from activities in this area.
Performance Monitoring

In common with other service organisations operating in the Australian wool industry, the Authority's raw wool testing activities are influenced by the fluctuations in wool receivals and the peaking nature of shearing patterns. To maintain its service commitments to its clients, to reduce the service time from sampling to issue of test results and to control operating costs, it is essential for the Authority to monitor its performance via computerised systems.

During the year, the average service times for all services were reduced and, regardless of sale cataloguing deadlines even at the peak work-load period, in the presale testing area not one single test out of some 362,000 exceeded the maximum service time limit of ten days.
Further significant improvements are expected in service, production and quality control, following the current upgrading of the Authority's computerised systems, which was commenced in June 1980.
Fees for Major Services
The sampling and testing fees charged by the AWTA for its major raw wool and textile testing services were not altered, as compared with the previous year. With regard to these major activities:
Presale Certificate services fees have remained unchanged since November 1975, when an average charge reduction of 8 per cent was introduced;
Post Sale Certificate service fees have remained unchanged since July 1975, when a minor charge increase averaging 0.7 per cent was applied;
charges for all significant textile testing services have remained unchanged since July 1977; and
Conditioning Certificate fees were last increased in July 1978, after being held constant for the previous three years.
Financial Results

In accordance with the Wool Industry Act 1972, the ultimate legal responsibility for funding the AWTA rests with the Corporation. However, the Corporation has adopted the pragmatic and commercially realistic policy of requiring the Authority to be accountable for its own viability and to manage its own affairs.

As a result, the Authority aims to operate as a stable, commercially self-supporting organisation by ensuring that its profitability is sufficient to meet the full costs of its activities and to also provide funds to cover its essential capital expenditure and working capital requirements.

A detailed management accounting system has been developed to monitor financial performance and to ensure that key managerial staff have timely and factual data to assist in their operation decision-making.

Members of the Authority receive financial reports monthly, including sales reports by major activity, expenditure reports by cost centre and managerial location, a profit and loss statement and a monthly balance sheet.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate, which represents the last parliamentary stage in the passage of a new national companies Act, ought to be a great parliamentary occasion. It is, after all, the culmination of 22 years of endeavour which began right back in 1959 to bring the company law framework into a single national, coherent shape, but we regret that the occasion is nothing of the kind. The Companies Bill-the huge document which is the centrepiece of the present package of Bills-is a profound disappointment. It represents a sad tale of reforming opportunities forgone. With only minor exceptions, it represents no more than the lowest common denominator of the existing State company laws.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, the whole scheme of which this Bill and other Bills in the package are a part, this exercise in so-called co-operative federalism, is itself a disappointment-necessarily, because of its very nature, a thing of shreds and patches. The Bills come to us after an unusually lengthy debate in the House of Representatives. There has been in that chamber a full second reading debate and, what is very unusual indeed, nearly four hours of Committee debate. During the Committee stage a number of substantial contributions were put on record by Opposition spokesmen, especially Mr John Brown, the honourable member for Parramatta and shadow Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, and Mr Ralph Jacobi, the honourable member for Hawker, who has long had a passionate and very knowledgeable interest in this area of the law.

Because of the length of that Committee stage debate, because of its complexity and effectiveness, the Opposition does not propose today to embark on a lengthy Committee stage debate in this chamber. To do so would be simply to repeat a good deal of material that has already been put on the record. However, I do propose to spend a little more time on my speech in the second reading debate than might otherwise have been the case, in our presently constrained procedural circumstances, to inform the Senate of the Opposition's attitude to this legislation, which after all is one of the most important legislative packages that could come before any parliament.

The Opposition has many problems with these Bills, but our main concerns operate at three different levels. In the first place, the legislation amounts to an abdication of Commonwealth responsibility in a field which it ought to be occupying in its own right. Secondly, it is our position, which later I will spell out in some detail, that a co-operative scheme of the kind that is in issue here is simply not a satisfactory substitute for overriding Commonwealth legislation. There are too many inherent weaknesses in this kind of so-called co-operative arrangement. Our third level of concern is in regard to the specific terms of the Companies Bill, which are quite profoundly disappointing from a law reform point of view.

I will now discuss each of these matters in turn. I begin with the question of the abdication of Commonwealth responsibility which clearly seems to be involved in the approach taken by the Government.
