TALK.START.PARA: —The point I was making before we broke for lunch was that the scheme of which the present Bills are a part represents an abdication of the responsibility the Commonwealth has to exercise national leadership by passing national laws in an area manifestly crying out for them. The Bills we are passing today and the Bills which have preceded them in the development of this co-operative national companies and securities law scheme are being passed by the Commonwealth Parliament, of course, but they do not, in themselves, have any national application. All the Bills which we have been passing and those which are before us today apply only to the Australian Capital Territory and they are passed in reliance only upon the Commonwealth's constitutional power to legislate with respect to its own territories under section 122 of the Constitution. The application to the rest of the country, which is the intention, depends on all individual States passing their own legislation to pick up and apply the model Australian Capital Territory Bill in their respective jurisdictions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition believes that the Commonwealth should pass its own legislation in this area. The points in issue were developed at considerable length by me in previous speeches on 19 November 1979 and 26 February 1981. I do not stop to repeat them in detail here. I simply make the following points: In the first place there is an unquestioned need for effective and uniform national legislation and the document that most forcefully established that need was the report of the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange-the Rae Committee-which was tabled in this Parliament in 1974. Secondly, the States have amply demonstrated that they cannot be relied upon to maintain uniformity of approach in complex regulatory areas like this if they are left to their own co-operative devices. The whole history of the uniform companies Acts in 1961 is ample testimony to that. The third point I make is that the Commonwealth has sufficient constitutional power, in my belief, to go it alone.

The last point is the one that is most often contested, but it is one in which I for one, for what it is worth, have always had a good deal of professional confidence. I believe that the High Court, when it is put to the test, will continue to give expansive readings to the corporation power of section 51 placitum (xx.) which initially came of age in the 1970 concrete pipes case. I am well aware that the consitutional reference in section 51 placitum (xx.) is not to corporations generally but rather to particular classes thereof, namely, trading, financial and foreign corporations. I am equally well aware that judicial dicta in the early cases sought to make a distinction between those categories of corporations and others including mining and manufacturing corporations. I still contend that the trend of interpretation in the few cases to touch this issue since 1970 gives one considerable ground for optimism. I refer especially to the Western Australian football league case decided by the High Court in 1979 and also to two recent Federal Court decisions in which Mr Justice Brennan, now Sir Gerard Brennan of the High Court, participated. I refer to the Ku-ring-gai Co-operative Building Societies case and the State Superannuation Board of Victoria case in 1980. Again, I am well aware that there was an argument in the early years of this century, based on an extraordinarily narrow grammatical reading of the relevant text, that Commonwealth law can constitutionally bite upon companies only once they have been formed and that Commonwealth law cannot constitutionally extend to company law of the familiar kind governing the creation of companies in the first place. Again, without going into the relevant complex legal argument I believe there is good reason to suppose that the early interpretation is much too narrow.

I also make the point on this constitutional question that there is a strong case for an exercise of venturesome approaches by the Commonwealth when this kind of need for strong national legislation is in issue. This point has been acknowledged from time to time by both sides of the political spectrum. It certainly has not been acknowledged by the present Attorney-General (Senator Durack), although I must confess that with the amendment he is proposing today to the Acts Interpretation Act there seems to be a whole new spirit of adventure abroad in the breast of the Attorney. I am thinking more particularly and immediately of some comments made by a distinguished former Attorney-General on the Government side. I refer to Mr Ellicott who, when speaking in 1974 in support of the Whitlam Government's National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Bill, made the following remarks:
. . . uncertainty as to the extent of constitutional power should never of itself be a reason for opposing an otherwise worthwhile legislative exercise of power;
nor should it prevent a government, properly advised, treading where angels of constitutional probity have formerly feared to tread. The High Court, as we know, will readily give us the answer-

I repeat that Mr Ellicott made those remarks in 1974. I certainly make the point that this Government has never demonstrated any great constitutional timidity when it has wanted to enact draconian legislation of a union-bashing kind. I refer in particular to the 1979 amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act which involved a degree of constitutional adventure under the heading of section 51 placitum (xxxv.) of the Constitution. I also refer to the exercise in the introduction of section 45D of the Trade Practices Act which involved a reliance on section 51 placitum (xx.) which is in issue here. It went rather beyond anything that had previously been given judicial seals of approval.

When it suits the Government's purpose there has never been any question of timidity or caution on the constititional front. I suggest that there is ample foundation in the law as it stands and as it might be expected to develop over the next few years on which the Commonwealth could proceed should it be minded to do so to enact its own national companies and securities law. It was, of course, the attitude of the Australian Labor Party when in office to support such national legislation generated unilaterally by the Commonwealth, and it remains our attitude that that is the only way we can expect ever to get enacted not only national or uniform companies and securities legislation but the kind of strong reforming legislation that is so obviously necessary in this particular area.

The point I have been making about the abdication of the constitutional responsibility of the Commonwealth is much reinforced when one considers the second level of the Oppositions concern to which I now turn, and that is the proposition that the co-operative scheme is simply not a satisfactory alternative to the unilateral exercise of the Commonwealth's own constitutional power. There are two basic reasons for that. The first of them is the accountability problem, and that is a real problem, an endemic problem, in any exercise in co-operative federalism. The criticism about the lack of accountability necessarily involved in co-operative schemes has never been satisfactorily answered by the proponents of co-operative schemes.

I suggest that the great Australian sport in this Federation is not cricket, league football or even Australian rules; it is the sport of passing the buck. That is the inextricable essence of federal systems and it is the inextricable concomitant of co-operative schemes of the kind that are in issue here. A scheme of this kind where no single government is obliged to accept or does accept responsibility for anything the governing organs like the National Companies and Securities Commission do and where no single government does accept or is obliged to accept responsibility for the inadequacy of the law, if the inadequacy is demonstrated in any case, is a classic situation of a vacuum which just will not be filled by anyone. That is the basic problem inherent in schemes of this kind. It is even more obviously a problem in this area because the very point in issue is made in the text of the Maroochydore agreement which itself underlies the whole co-operative scheme. I refer, as I have in the past, to paragraph 38 (1) of that agreement which states in so many words that the policy direction and general control over the administration-that is, over the new body on companies and securities law-shall be exercised to the exclusion of ministerial direction and control by the responsible Minister of the Commonwealth or of the State. That is how extreme the situation is in terms of abdication of responsibility and of accountability in any graspable form. That will be a continuing problem as long as this co-operative scheme is sustained.

The other problem inherently bound up with this kind of arrangement, whether it deals with companies and securities law or with anything else, is the problem of inertia and lowest common denominator solutions to complex problems. The inevitable result of this kind of co-operative scheme is lowest common denominator compromises. Legislation emerges which is no stronger than the weakest government in the participating scheme is willing to accept. Legislation emerges which is no more progressive than the most reactionary government in the collection of those participating is prepared to accept. That will become clear in a moment when we turn to look at the nature of the actual reforms, if they can be so described, which are accomplished in this legislation. However, the point is usually made about this co-operative scheme that the sort of comment is only true, if it is true at all, in respect of the initial legislation where unanimity is required and that that situation will change and can be expected to change in the future when the only requirement is that of a majority decision.

But I put to you, Mr President, very strenuously the point that was very cogently put, as always, by my learned friend and colleague Mr Jacobi, the honourable member for Hawker, when he spoke on this matter in the lower House. The point is that it remains the case that the States participate and will continue to participate in this co-operative scheme on a voluntary basis-they are not obliged, legally or in any other way, to remain in it-and that for any State to threaten to leave the scheme will wreck its whole underlying concept. When we put those two propositions together, exactly the same dynamic will apply in the future, sustained this time not by the requirement of formal legal unanimity but by the familiar federal politics of blackmail.

I turn now to the third level of concern which the Opposition wishes to express about these Bills and, in particular, about the monster Companies Bill now in front of us; that is, the inadequacies of the present legislation, looked at in its own terms. It is manifestly the case that the present Companies Bill is not a reforming piece of legislation. Indeed, so much was admitted, one might almost say with refreshing candour, by the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Moore, writing in the Australian Financial Review on 26 May when he said that in so many words. Such timid measures as were introduced in the first-exposure draft Bill early last year have subsequently and inexorably been whittled away, first of all in the August 1980 draft and now again in the completed 1981 Bill before us.

The only changes of any significance at all in the body of Australian company law that are accomplished by this Bill are, firstly, the one place of registration concept, which is important because it enables companies to avoid the multiple filing which has plagued the practical administration of company business for so many decades in this country; secondly, the substantial systematisation of penalties which has been long overdue in this legislative area; thirdly, some reforms, not very earth shattering but reforms nonetheless, in the law on pre-incorporation contracts; fourthly, some undoubted improvements in the law with respect to companies dealing with their own shares; and, finally, some provisions of a significant kind concerning the registration of priority of charges. But that is not much for a Bill of 532 pages and with 581 clauses, excluding the Schedules, because an enormous number of things that might have been done have not in fact been done.

A good selection, by no means intended to be exhaustive, of the sorts of things which might have been done but which were not done is set out in the Opposition's amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Companies Bill. I propose to spend just a few minutes drawing the Senate's attention to the particular matters with which we are concerned. They are matters which we regard as crucially necessary if any serious exercise in the fundamental reform of company law is to be involved in legislation of this kind. The first matter we refer to as requiring immediate legislative attention-it is dealt with in paragraph (5) (A) of the amendment-is the abolition of the category of 'exempt proprietary company' and the privileges associated with that category. Exempt proprietary companies are defined in clause 5 of the Bill as basically those companies in which there is no direct or indirect share ownership by a public company. A number of advantages flow from being an exempt proprietary company. They are set out variously in clauses 230, 263, 264, 277, 278, 279, 282 and 417 of the Bill. In essence they involve the advantage that an exempt proprietary company need not appoint an auditor and need not file a copy of its accounts along with its annual returns as long as it operates as an unlimited company or has the accounts audited. There are advantages, and an unhappy situation is associated with them because they mean that those potential creditors who may wish to trade with the company in question, if it is exempt, have no automatic right of access to the kind of information that would enable them to judge the company's financial viability. The Opposition takes the point very strenuously, and made it very strenuously in the other place, that the price of limited liability, if limited liability is to be retained in our company law-I will come to that in a moment-must be financial disclosure. Paragraph (5) (B) of the amendment refers to the need to reform the law by:

The provision of statutory directions and powers to the national companies and Securities Commission and the courts to look behind the corporate entity in appropriate circumstances, to ascertain those who control it or hold shares in it, and, having regard to the purpose of the creation of the corporate entity and the manner of its control, to affix personal liability and adjudicate personal rights where it is just and equitable to do so.

That paragraph deals essentially with the subject matter of lifting the corporate veil. The context in which the suggestion is advanced is, of course, the misuse of corporate personality in the shape of what are generically known as two dollar companies. The offices of the Corporate Affairs Commissions, as we well know, are littered with a number of two dollar companies that have crashed to the detriment of employees, creditors and shareholders; and something ought to have been done about that.

Paragraph (5) (C) of the amendment refers to the desirability of extending the powers of inspection of the National Companies and Securities Commission to ensure the fullest reasonable access of the Commission to books, a matter dealt with in clause 12 but in our view dealt with insufficiently. Again the context in which that is made is set out more fully in the Committee stage debate in the other place. Paragraph (5) (D) of the amendment refers to the desirability of there being the amendment of any provision which enables questionable practices to be hidden by means of legal professional privilege'. The reference there is to clause 16 of the Bill. The particular point being made there is the notion, not altogether unknown regrettably in my profession, that questionable transactions can from time to time be channelled through unethical lawyers, securing in the process the protection of legal privilege. If the basic and correct principles governing privilege are to be maintained, obviously the draft of any such approach to this problem needs to be tackled very carefully. Nonetheless, it is a problem to which we draw attention. Paragraph (E) of the amendment refers to a suggested:
. . . requirement for all companies to raise and maintain a prescribed minimum nominal and paid up capital,

This is a crucially important amendment and, again, it is one of those right at the heart and soul of the Opposition's concern about this Bill. The situation is, under present company law as it applies in Australia, that one can have paid up capital for a private company of as little as 2c and, in the case of a public company, of as little as 5c. That can be the total paid up capital which is accessible to creditors in the event of a company collapse. It is a bizarre situation and not one that is repeated elsewhere. It follows in Australia from the absence of any explicit legislative minimum amount of capital that must be subscribed. The lowest denomination tender of 1c can, in fact, be the amount of a subscription. The 2c and 5c figures follow simply from the fact that the minimum number of shareholders for a private company is two and for a public company five.

As I have said it is a bizarre situation, an unhappy one and one that the Minister responded to by saying that the proposals had some weight and he would give them attention. I suggest that he ought to give them urgent attention. He also ought to give some attention to what I think is the fascinating suggestion-it has been advanced in other quarters but it was advanced on this occasion by Mr John Brown, the Labor spokesman-that one way of coping with the problem of insufficient subscriptions of capital would be to require the amount of the subscribed capital to be identified in the actual title of the company. Thus it would be, as Mr Brown suggested, Bloggs $100 Pty Ltd. Other examples that spring more readily to mind are perhaps Messner Accounting Enterprises $10 Pty Ltd or Lynch Property Developments 2c Pty Ltd.

—I will give Senator Rae a Senator Carrick stare and count to ten.
—Irresistible.
—I thought we were friends on this subject area at least.
—That is why I thought I could say it.
—Yes, I appreciate that. Paragraph (F) of the Opposition's amendment draws attention to yet another requirement of any fundamental company reform. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Rationalisation of the cumbersome provisions in respect of company names on the basis of single nationwide registration.

It is one of the more peculiar characteristics of this massive Bill that a very large part of its weight is accommodated with what is, on the face of it, a fairly trivial regulatory area; that is, the registration of names. I refer to clauses 40 to 64 where, for reasons which still remain unclear to me anyway, the one stop registration principle which applies elsewhere in the Bill was simply not adopted. Although it is more in the nature of an irritant and an absence of streamlining rather than anything of more substantial importance than that, it is the kind of thing one would have thought might have been capable of resolution when this Bill was being put together. Paragraph (G) refers to:
a requirement that dividends be paid only from the genuine profits of a company,

That is a reference to what is presently inadequately dealt with, in our view, by clause 565 of the Bill. Indeed, it was a point that was acknowledged in the House of Representatives by the Minister in his reply to the Opposition's suggestions on that point at the Committee stage. Paragraph (H) of the amendment refers to the necessity for a:
Full review of the provisions relating to fund raising and prospectuses to ensure maximum disclosure and to require independent valuation of assets exchanged for issued shares,

Indeed, this is a subject on which the Senate has had the benefit of my views expressed, again at some length, in the context of the Negri River affair on 3 March this year. I think the point is obvious enough not to bear detailed repetition at this point. The only specific matter that needs to be adverted to yet again is that the Eggleston committee's recommendations were quite explicit on this point and, in our view, ought to have been adopted. Indeed, Mr Moore, the Minister, again quite overtly acknowledged that this was a major area of the Bill clearly needing some more detailed attention. I just wish to goodness that he and the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities would give it that attention. Paragraph (I) of the amendment refers to a necessity for:
reform of the provisions relating to companies financing dealings in their own shares, including the removal of the exemption given to financial assistance to salaried directors,

The point which speaks for itself, I suppose, as a general principle-Mr Moore made, I think, a valid point in reply-is that there was a concern in this area to endeavour to continue to encourage shareholding by employees, a proposition with which the Opposition and I do not dissent. Equally clearly, there would appear to be a case for more effectively regulating, limiting and determining in the public interest how the financing of directors' shareholdings or acquisitions might be accomplished. That matter is dealt with in clauses 129 to 130 of the present Bill, in our view not very effectively. Paragraph (J) of the amendment consists of a suggestion that there be:
provision for a higher required standard of competence, care and diligence for directors and officers of companies,

Again, this is a reference to an existing clause of the Bill-in this case clause 229-which, in our view, is manifestly inadequate and which in this case represents in its final version, a substantial backsliding from the original terms of the draft exposure Bill prepared early last year. It is not an area in which the Opposition's well and cogently argued points-as usual-were responded to with any degree of explicitness by the Minister, but clearly again in our view it is an area where reform is needed. There are only three or four more paragraphs in the amendment but there are many problems with this Bill. Paragraph (K) refers to:
a requirement that more frequent accounts be lodged by companies listed on the Stock Exchanges,
That is a reference to the inadequacies in this respect in clauses 263 to 276. Again, I think that is a point which speaks for itself. Paragraph (L)--

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean when you say 'more frequent accounts'? Is that envisaged as an amendment to the Companies Act or to the listing requirements? In other words, are quarterly statements inadequate or--

—That is the view. I am not quite sure off hand, without having done some more detailed work on this provision, what the formal requirements are at the moment. I think that in relation to the Companies Act they are only annual and it is a matter of whether there ought to be access through the companies office to scrutiny procedures for more regular accounts than that, at least in the case of quoted companies. There is no concern on our part that any such requirement should extend to unlisted un-companies because, manifestly, the sheer amount of administration and paper work involved in that would be far and away greater than the return that could be conceivably justified by it. As I understand the position articulated by our shadow minister in the other place, to which I simply advert rather superficially, it is our intention that there be an explicit provision that for quoted companies, perhaps those with a turnover of above some specified minimum level, in order to focus in on those areas where deficiences have been felt in the past, there should be some requirement for more frequent accounts, perhaps not necessarily the whole box and dice accounts; maybe just particular indicators being the subject of an additional requirement of this kind. I would be happy to take that up with the honourable senator at an appropriate occasion later. Paragraph (L) of the Opposition's amendment deals with the vexed and controversial question of companies acting as trustees of trading trusts. The paragraph in question reads:

SPEECH.PARA: In order to protect creditors and to assist the prevention of tax avoidance, the imposition of stringent disclosure requirements upon companies acting as trustees of trading trusts, in relation to their capacity as trustees and the accounts of the relevant trusts, and the imposition of heavy penalties for non-compliance,

There seems to be no doubt but that the trading trust can be used as a vehicle for significant tax avoidance in this area. The only significant area for argument seems to be whether one deals with this phenomenon in companies legislation of this kind or whether, rather, one regards it more aptly as the subject matter of specific taxation legislation. The Opposition's view, in essence, is that it is the kind of commercial problem that needs attention at both levels. We cannot for the life of us see why the former Part 6AA in the exposure draft was abandoned in the subsequent development of this Bill. This is not a matter to which the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs gave the Opposition the courtesy of a reply at all in the Committee stage in the other place. If the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), without asking too much of him on this occasion, could give us some specific indication as to precisely what the Government's policy and intentions are in this area I think that would be a useful and constructive contribution to the general knowledge of honourable senators.
Paragraph (M) of the amendment refers to:
Full disclosure to the public of the beneficial ownership of all shares in companies.

Again, this is something that hardly needs elaborate or rhetorical debating passion on my part because the self-evidence of the proposition one would think is so great. I simply repeat the plea that was very passionately and effectively made on this subject by my learned friend and colleague, Mr Jacobi, in the other place when he said, in a way that is absolutely unanswerable, that the provisions are defective; they are ineffective and the only way to protect Australian equity and resources that this country wants to develop is to force disclosure of nominee shareholding. I agree with him. Again I would be interested to know what reasons there might be for the unwillingness apparently of the Government to proceed in this area. Maybe that is a matter on which the Government feels a little more sensitive than some of the other areas with which I have dealt.
Paragraph (N) of the Opposition's amendment refers to the need for :
Published accounts to include full details of each director's and officer's remuneration and right of inspection for employees and shareholders of director's service contracts.

In effect, those matters are covered by clauses 263, 269 and 270 of the present Bill. They are matters again in respect of which there was not much in the way of a positive response from the Minister in the other place but are matters that we would hope have some self-evident policy advantages and would be taken on board by the Ministerial Council.
Paragraph (O), the second last paragraph of the Opposition's amendment, deals with the subject matter of clause 320 and refers to:

Adequate remedies for oppressive conduct, including extension of the concept of oppression to single and anticipated acts unfairly prejudicial to a shareholder, and provision of further means such as a 'shareholders' tribunal' to protect the interests of minority shareholders.

Again, one would have thought this matter was of enormous and obvious importance but we received no response from the Minister, notwithstanding that his own officers have indicated, in the very extensive briefings we have had and for which we are grateful in the build-up of this legislation, they were matters which were very much on the list of priorities for reform. The last paragraph of the Opposition's amendment details the inadequacies of the reformist qualities of this legislation. Paragraph (P) calls for:
Complete reform of the winding up provisions, including greater protection for unsecured creditors, following a reference on insolvency to the Australian Law Reform Commission.

Part XI of the Bill-it is huge Part of the Bill which has some 117 clauses-which deals with this matter is, in our view and indeed, it appears, in the view of the Minister, much in need of attention. The only difficulty is who is going to give it that attention and when. The Law Reform Commission indicated in the course of its earlier recovery of debts reference that it was able, willing and anxious indeed to take on the question of company insolvencies as well as the larger issues still remaining unresolved in the bankruptcy area. The Government so far has not responded affirmatively to that request. One wonders why. Can it be a resource problem or can it be some dark policy secrets that the Government is nurturing to its breast? If the Minister for Veterans' Affairs would care to tell us we would like to know because this is manifestly an area demanding attention. That list, lengthy as it undoubtedly is and occupying as it did some four hours of debate in the Committee stage in the other place-a debate which perhaps honourable senators will be delighted to know will not be repeated here-nonetheless still by no means exhaustively catalogues the deficiencies of this legislation.

There is one other matter to which I specifically draw attention although I will not debate it, and that is the particular question of an accounting standards review board. That is the subject of clause 4 of our amendment, the expedition of which seems undoubtedly to be a crucial necessity given the extraordinary chaos-I do not think that is too high a word-which prevails in the evolution and application of relevant inflation-proof accountancy standards in this country at the moment. So much for particular matters.

In general terms, the point that the Opposition makes-I guess we have given enough illustrations to make the point-is that this is a major reform opportunity which has been forgone. For that reason, this Government and the weaker and more reactionary elements which constitute the majority of the Ministerial Council, deserve a great deal of the blame. There is one aspect of this though for which the Minister deserves a degree of blame. It can be described only as something very close to, if not actually constituting, a misrepresentation. I refer to a letter which was written by the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs to the Australian Financial Review and which appeared in the edition of 27 May, in which he claimed extraordinarily that it was not within the jurisdiction of the Ministerial Council for reforming legislation to be produced. He said:
. . . the Companies Bill should be seen essentially as the foundation for future, comprehensive and on-going reforms.
So far so good, but then he went on:
This view is consistent with the Formal Agreement-
He is referring to the Maroochydore agreement of 1978-
Which requires the initial legislation to be substantially based on the existing ICAC Companies and Securities Industries Acts.

He said that the Maroochydore agreement requires the initial legislation to be thus based. Clause 8 (2) (b) of the Maroochydore formal agreement provides that the initial legislation to form the basis of the scheme shall:
. . . except to the extent that amendments are agreed upon by the Ministerial Council . . . be substantially in conformity with . . . legislation.

It refers to the existing legislation. In other words, the Ministerial Council unquestionably had the power to introduce reforms without restrictions, subject only, of course, to the limiting requirement of unanimous agreement. I make that point because there is a disposition, there has been a disposition and no doubt it will be repeated by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in his reply unless he is a little more honest than his counterpart in the other place to claim that it was not in the inherent nature of his exercise to produce a reforming Bill. Clearly it is not accurate to make that claim. The power was there. It is simply a matter, for a variety of other reasons, resulting in the opportunity being forgone.

The other point I want to make is a general point of some importance. I refer to the question of the formation and establishment of the companies and securities law review committee. The formal Maroochydore agreement between the Commonwealth and the States which established the companies and securities co-operative scheme did provide in clause 21(2) as follows:
To assist the Ministerial Council in discharging its functions-
I interpolate here to indicate that it is to consider and to keep under review the formulation and operation of the companies and securities legislation: Clause 21(2) further states:
. . . there shall be a Companies and Securities Law Review Committee.

One of the functions that that review committee was given in terms of the formal agreement was to carry out research into and advise on law reform in relation to the companies and securities legislation. This committee has not yet been established-that was admitted by the Minister in the letter to which I referred in the Australian Financial Review yesterday-nor am I aware that there have been any moves to establish it. It is 2 1/2 years since the agreement was signed. Such a committee would have to be staffed with appropriate academics, company lawyers and departmental experts from the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs. Such a committee could have fulfilled its intended function by advising the Ministerial Council on the Companies Bill. Never, I suggest, was an expert committee more badly needed nor its absence more evidence than in relation to this Bill.

The reality of the matter is that in the early part of this century Victoria led the way in company law reform in the common law world. Victorian law recognised the private company 11 years before similar recognition was accorded in Britain. The Victorian Companies Act in 1938 was in many ways an improvement on the British consolidating Act of 1929. Since that initial extravaganza by the Victorians, which has not been repeated since in that State, all the running has been made not in this country but in Britain, the highlights being the Green committee report in 1926, the Cohen committee report in 1945 and, of course, the Jenkins committee report in 1962.

The only significant initiative that has hitherto been taken in Australia as a major reforming exercise was the establishment of the Eggleston committee, appointed by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in 1967, to inquire into protection mechanisms for the investing public. That Committee's report, admirable as it was, was the product of insufficient time at the time, and has certainly been the product of insufficient governmental attention since. I simply make the point, without going into as much detail as I could about the earlier attempts at reform in this area, that this much vaunted, much heralded Companies Bill was the golden opportunity for wide consultation for a detailed report by a committee giving reasons, unlike the Ministerial Council in this case, for what it does and does not recommend and for wholesale reform in all the areas to which the Opposition's amendment refers. I conclude my remarks by making the point, although it is a fairly detailed one--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha, ha.

—In response to Senator Rae's guffaw, I say that it is the last subject to which I wish to refer. Lest he be minded to continue guffawing, I simply make the point that I am making this speech at the expense of four hours, or potentially more, of Committee debate. He should count his blessings. This was also the occasion for reform of an even more fundamental and far-reaching kind. I wish to leave the Senate and indeed, the Minister and the Ministerial Council, with an idea. I believe that rather than having just the kind of inevitably and essentially patchwork reforms which I have been listing and which are the subject of the Opposition's amendment there is a strong case for considering the whole question of limited liability. Let me remind the Senate that limited liability means that if on the winding up of an insolvent company the assets of the company are insufficient to pay its debts in full the liability of a shareholder to meet those debts is limited to the amount which is not paid up on his or her shares. In the absence of fraud, or if reasonable grounds can be shown for believing that the company could pay its debts, the directors of the company have no liability for those debts.

SPEECH.PARA: The historical justification for this situation has always been that limited liability provides a safeguard for risk-taking and that therefore it is an incentive to investment. In a large company it ensures that the non-participating contributors of capital are not liable for the misjudgments or failures of the directors and managers. However, the evil of limited liability is that it leaves unprotected and unpaid creditors who have entered into bona fide transactions with companies while providing a shield for those who stand to benefit if the company succeeds. In other words, it shifts the risks of failure. It shifts those risks away from the proprietors of a company, who will have all the benefits of success, to creditors who then bear the costs of failure but who get no more than their due if things go well. It must be seriously considered whether this is a proper allocation of mercantile risks.

The Opposition's concern, although we have not articulated it in quite such explicit terms, about the consequences of limited liability is of course reflected in a number of the specific items in the amendment. In the first place the price of limited liability, as I have said, has to be full disclosure of accounts so that creditors can take steps to inform themselves of the financial position of the company with which they deal. Thus paragraph 5(A) of our amendment calls for the abolition of the category of exempt proprietary companies and its privilege of non-disclosure. A similar theme is evident in paragraph 5(L) of the amendment, which calls for stringent disclosure requirements for companies acting as trustees of trading trusts. Again, paragraph 5(B) of the amendment calls for company law to incorporate powers in and directions to the National Companies and Securities Commission and the courts to pierce the corporate veil in appropriate circumstances-that is, to remove the shield of limited liability and to affix personal liability on directors and shareholders where it is just and equitable to do so.

Paragraph 5(E), to which I have referred, is also relevant to this theme. It calls for a prescribed minimum, nominal and paid-up capital. This too should be a prerequisite before the privilege of limited liability is conferred. It will ensure some minimum financial substance and thus reduce the risk of insolvency. It will act as a deterrent to frivolous incorporations. It will certainly end the abuse of the $2 shelf company. As we know, it is this kind of company which is so widely used, in tax avoidance schemes, in particular as the trustee of trading trusts.

A couple more paragraphs are relevant to this theme. Paragraph 5 (H) calls for the independent valuation of assets exchanged for share issues. This may not stop the most determined of fraudulent promoters but it would greatly limit the number of formations and, for that matter, failures, of companies by reckless or inexperienced proprietors who are short of real working capital. Finally, paragraph 5 (J) calls for a higher standard of competence, care and diligence for directors and officers of companies. This provision, too, is intended to safeguard those who deal with companies in good faith and, of course, to pre-empt unnecessary risk-taking or incompetence before it does any damage.

I believe that there is a case for going beyond these kinds of measures which nonetheless assume the universal continuance of the limited liability principle and to raise for serious debate the question as to whether limited liability should be so automatically accepted and applicable for all classes of companies. At present, all companies have the privilege of limited liability. This means that all companies, large and small, public and private, must comply with the mountainous regulatory provisions of this Bill, all 532 pages of them.

For small traders and private companies, this Companies Bill, like the Companies Act which it is to succeed, is undoubtedly a procedural wilderness and a legal minefield. I suggest that small companies, as defined by the number of owners, their capital and their turnover, or some combination of those criteria, should be given the alternative of unlimited liability with no obligation to disclose and a simpler code of conduct. This, of course, is a matter of fundamental and, indeed, almost religious significance in company law. Obviously, it cannot begin to be fully canvassed here, not least because I have trespassed so much on the Senate's time, but I assert that the advent of unlimited liability, whilst having obvious advantages to creditors, would not discourage soundly based businesses. The emphasis, of course, is on that qualification. Any discouragement to reckless trading or highly speculative incorporations could only be welcomed in my view. At the same time the correlative privilege of non-disclosure and a simpler code of conduct to adhere to would take appropriate notice of the fact that much company regulation is unnecessary for small companies where there is a substantial identity between the managers and the shareholders of the company in question. I therefore propose that consideration should be given to having ultimately separate legislation, perhaps even a small businesses Act-that ought to be dear to the heart of Senator Messner-to give effect to the kind of differential needs and obligations of small and large companies. I suggest that that might be a viable scheme.

The above catalogue of complaints and suggestions, as I have said, by no means exhausts the things that can be said about this Bill but it gives a clear indication above all else of how weak, timid and unadventurous a document it is. It is perhaps also worth making the point-it is a point I have made whenever speaking about such schemes-that there is an air of awful unreality in any event about pursuing this debate much further than I have sought to do today. As we all know, the reality is that no particular amendment that we might propose is likely to be accepted. That is not unusual in this chamber but in this case no amendment to the legislation now before us is likely even to be considered-taken away overnight and contemplated by the Government. That follows because of the nature of the package arrangements which are involved in this co-operative Federal exercise.

The Bill has been approved by the Ministerial Council. It comes before us on a take it or leave it basis. There is nothing that we can do to improve it. All we can do is to make suggestions of the kind that I and the Opposition have made-they have been made at much greater length in the other place-which may or may not be taken seriously. So much for parliamentary sovereignty! That is another reason why I believe the only satisfactory long term solution to the problem of getting an effective system of not only uniform but also strong and reformist national company law is for the Commonwealth to take the bit between its teeth and enact the necessary legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans in both an interesting and constructive contribution to the debate, notwithstanding the fact that I laughed at his suggestion that he was concluding some quarter of an hour ago, or whatever it was, described the Companies Bill 1981 as the much vaunted, much heralded Companies Bill. I have never thought that it had achieved that sort of acclaim. Rather I thought that the attitude adopted by the Parliament, the public and the media is as the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) described it in his letter to the Australian Financial Review-the start of a reform process, the first stage in developing what may become a modern, workable and appropriate package of companies legislation in Australia. I think that point needs to be made as a brief response to Senator Evans's speech. He said it was the vehicle but it was not used. Therefore I will give a very brief resume of the background on how this legislation came about.

SPEECH.PARA: There was concern in Australia that the whole area of the company law, securities industry law, the rules and administration of stock exchanges, company registries corporate affairs commissions-or whatever they may be-was demonstrated to be inadequate. This led to the suggestion, through a Senate committee, and certainly a general public acceptance that reform and a new approach was necessary. That led to the introduction of a Bill for Commonwealth legislation which had some draconian aspects to it as well as some desirable reforming aspects. However, it caused this chamber some concern and the Senate referred that Bill to a committee which considered it during1975. It had not reported on it when the events of 11 November 1975 led to a double dissolution and change of Government. On the change of Government it was decided quite legitimately, although I believe wrongly that the approach more appropriate than using what I believe to be the undoubted Commonwealth power to legislate was that of co-operative federalism.

In 1976 the Commonwealth Government forwent the opportunity which had been created of having a single Commonwealth companies Act enacted by a parliament and that parliament being solely responsible for it. To me that would have been consistent with both the single power of the Commonwealth Constitution in relation to companies and also with the package of powers created. I do not propose to dwell upon the package of powers that would have been available. Suffice it to say that such a package of powers has supported the United States of America Securities and Exchange Commission since its introduction in 1933. I do not believe-my view was supported in some fairly weighted legal opinions which were received by the Senate committee-that that would have been possible in Australia. But the Government of the day legitimately chose to adopt, consistent with its party's philosophy as it perceived it, the co-operative federalism approach. Inevitably that involved negotiation, compromise and the achievement of a start point from which one may be able to look at reform. I do not accept the criticism that this was a real opportunity for reform.

The Maroochydore agreement, which was eventually reached between the relevant Ministers of each State and the Commonwealth, was for the creation of a national companies and securities commission and the creation, by agreement, of a package of legislation which was to be enacted by the Commonwealth Government but which would be at its commencement as close as possible to the existing legislation common to the States. So it was a matter of hastening slowly. That is what was agreed to at Maroochydore in December 1978. I believe one of the unfortunate aspects of the development of this legislative package with which we are now dealing is that there have been too many attempts to try to improve the existing provisions, which has tended to hold up the introduction of this legislation. It would have been far better to have taken as a package what existed in the States, pass it and then say: 'Now we have got the basis of a national companies and securities commission. We have the basic legislation which enables the system to work. Now let us look at using the national companies and securities commission apparatus and take the opportunity to implement reform.' Whilst I find almost overwhelming the temptation to engage in a full debate on all the issues that have been raised by the amendment which Senator Evans moved and all of the other interesting aspects which are contained in the Bills, I resist it.

Therefore, I will deal briefly with some of the matters that Senator Evans raised because I believe the matter is at the next phase-the stage at which this Parliament will need to debate in far more detail some of the issues which need to be faced in Australia. There are a very large number of issues involved. I believe from a situation where we started to develop the possibility of Australia leading the world in the formulation of an appropriate companies and securities legislative design, we have fallen behind at the alter of co-operative federalism, because it has taken so long-it is nearly five years since a serious start was made-to get a co-operative approach to the creation of a national commission and the development of a legislative package. That approach did not start until some time after the new government came into power in 1976. That is why I said it is nearly five years since that took place. Had it been possible to get a little more co-operation from some of the State governments, I believe the whole thing could have been achieved more expeditiously. I point out that this is not a matter of saying that one party or one side of politics was right or wrong in relation to the matter. Those representatives on the Ministerial Council represented the major political parties of Australia in the various State governments and the Commonwealth Government. There were differences. Those differences had to be determined on the lowest common denominator basis because the Maroochydore agreement involved unanimity in relation to everything that was to be the original package. That is, unanimity in relation to the legislation for the creation of the National Companies and Securities Commission, the companies and securities industry legislation and other various pieces of legislation.

When one looks at the disparate interests of six States and the Commonwealth and imagines the possibility of enjoying daring reform with unanimity one is looking at a very long term process at best. I return to the point I made earlier. Far from agreeing with Senator Evans that this was the vehicle for reform, I think it was a vehicle destined to be the lowest common denominator in its initial stage. Had it been approached from the point of view of trying not to worry about some of the more important issues related to variations of the existing law, we may have had this legislation a lot earlier than we have. I do not say that critically of anybody but rather as an appraisal, looking back perhaps with a degree of hindsight. It is unfortunate that all of this legislation was not in force a little earlier.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not wish to re-cover in detail the ground that has been covered in previous speeches which I have made in relation to the prior legislation which has arisen from the Maroochydore agreement. I simply say that I endorse and wish to affirm what I said on those prior occasions in relation to the approach which has been adopted. I see this as step one. The legislation will be on a national basis. That is a major step forward. It may not be the most adequate, most interesting or most reforming legislation, but it is at least legislation on a national basis. I trust that from now on it will involve the agreement of only a majority of the members of the Ministerial Council to reform the legislation. There will be an opportunity for the National Companies and Securities Commission, through what I see as the adaptation to Australian circumstances of the American SEC special study role, to develop some public awareness, debate and consensus in relation to what sort of companies and securities law will be most appropriate to serve the needs of Australia for the ensuing two or three decades. It will also be able to start to get some agreement so that we will not have the lowest common denominator principle applying; rather we will have an exhausting of the debate and then an understanding by clear definition, by the recommendations of the National Companies and Securities Commisison, of what is likely best to serve Australia's needs.

We will then have the opportunity for the introduction of new legislation and we will have one parliament responsible for dealing with it. I hope that this Parliament then will start to take an interest, which it is not taking at the moment, in the detail of the legislation, and that when people ask 'If I apply some of my very precious time to considering these issues, can I expect to see some change take place?' the answer will be yes, they can. It will be worth while. But at the moment it is understandable that most people have adopted the attitude that as this legislation required unanimity and as the Parliament, in effect, is being denied the opportunity to play any sensible part in the determination of what is in the legislation, if they want to change anything at all by way of amendment, they destroy the package and the unanimity. One is back to square one. It has to go back to the Ministerial Council to be agreed to and it has to go back to each of the parliaments before it can become effective. I regard it as quite understandable that many people have adopted the attitude of saying: 'Let's get the show on the road first, then start to look at the detail of which way down the road we ought to go'.

With that background I would like to make some brief comments on the amendment which has been moved by Senator Evans. I do not have a great deal of objection to a number of matters which he raised from the point of view of being matters which ought to be considered. But I believe that one or two of them are inaccurate or inappropriate and some of the others, I believe, are matters which would be worth considering by the National Companies and Securities Commission, but not as a tag to this Bill which I believe ought to be approached from the point of view I have outlined, which is: Let us get this Bill, the lowest common denominator which could be achieved with unanimity on a bipartisan Commonwealth and States basis, and then let us see where we go from there. The first part of the amendment moved by Senator Evans states:
. . . the Senate
(1) expresses its concern-

(A) at the Government's abdication of its responsibility to make national laws for companies and securities pursuant to the Commonwealth's own constitutional powers, and in accordance with the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange in 1974 . . .

I can indicate only that that would not unnaturally attract some degree of sympathy from me. The members of the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange believed that the Commonwealth had the constitutional power. We also believed that the States had behaved in a way which led one to believe that they had abdicated their right to be able to determine what should happen in this respect. That Committee report demonstrated time and again that the States had failed totally and absolutely in their regulatory responsibility, as had in many instances the stock exchanges. The stock exchanges have done a very considerable amount to endeavour to reform their procedures and to overcome their demonstrable shortcomings at that time. I am not sure that the States-certainly not looked at in globo-can be given the same degree of accolade in that respect. But, as I have mentioned, I believe it is the legitimate right of a government elected by the people with a clear mandate and a clear philosophy to say that it will adopt the co-operative federalism approach to issues such as this. It is its clear right to be able to approach it on that basis, however much I may believe that it would have been more effectively done in another way.

I do not accept the suggestion in the first part of Senator Evans's amendment that the Government has abdicated its responsibility. I believe it would have been more effective had it taken advantage of the opportunity which had been created for it to go it alone, but in the circumstances it chose, quite legitimately, to go the other way. This is what has been achieved to date. The sooner we get the legislation enacted and implemented the better. The second part of the amendment states:
the Senate-
(1) expresses its concern-

(B) at the lack of effective accountability of the National Companies and Securities Commission to either the Government or Parliament of the Commonwealth, or to any other single elected Government or Parliament,

There are two aspects of that. One is general accountability. I do not accept that as a criticism of the legislation. I believed it was essential, and I still believe that it is essential, for the National Companies and Securities Commission to have a degree of independence. Whilst accountable in terms of reporting its finances and its actions on an annual basis, it should be clear, free and independent from any particular government in carrying out the statutory functions which have been given to it. Insofar as the question is raised that it is not really accountable to any of the parliaments in that no individual parliament is in a position necessarily to liaise directly with or to take up the recommendations of the National Companies and Securities Commission-one might say almost a special relationship with the National Companies and Securities Commission-I believe that is a temporary situation.

I take the opportunity to express my sympathy to those commissioners who have been finding the fulfilment of the task for which they were appointed somewhat frustrated by the time it has taken to get them into a position where they have legislation to administer and a capacity to act. I pay a compliment to the patience and the endeavours of the Chairman and his other commissioners who, notwithstanding some feelings of frustration, have stuck with it. I believe that once we get this legislative package going and once the National Companies and Securities Commission can get itself going, we will find that, as the amendments are made by the Commonwealth Parliament, there will be the opportunity for some degree of liaison and understanding and some interest taken by the Commonwealth Parliament in relation to the work of the National Companies and Securities Commission. I hope that there will be intercommunication between that Commission and the Commonwealth Parliament on a consistent basis so that there will be some reasonably close degree of understanding of where they are going and what legislative results may be desirable to follow. I refer to paragraph (1) (C) of the amendment moved by Senator Evans, which states that the Senate expresses its concern:

that despite the inordinate delay in introducing the legislation, the Parliament of the Commonwealth has not been given an opportunity effectively to scrutinise this Bill and associated Bills and will not be able effectively to determine company law in the future under the Co-operative Companies and Securities Scheme;

I think I have dealt with most of that but the only further point I would make is that, insofar as there is implied in that paragraph a criticism of the successive Ministers since Mr Fife as the responsible Minister, that would be an extremely unfair criticism. I have never known legislation to be dealt with in a way which made it more readily available to both sides of the Parliament earlier and with more opportunity to consider than has happened with this legislation. Both the Government parties and the Opposition parties have had committees in relation to this legislative package. Both committees have been provided at an early stage-long before its introduction to Parliament-with copies of the proposed Bills. Both of them have had ready access to briefing by departmental officers and I think in fact, far from its being a case in which any even implied criticism would be legitimate, the handling of this package of legislation, designed originally by Mr Fife and followed by his successors is an excellent example of the way in which legislation can be approached-by giving those who are interested on both sides of the Parliament an adequate opportunity to study, to be briefed, to consider and to debate. I therefore take the opportunity to say, insofar as there is any implied criticism in the paragraph, that I wish to assert the very opposite; that is, that the successive Ministers are to be complimented for the way in which they have approached this legislation. I also take the opportunity to pay a degree of tribute to the officers of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs who have also been very ready in the assistance which they have given to the parliamentary committees, as I understand it, on both sides, in briefing them, in providing information and in answering questions. I can say only that I wish I felt more excitement about the content of the legislation which would have made the whole exercise just that much more worthwhile. But I still look forward with enthusiasm to what this will make possible by way of future reform.
Paragraph (2) of Senator Evans's amendment reads:

calls upon the Government in the event of the breakdown for any reason of the scheme, of which the Bill is a part, immediately to proceed to the introduction of Commonwealth legislation for the national regulation of companies.

Insofar as I have supported the current Government's right, and the appropriateness of the current Government's use of the co-operative federalist approach, I reassert what was asserted in the report of the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange and that is, that it is essential that there be national legislation and if there is any breakdown in the co-operative federalist approach then there is the clearest possible responsibility on the Commonwealth Government to exercise its powers and to introduce its own legislation. I agree that any Commonwealth Government would be recreant if it did not in the case of breakdown immediately take over the responsibility to ensure that there is appropriate legislation on a national basis for what is an extremely important part of the whole operation of our national economy and our national society.
Paragraph (3) states:
notes that this Bill places uniformity before reform in deference to powerful vested interest groups and represents a retreat to the lowest common denominator standard of company law;

I have already commented on the lowest common denominator standard aspect and the retreat to powerful vested interest groups is, I believe, one of the indications of the sort of mania that occasionally distorts that which is worth while that comes out of the Opposition into that which is almost not credible. I regard it as unfortunate that those few words were put into that paragraph. Otherwise I comment that it is for the reasons that I have referred to, the lowest common denominator standard of company law.

Paragraph (4) 'calls upon the Government to expedite the establishment of an Accounting Standards Review Board'. For reasons which I gave the last time I spoke in relation to this legislative package, I totally support the urgent need for getting on with that side of it. I believe there are so many problems in relation to the whole of the questions involved in accounting standards that this is the vehicle which will enable the work that is being done at the moment to be formalised and brought into action. In saying that, I do not wish to be taken as being critical of a whole lot of the work which is taking place at the moment. But it needs to be brought together and it needs to have a focal point. I believe that the Accounting Standards Review Board could provide that. There is a horde of questions, some of which have been dealt with and others which need to be dealt with. I am quite sure that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) will not have any problem in agreeing with that particular paragraph.

Paragraph (5) 'calls upon the Government immediately to pursue a fundamental reform of company law', and includes items (A) to (P) which are a cross-section of matters of question, of interest and of areas of possible reforms. In relation to all of those I simply go back to saying that I believe they are all proper matters for the National Companies and Securities Commission to consider in carrying out its special study role as to what ought to be the framework for the development of the company law of Australia for the next few decades. I do not propose to deal with each one individually but rather to say again that I do not think they need to be the matter of a motion from the Senate. I am quite sure that the National Companies and Securities Commission will advert to the debate which takes place in this chamber as well as to the debate which has taken place in the House of Representatives.

A number of matters were raised in some detail in the debate in the House of Representatives which Senator Evans has quite effectively dealt with on a more expeditious basis in this chamber and to which I trust the National Companies and Securities Commission will have regard. I do not see the necessity for the amendment which has been moved by Senator Evans although I find a number of areas of it perfectly reasonable to be raised by way of debate for further consideration. I resist the temptation to debate in detail the issues because I think, and I hope, that they will be matters for committee consideration in this chamber at a future time. I hope that it will be possible for us to look at having a standing committee of this chamber which will continue the work which was started in this chamber of having regard to the importance of the company law of Australia, the securities industry law of Australia and the operation of that law in facilitating the growth and development and fair opportunity for people and enterprise to take place. I hope that we will have a committee which can liaise with, and pay regard to the work of, the National Companies and Securities Commission and the Accounting Standards Review Board, one that will endeavour to ensure that it has a knowledge and understanding of what those organisations are doing and some input to their deliberations. I hope that it will be a communications base with the Parliament to ensure that there is a thrust towards getting reform once there has been sufficient input from the various sectors. There has been agreement on what is desirable and necessary and then it becomes clear that we can develop a long way in this regard.

I conclude by referring to the question of unlimited liability, which Senator Evans mentioned. He did not refer to the British White Paper on company law of 1973, I think, which pointed out that limited liability has become a fiction in our type of society; that if one is small enough to need it, creditors with any sense will ensure that they have personal guarantees; if one is not small enough to need it, the question does not matter. The original objective of having limited liability to encourage entrepreneurial development and risk-taking in the interests of the development of the nation has been lost as a result of modern commercial practice. I would certainly agree that there is a very strong case for a reconsideration of the value of limited liability. There is a very strong case for the consideration of the desirability of having proprietary companies and whether they should not be limited partnerships in some form and for reconsidering the idea of having thousands of companies which have two shareholders but which have a corporate name. They are cluttering up the company registries and in effect are cluttering up the Companies Act. That is the legislative structure which attempts to deal with the BHPs and the Bloggs Pty Ltd corner stores.

In my view, the two are not capable of being dealt with in one legislative package. It would be far better to be able to say: 'That is a State matter. The small business area of company law ought not to be in the national company law at all; it ought to be dealt with on a State by State basis'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I would agree with you on that aspect, Senator.

—I did not expect total unanimity. I would like to pursue it for a moment. It seems to me that what ought to be national is that which is national. There is no doubt at all that major business enterprise, as conducted through the company structure, operates in Australia on a national, if not an international, basis, and it is absurd to be looking at it from the point of view of the possibility of administering it on a State by State basis. Equally Bloggs Corner Store Pty Ltd could never be regarded properly as a matter of the interest of the national Parliament. In my view, it ought to be able to be dealt with by an appropriate form of local legislation designed by the government elected in each State to facilitate best the development of small business enterprises in those areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I said that I would resist the temptation to develop a number of these subjects, and having taken slightly longer than I intended, I simply indicate that I support the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are good at resisting temptation.
—I support the Bill and resist the temptation to support the amendment.
