SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel like a pigmy among giants in this debate but will take some five minutes of the time of the Senate to make some comments on the Bill in the package called the Crown Debts (Priority) Bill. It is with some pleasure that I see amongst the body of advisers Mr Malcolm Starr, who played a very able role as Secretary of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which produced the report on the priority of Crown debts. The thrust of that report was that the priority which the Crown has traditionally exercised in the distribution of those meagre funds or assets which remain following bankruptcy or insolvency should be done away with. In that way the community-which is, after all what we are talking about-through its Government, should rank equally with ordinary members of the community who find themselves financially disadvantaged, imperilled or in jeopardy because of the insolvency of some firm, business or trading enterprise. The whole thrust of the report was to say that when such meagre assets have been drawn together out of the wreckage the community should share equally with employees, unsecured creditors and all who have a claim on the firm in respect of its remaining assets.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill provides some further movement by the Government-some two or three measures have been brought down in the last few years-to bring the legislation somewhat more in line with the thrust of the Senate Committee's report. Nevertheless, in our opinion, the Bill fails in that it does retain priority for the Crown in relation to tax instalment deductions, withholding tax on dividends and interest remitted overseas. What this means in particular is that when a company falls into a parlous state financially and has to be brought to an end, those employees who may have gone for three or four weeks without pay, who perhaps have accumulated entitlements to holiday leave or who are on workers' compensation, perhaps not covered by insurance arrangements-there is another category, but I cannot remember it-will find that tax instalment deductions will be taken by the Commonwealth from the meagre funds. Inevitably and invariably they will swallow up all the moneys available for distribution.

It seems to the Opposition, as it did to all the community groups which gave evidence to the Committee, that that is unfair. It does not greatly enhance the revenues available to the Commonwealth Treasury. In fact, I think it was estimated at the time as amounting to perhaps $6m. That figure does not take into account the fact that if employees do not get their wages or other accumulated entitlements from the assets that remain there may be a snowballing effect of bad debts throughout the community which may offset the revenues that would otherwise accrue to the Commonwealth Treasury. Not only is it unfair and not of great fiscal importance, but also all the community groups which gave evidence were of the opinion that the priority expressed as priority of the Crown-which has a sort of feudal and awesome ring to it but which merely means the priority of the community over certain members of it-should be done away with.

We go further in the amendment, which I intend to move at the appropriate time, and say that, indeed, employees in such situations should have a priority over the Commonwealth. In that regard, the amendment goes beyond the thrust of the Committee's report. In respect of wages and workers' compensation payments it seems to us that employees, who have no form of sustenance other than remuneration from their firm, should have priority over the community, which has other sources of revenue available to it, and over those involved with the firm, perhaps as traders or even shareholders, who also have other sources of revenue. The Opposition is firmly of the view that employees ought to have a priority in relation to wage and compensation payments. It is not enough that they rank equally, because the moneys that are left to be distributed are very meagre.

This seems the appropriate time to mention, as a sideline in a sense, that in Estimates committees much concern was expressed that the bankruptcy jurisdiction is overwhelmed by so much work at present that the official receivers in the various provinces are quite unable to carry through the distribution of assets that they have managed to marshal. In my home State there have been instances of official receivers having to write to creditors and say: 'I have the moneys available but they will not be distributed for a year or so because I do not have the staff to write out the cheques to make the moneys available to you'. We have not only the problem of the ranking of creditors but also the question of whether moneys will ever become available to them in a reasonable time, whatever their ranking. There is a strong case to be made out, perhaps at another time in another debate, for a diversion of money by the Commonwealth into the bankruptcy jurisdiction to ensure that those who are awaiting distribution of funds can receive them as speedily and expeditiously as possible. I know that Senator Messner has a particular expertise and interest in bankruptcy and associated matters-as a professional man, not in any personal capacity. With those few words I simply wish to indicate that at the appropriate time-I understand it will be a little later this afternoon-it is my intention to move the amendment, circulated to honourable senators, to the motion for the second reading of the Crown Debts (Priority) Bill 1981. That will involve adding at the end of the motion:
, but the Senate-

(1) Expresses its concern that Crown Priorities in relation to tax instalment deductions and withholding tax on dividends and interest remitted overseas, and the priority of the Crown in right of the States, have been preserved; and
(2) calls upon the Government to-
(A) abolish all remaining Crown Priorities in right of the Commonwealth and to seek the abolition of all remaining Crown Priorities in the State sphere, and
(B) ensure that all wages and compensation payments to employees are given priority over all creditors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank both Senator Evans and Senator Rae, who took part in the debate on the Companies Bill, and Senator Tate, who spoke to the Crown Debts (Priority) Bill, for their interesting and constructive remarks. I would like to dwell on the more general issues which were raised by Senator Evans and then to deal with not all but some parts of the amendment he has moved because, as he indicated, much of it received attention in the House of Representatives from the Minister who had carriage of the Bill. Firstly, may we address ourselves to the important basic concept of the legislation. It is based on an agreement between the States. On that base is constructed the legislative framework for the Commonwealth, incorporating the States as well by agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans said that in his view this is not the best way to proceed in this area. Nevertheless, as Senator Rae so ably pointed out, it is a very sound base for moving forward. I liked the kinds of remarks which he made in that respect. He regarded it as a starting point or as a launching pad. He sees it as a point from which progress can be made in the development of company law in this country. If we accept that premise, most of the issues raised in the Opposition's amendment fall to the ground. That is not to say that several of the matters raised are not matters which ought not to be contemplated by the Government. Indeed, several of the issues are important and no doubt will be discussed by the various States at the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities and at various times in this Parliament, no doubt as a result of the development of the interest of this Parliament in corporate law. I draw attention to that because Senator Rae made the very important point that one of the main results of this form of development of corporate law is that for the first time the Commonwealth will have a specific interest in the operations, the reporting functions and the regulation generally of the great Australian corporations. It provides a base from which this Parliament will be able in future to exercise a supervisory role as well as direct control, if it sees the need. That will entail the use of the new instrumentalities which are to be set up by other legislation, in particular the National Companies and Securities Commission.

I turn now to two or three of the issues which Senator Evans raised. I start with his amendment. Paragraph (1) (A) is an indication by him that the Government has abdicated its responsibility to make national laws for companies and securities. I noted that Senator Rae had some sympathy with the view that there ought to be a national law based upon the 1974 report of the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange. That is something which the Government thought about very deeply in implementing this proposal. Senator Evans's point goes to the basis of the objection which the Government saw in trying to establish a basic and general law with Commonwealth application but without consideration of the States' interests. It is of particular concern, and perhaps a glowing example of the way in which the Commonwealth works, that a great deal of enterprise has been undertaken successfully by the various States and the Commonwealth in bringing together all these diverse interests into a form of law which can be regarded as truly national.

In regard to the issues which Senator Evans raised in this context it is important to acknowledge that if the States were to break away from the Ministerial Council and enact their own legislation, to the extent that the Commonwealth had extended its own legislation to cover the whole of the Commonwealth other than the Australian Capital Territory, which it would otherwise do, the State law, where it was identical, would be superseded by Federal law. The Federal law would have application. It would need a relatively minor adjustment to the Federal legislation to enact a Federal company law.

As to the difficulties of the various State relationships, Senator Rae put the position very clearly. The States have joined the Ministerial Council. The amending process of the laws in the various States in the Commonwealth will now rely upon a majority decision rather than the unanimous one which was required in the first instance in order to bring the whole legislative framework into creation. Consequently, that seems to me to present the opportunities for which Senator Evans is looking for the future development of the legislation and, particularly, the concept of corporation law throughout Australia.

I shall deal with the points raised in paragraph (5) of the Opposition's amendment. They are the matters which the Opposition would like to see incorporated in the reform of any company law. I address myself firstly to paragraph (5) (A) which touches on:
The abolition of the category of 'exempt proprietary company' . . .

Senator Evans during his remarks referred, I think, to the aspect of trying to extend the concept of maybe unlimited liability to a great number of small companies so that they could be released from the obligations of reporting under the companies law. Indeed, that is a matter which has exercised the minds of several honourable senators in this place and, indeed, it has been discussed at other levels in the public arena. Indeed, I believe it is a very worthwhile proposition that we should look at this area in the future. To have sought to have incorporated it in this law, I believe-Senator Rae has pointed this out-would have unduly delayed the establishment of the framework and considerably lengthened the process by which this law would be set in place so as to regulate the important areas of public company operations on the stock exchanges and in order to safeguard the public against abuse.

Consequently, I hold to the view that that is a matter for the future and we ought to address ourselves to it. However, it appears to me that Senator Evans's amendment, bearing in mind his objective of establishing maybe a separate form of corporate entity, is going about the whole thing the wrong way by proposing that exempt proprietary companies should be abolished and that privileges associated with such exemption should also be abolished. It seems to me that that provides a framework for developing the later concept of which he spoke.

Paragraph (5) (B)-looking behind the corporate veil, so to speak-deals with a matter which has indeed represented a development of the law in many ways in the last few years. We have seen the rising degree of prosecutions of directors for misfeasance and all kinds of defaults of officers of companies. Indeed, the present legislation will incorporate many penalties against officers and directors of companies where those things have occurred. I do not know whether Senator Evans has other things in mind. Perhaps he does. Indeed, no doubt, as the public discussion on these issues continues matters will arise from time to time which the Government would like to consider and take into account.

In relation to the extension of the powers of the NCSC to ensure the fullest reasonable access to books. I point out that the NCSC already has extensive powers, subject to certain safeguards, for the inspection of company books where criminal activity is suspected. I suspect that that is the very area which is worrying Senator Evans. The purpose test in sub-clause 12 (1) of the Bill has been introduced to ensure that the NCSC's inspection powers are not used for purposes extraneous to the prevention and detection of offences relating to companies.

It was not thought appropriate, in the interests of maintaining some privacy for public companies, that the NCSC should require the production of company books purely for the purposes of making recommendations to the Ministerial Council for the reform of legislation. Public submissions have been received in respect of that view. It has been noted that the powers of inspection provisions in the Companies Bill appear in substance to be as broad as the inspection powers given to the Corporations and Exchange Commission in the Corporations and Securities Industry Bill 1974. In that sense I think we have met to a very large extent the criticism implied in the amendment which has been put down by Senator Evans.

As to the requirement of companies to raise and maintain a prescribed minimum nominal and paid up capital, I believe this is an essential area of the corporate law. In fact, it is a matter which the Government will be continuing to monitor and, indeed, it is already well and truly incorporated in the legislation. Paragraph (5)(I), which speaks of the 'Reform of the provisions relating to companies financing dealings in their own shares', is a matter of long-standing provision in the law. In fact, it is based generally on section 67 of the Companies Act of the interstate Corporate Affairs Commission. This provision has, however, been extensively redrafted in this Bill following a detailed consideration of the matter by the interstate Corporate Affairs Commission and in the light of submissions received from the public generally.

The exemption mentioned in paragraph 129 (9) (b) in relation to financial assistance being given to salaried directors represents no change from the existing law and no reasons have been given as to why salaried directors should in the future be treated any differently from any other employees. In addition, it should be noted that a similar provision was contained in paragraph 171 (2) (b) of the National Companies Bill. This provision did not, however, contain the requirement that the scheme approving the issue of shares be approved by both the company and its ultimate holding company at general meetings.

On the question of how a company is to become aware of relevant facts, case law seems to have established that the persons in the company who must have knowledge of the offence are those who constitute the directing mind and will of the company. The test case is Tesco Supermarkets Ltd v. Nattrass 1972. Exactly who these persons are in each case will, of course, have to be decided on the facts and it is not likely that the legislature could provide guidance which would be equally satisfactory in all circumstances. I believe again that area will no doubt have to be reviewed from time to time in the light of developing circumstances in the business world. Companies of today are different and business today operates so much differently from the way it operated in the nineteenth century. Therefore, we can say that the developments over time will need close watching, and that area is another one for future consideration.

I will just touch on the matter which was, I think, of particular interest to Senator Evans. That was the matter of trading trusts and the operation of companies acting as trustees in this situation. The provisions on trading trusts were incorporated in the April 1980 Companies Bill and were omitted from subsequent drafts because members of the Ministerial Council felt that the original provisions contained a number of defects which meant that they did not achieve their intended purpose. I add-Senator Rae pointed this out-that indeed the development of the legislative framework in this Bill has been delayed considerably by some of the reforming techniques which were adopted in the discussions at Ministerial Council level and which were subsequently found to be defective. Indeed, this area is one such affected area.

For example, in speaking to one of these defects, one of the stated aims of the provisions was to alert members of the public to the nature of the entity with which they might be dealing. However, the provisions were criticised on the ground that they might have actually disadvantaged members of the public because, knowing that they were dealing with a company acting as a trustee, they could have been deemed to have had constructive notice on the terms of the trust. Accordingly, potential creditors would have been forced to make expensive and often needless inquiries in order to engage in the most basic transactions.

Another of the stated aims of the provisions was to clarify the extent to which the assets and liabilities of the trusts were to be disclosed in the accounts of the trustee company. It was felt in many quarters, particularly in professional quarters, that the provisions clouded rather than clarified the extent of disclosure required under the existing law. Although a specific reference to trading trusts has been deleted from the Bill, there has been no lessening of the requirements of the existing law to disclose details of any trusts being carried out by companies. Of course, it is necessary to give a true and fair view of the accounts of the company itself. Further, I point out that in the present ninth schedule of the present companies Acts in the various States there is a requirement for separate disclosure of the total assets and liabilities of a trust where a trust company is involved insofar as that represents a possible contingent liability of the trust company and, as such, is available where those companies lodge their accounts with the registrar. I believe that particular area is again one which the Government will have under review from time to time. It is a matter about which the Government should and will, no doubt, accept submissions from interested persons in the community from time to time. Indeed, it is a highly relevant area of general concern.

In relation to the whole question of reform of the winding-up provisions which Senator Evans mentioned during his speech, it is indeed a very complex area of the companies legislation. Again I think it is one of those areas which would have unduly held up the development of the establishment of the legislative framework at the national level had it been entered into by way of discussion with the States at this vital stage. Accordingly, I see that area as another one for future review. No doubt the Government, with the States, will be looking at those questions from time to time.

In relation to the companies and securities law review committee, which Senator Evans mentioned, I am advised that the establishment of that committee has been referred to the National Companies and Securities Commission but as yet no report is available. I cannot indicate when we might expect a decision on that matter. Once again, bearing in mind the time, I thank honourable senators for their contributions to this debate. I wish the Bill a speedy passage.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I indicate opposition to clauses 10 and 11 of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981. This is the only specific matter that the Opposition proposes to debate officially in the whole Committee stage of this Bill. It is the very important matter of crossings, which are, of course, the arrangements whereby sales of shares are conducted within a broker's office. This matter arises in the context of crossings by brokers acting for an offeror either on or off market in a takeover situation. These two clauses of this Bill remove the prohibition that would otherwise operate on crossings of that kind. The Opposition's objection is to the removal of the prohibition, because we think crossings ought to continue to be prohibited in this context. The explanatory memorandum that was advanced by the Government in relation to this Bill, although there was no comment about it in the speech of the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore), made it clear that the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities had some reservations about this issue and it did not propose to proclaim these two clauses unless and until it unanimously so resolved. It is the view of the Opposition that there is something inherently bad about this kind of arrangement and the matter ought not to be so left; these provisions ought to be removed. If these provisions remain, the Government is asking the Parliament to pass into law provisions that it appears to have decided are neither desirable nor feasible. We are accommodating ourselves well enough to the proposition of handing over to the Ministerial Council the responsibility generally for these matters, but this in our view seems to go a little far.

SPEECH.PARA: The other more substantial and immediate objection to this provision is that we have no confidence that the business rules of the stock exchanges or the self-regulatory policing activity generally of those exchanges is likely to be sufficient to ensure that crossings transactions of this kind are handled by the brokers concerned with the appropriate degree of honesty. The Minister in his reply in the other place to our suggestions to this effect, acknowledged that there was a problem here. However, he was not prepared to concede that the problem was as large as the Opposition was claiming in the other place or that I am claiming now. The Minister conceded that at least in one respect of the situation there were problems of this kind. I refer to his response on 13 May 1981 as recorded in Hansard on page 2349. This is the same speech of the Minister when he gave us a fascinating insight into Liberal values with his comment.
The most important thing to anyone, after health, is a person's shares or money.

That ought to be recorded for posterity as a fascinating insight not only into Liberal values generally but also into the values of the Moore family household. Be that as it may, another passage of his speech reads:

That problem can only really take place where a broker is building up a holding on behalf of an offeror prior to the offer being made. Under the circumstances of the new Bill dealing with the National Companies and Securities Commission that relates to shares prior to the 20 per cent threshold. Under those circumstances a broker acting for a offeror accumulating up to the 20 per cent mark on a rising market will, of course, be buying shares at a varying price. A client of that broker offering to sell on those price patterns needs to know of these activities or have complete trust in that broker. It is only within that context that I see a problem within the prospect of crossings.

I put that into the record because it indicates that the Minister, who was a very experienced stockbroker in his previous incarnation, was at least prepared to acknowledge that there is a significant potential for difficulty in that area. He went on to claim that the honesty and diligence of the broking profession were such that caution of the kind that the Opposition had was not justified. I think it is worth noting that he made at least that acknowledgment. That in short compass, is the reason for the Opposition's position. I believe it is an important point and justifies the attention which we have given it in the Committee stage. We do not propose to divide on the matter but we would appreciate a response from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner). That is the only point that we will raise in the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel as though I am about to talk about a fruit salad, except I suppose fish and dried fruits do not make a fruit salad. Because we are debating the first reading of a money Bill I take the opportunity to raise a matter about which I have been concerned. It was, extraordinarily enough, the Australian Dried Fruits News that gave me some sort of lead to raise this matter under this legislation. The front page depicted dead trees and salt pans. At the bottom was a caption which read: 'Salt, the slow killer'. The front page created some drama that it does not always create. Of course the magazine is concerned with a matter that Australia should be much more concerned with, and that is the subject of clean water or, I suppose to be more to the point, the lack of clean water. By clean water I am not referring just to water that is free from mud or sewage, something that is hard enough to find in many parts of Australia, but also to water which is free from salt and radioactivity.

SPEECH.PARA: Because a number of matters which fall under the heading of water and especially the lack of clean water have been drawn to my attention, I am using these Bills to raise the subject. The Australian Dried Fruits News came out with this dramatic front page saying that salt is a slow killer. Salt is a great danger to the livelihood of many vine growers in Australia and particularly in Victoria. Some work is being done to try to produce salt tolerant vines, but it is slow work. It has always seemed to me that it would be more to the point if more money, time and effort were put into finding the reason for the salt being in the water in the first place and killing the vines in Victoria and South Australia. However, I found the editorial in the magazine not so much to my liking as the front page. I felt that the editorial looked at only one problem, and looked at it from a South Australian angle. It tended to lay the blame on everybody else and especially on New South Wales.

Anybody who has shown any interest in the matter lately and has been following any of the newspaper reports will have observed that South Australia is taking a very political attitude to New South Wales on the problem of water. It has been extraordinarily one-eyed in seeing only that New South Wales is causing the problem that South Australia has with salinity in the River Murray. The magazine editorial referred to hearings for the granting of licences for irrigation in New South Wales and to the fact that South Australian irrigators had sought to be seen as objectors to the granting of those licences. The last paragraph sums up what I am trying to say about the stand that South Australia has taken. It states:

The less immediate, but by far more important point at issue, is whether the present policy of the New South Wales Government is detrimental to the future development of South Australia. New South Wales rightly points out that South Australia has always been provided with the quantity of water provided under the Murray River Agreement Act and in most years has received water greatly in excess of this minimum. While this is undoubtedly true, it only serves to highlight the inadequacy of an agreement which, while ensuring that South Australia is provided with adequate water, does not also provide that the water will be of useful quality. Only a political decision can alter this Agreement.

What worries me is that while many people are engaging in politics on the issue not a great deal of work is being done about solving the very real problems. Anyone who cares about water quality in Australia at all would agree that the last sentence, which states that only a political decision can alter the agreement, is a political comment. It is unfortunate that at the moment that is the only way we see of solving the problem and altering the predicament. The Australian Dried Fruits News is participating in a most partisan and political way and is completely ignoring the part that Victoria plays in providing very saline water for South Australia. I would have liked to see the dried fruits growers, the vine growers and the fruit growers-the people in the south-eastern corner of Australia who depend on the River Murray-being much more vocal and much less political in this magazine. I would have liked them to be much more vocal and to ask governments to realise that the River Murray is one of the greatest resources Australia has and that a tremendous number of Australians depend on it for their very lives. It is time that Australian governments dropped their political stances and got together to make sure that the very real problems that are arising are dealt with.

Some members of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment-my friends Senator Jessop and Senator Mulvihill and me-only a week ago stood on the heavily silted up mouth of the Murray. To the three of us, who come from the three States that are the cause of the problem and are also affected by it, it seemed that the time had long passed when Australia should take due note of the fact that the greatest river in Australia has now no outlet to the sea. So far as we could ascertain from people who should know about the likelihood of water coming down the Murray in the next season, it will be quite a time before the Murray again has a mouth open to the sea. Indeed, it might happen that rather than water coming down the Murray to open the mouth the sea might open the mouth and take seawater up the Murray to the detriment of the lives and livelihood of a large number of people.

It seemed to the three of us, while standing on the mouth of the river, that governments of all political persuasions had been less than responsible in looking at the problem and in doing something about it. The silting up of the River Murray's mouth has been a problem that people knew would happen and about which nothing has been done. It is not a new problem. It has not suddenly happened, and yet nobody has moved to deal with the problem. Members of the Committee have listened to the River Murray commissioners and the people who work for the River Murray Commission. We have read reports and listened to the irrigators and the farmers. Everybody knows that the solution is that the River Murray Commission should have teeth to tackle the problem and to make decisions but, because everybody is too busy playing politics, the River Murray Commission has no teeth, the River Murray has no mouth to the sea, the water level is falling and people's lives and livelihood are in danger.

South Australia is trying to blame New South Wales and turning a blind eye to the part that South Australia plays. Of course, New South Wales farmers will use the water in their State. They in turn are caught up by the salt that comes into their rivers from Queensland. They too must acknowledge that a lot of the salt that flows down their rivers and into the Murray is caused because trees have been removed from catchments and land has been cleared. Victorian farmers look to use the water from their rivers and they find that because of the clearing of catchments and the clearing of land for farming they have a tremendous problem with salt. South Australian farmers look to use the Murray and they find for exactly the same reasons that they have excessive salt rising on their land. They have to use the saline water which comes down the river.

All three States continue the same illogical practices which exacerbate the problem. For instance, none of them has programs for replanting in either catchment or farming areas to lower the water table. None of them has plans to buy back lands demonstrably unsuited to irrigation and that type of farming. None of them has schemes to force more logical and sensible irrigation on the farmers in the States. Three States and the Federal Government form the River Murray Commission. The River Murray Waters Agreement has been on paper for too long and nothing has been done. Yet all members of the Commission know what has to be done. Victoria allows water to flood over salt prone land and so pour millions of tonnes of salt into the River Murray. Victoria has a water commission whose only solution is to collect salt in increasing numbers of salt lakes which, in turn, threaten good land. It knows what can solve the problem but does nothing about it. It has even gone to the length of finding out that the farmers themselves do not understand the causes of salinity in many areas. Victorian soil conservation officers conducted a small survey of farmers to learn how much they understood of surface and subsurface water movement and its relationship to soil salinity and erosion. The farmers were involved in gully and tunnel soil erosion problems. Half had dry land salted areas, yet did not appear to know what caused this. One would have thought that the next step would have been immediately to give those farmers information to ensure that they understood why the salinity arose, but nothing has been done. No public education program has been undertaken to make farmers more aware of the causes of their problems, that their own practices are causing the problems and that their practices are in turn causing problems for people in other parts of Australia.
In an article in the National Farmer, Jeff Jenkin, of the Victorian Soil Conservation Authority, is reported as saying:

. . . forests are particularly effective in keeping the soil dry as the roots spread over a wide range of depths, often to 20 metres or more. The forest provides a sensitive control over the water table . . .
When the trees are removed (cleared) and replaced by shallow-rooted pastures or cereals, this control is lost.

Yet there is no program to replant, or to plant in new areas. The problem is known, as is the answer, but nothing is done. In Victoria we have reached the idiotic position in which people propose that millions of dollars should be spent on a pipeline to take the salt water to the sea. Apparently, we are to go on producing the salt water and not do anything about preventing its production. Nothing positive has been done for more than 20 years. For that period we have known what the problem was, yet have done nothing about it.

Similarly, New South Wales irrigates and in so doing threatens new land. But at least at the moment that State, because of the dry season that it has experienced, has restricted the use of irrigation-as indeed it should in view of the problem that it faces. Those restrictions were announced after storage figures released by the New South Wales Water Resources Commission revealed that water in some dams had fallen to the lowest recorded levels. Mr Gordon, the Minister for Water Resources, is reported as saying:
Irrigation activities in some river valleys in New South Wales will be severely curtailed if the dry weather continues . . .

He added that only 60 per cent of the allocations made on the River Murray would be available, and only half of the normal quantities would be released into the Murrumbidgee. Therefore, it does not really matter if South Australia takes New South Wales to court. That will not provide the water that South Australia needs for the very life of its population, nor will it provide the water it needs for its farming areas. It will take a lot more than just one State threatening legal action against another to provide water in the condition and amount needed if we are ever to restore adequate supplies. It is extraordinary that South Australia should talk of taking New South Wales to court over whether it is preventing South Australia from obtaining water when it wants to use the water from the Murray River for the Roxby Downs uranium mine. I would have thought that by this stage South Australia would be getting its priorities right. Rather than go to court it should practise co-operation and urge that teeth be given to the River Murray Commission.

It has been said to me cynically in the last few weeks-and I believe it-that if the Murray flowed the other way South Australia might not have quite the same attitude to the use of water from that river that it does at the moment, but I do not believe that it is useful to engage in political by-play when people's lives are threatened. We have had evidence that salinity can be seriously detrimental to health; that the increasing amount of salt in Australian water can cause hypertension and heart disease. We have now two States, South Australia and Western Australia, which face a serious problem from salt in drinking water, so it is time for co-operation between all States and for firm political action on such matters.

But I find that South Australia is not happy just to have real problems with domestic water from the Murray and increasing salinity in its farming areas. Apparently it plans to use monstrous amounts of water for Roxby Downs. I find that it is also planning a uranium mine-the Honeymoon project-which is to use the in situ leeching method which employs a large amount of water to produce the final product. The environmental impact statement that was provided to the State Government and eventually to the Federal Government gives no account of how serious ground water contamination would be prevented if this method of uranium mining were employed. I am astonished that, in an area in which water is at a premium, neither the South Australian Government nor the Federal Government has demanded that the company involved show how it will deal with the matter. The environmental impact statement that it submitted was ridiculous. It gave no information on how the company planned either to obtain the water or to prevent or deal with the pollution of ground water that could arise. I am astonished that a State which is so sensitive to the use of water and the maintenance of clean water supplies should have shown so little sensitivity to a project that could damage its water resource in this way.

I find uranium mining threatening fresh water supplies in other parts of Australia also. I want now to refer to a case in Queensland. People may or may not be aware that recently a hearing was held in the Mining Warden's Court in Charters Towers about a proposal in respect of a uranium mine at Ben Lomond operated by Minatome Australia Pty Ltd. The company sought permission to lease additional areas to accommodate its tailings and waste water dams. It is of interest to note that finally the Mining Warden recommended that the application be rejected. His finding which provides certain interesting information about what could happen in the area, states in part:

The lack of hydrogeological study of the area has been pointed out, and evidence called to show that faulting and fracturing is abundant in the area. This has not been denied by the applicants witnesses who contend that such studies will take place at a later stage when more detailed engineering will take place. The objector has called evidence to show the unsuitability of the clay in the area for use as a sealer in the Evaporation Ponds and Tailings dumps, and also to encapsulate those area in their final stablisation. Evidence of the highly erosive quality of the country has been given and of the exceptionally high rainfalls which might be expected from time to time, which it is contended by the Objector would render stabilisation of contaminated wastes and tailings over a very long term impracticable.
There is some doubt as to the identity and quality of all the toxic materials which might be expected to accumulate in the evaporation ponds during the lifetime of the mining operation.

It appears that there must be some seepage or leakage from the evaporation ponds whilst they contain water during the mining operation, and that there is also danger of movement of water through the residue in the evaporation ponds when mining is finished and through tailings which have been placed in the dump and the open pit. It appears to me that only detailed hydrological and geological study can provide the necessary information on which to base any decision as to the suitability of the sites for the establishment of the evaporation ponds and tailings dumps. As to the long term isolation of tailings and wastes it also appears that such study is essential.
The mining warden finally determined:

However it is my opinion that it is the treatment of ore in this area and the long term storage of tailings and residues in the area which drains into Keelbottom Creek and ultimately the Burdekin River--
That would mean into the Burdekin Dam-
which are the main matters for concern.

I recommend to the Minister that this application be rejected in so far as it relates to the area to be used for the evaporation ponds, the tailings dump and the treatment plant and facilities pertaining thereto.

I am anxious to know whether the Federal Government will take that matter seriously. A wardens court was asked to weight up the evidence as to whether this mine could contaminate not only the ground water but also the very creek, river and dam water in an area that sustains a large population. The warden has maintained that this mine cannot continue because he cannot see that the company's plans will prevent contamination. Will the Federal Government then step in and say to this particular firm: 'You can stop right now because we will not give you a permit to export until such time as you can show us without any doubt that your mine and its workings will not contaminate the water?' What has worried people such as Senators Mulvihill and Jessop and me is that we cannot see the Federal Government or any State government taking the whole question of water seriously. Many people in Australia say blithely and as a throwaway line that this is the driest continent in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, they want to think as they did in the early post-war years with regard to the Snowy Mountains concept. That is what you are saying.

—Exactly. That is something I was coming to, Senator Mulvihill. It seems to me that, until we have a government with vision and a sense of nation and a government that really establishes and accepts that water is one of the most precious resources in Australia and that without it people will die and there will be no industry, no manufacturing, no mines and no food, and until we take the matter seriously, prevent the contamination of water and store it, we are not really facing up to one of the most important and serious problems that Australia has. In area after area in State after State we find that after water has been contaminated and after projects have been allowed to proceed, governments use political ploys to blame somebody else. I hope that this Government, my colleagues in this place and the Committee on which I have been proud to serve will continue to take up the matter and to press governments to deal with it as a matter of urgency.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to speak of my concern about the grain storage facilities in Australia. Honourable senators may recall that in 1977 I raised this matter following an explosion in the United States of America which resulted in 38 people being killed and 46 people being injured. The Weekend Australian of 31 December 1977 reported some comments I had made. It stated:

The Chairman of the Senate standing committee for science and the environment, Senator Jessop, yesterday said the Government should lay down uniform specifications for silo construction and proposed examination of a $5m to $7m scheme to safeguard existing silos.

I went on to say that if this were done we could establish throughout Australia a system of silos that could be sealed. Nitrogen could be introduced into those silos for two very useful purposes. First, it would kill the weevils without endangering human health. At present pesticides, which are sometimes harmful, are used. Nitrogen would have a very important effect. The other quite significant point is that nitrogen is an inert gas and its use would totally eliminate the possibility of explosion or fire. I believe that we are dealing with a quite significant industry in Australia which has an annual value, in the wheat area alone, of something in excess of $2 billion. Each year 55,000 farmers produce something in the order of 10 million tonnes of wheat. Of this, 77 per cent is exported and 23 per cent is used domestically.

I think this is a problem which needs to be looked at very seriously. It is all very well for people to say that the chance of an explosion in silos in Australia is very remote. In only April this year there was yet another example in the United States of America of what could happen here. I have an article which appeared in the Australian Financial Review of 5 May at page 31. It states:

Yet another grain elevator explosion has occurred in the US, this time killing seven people, and investigating experts are having trouble finding a reason for the blast. The explosion occurred on April 7 at the Texan port of Corpus Christi, where investigators say the port authority followed all the safety instructions laid down by the Federal Government.
The explosion also injured 32 people and severely damaged several 45-metre-high silos.
It is the most recent of several fatal grain elevator explosions in the US in recent years.

I have referred to the other more serious explosion which cost 38 lives and injured 46 people. A third explosion in 1978 killed three people and injured six. It seems to me that we cannot ignore the possibility of the same thing happening in this country. I think it may well be appropriate to examine the whole matter of rationalising the overseas grain sale facilities in some way. At the time when I last raised this matter I welcomed the suggestion by the then Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board, Sir Leslie Price, that wheat silos built in the future should be sealed to prevent explosions. I ventured to suggest that I did not think the Board could make such a decision. I do not know just who could because several authorities are involved. We have the Australian Barley Board and the Wheat Board. Would it be a good idea to suggest that there ought to be a grains board to take responsibility for the problem that I am mentioning?

It seems to me to be quite silly that, for example, four people go to Japan on the same day to sell wheat for Australia. It seems to me to be uneconomic and deserving of some rationalisation. I know that bulk handling in the States is done by instrumentalities. It is very difficult to get agreement under the present system because all those instrumentalities, quite properly, jealously guard their positions. It seems to me that it is time that we examined the matter again and looked at possible solutions to what I regard as being quite a dangerous situation if it is allowed to continue. Better storage facilities would also protect the valuable crops we grow in this country.

I will refer to one or two advantages of nitrogen treatment of silos. It is certainly widely accepted by the Wheat Board and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation that nitrogen can be used and is used to bring about inert atmospheres in silos. There are many advantages. There is no possibility of insects developing resistance to oxygen depleted atmosphere; there is no pollution; there is no smell or tainting of the grain; there is no danger to humans in areas neighbouring treatment enclosures; there is no rejection by purchasing countries because of the presence of toxic pesticides residues; no overseas exchange is required to develop, establish or operate the proposed system; there are no detrimental effects to grain-even the germinative quality is preserved; there is no spontaneous combustion hazard; there is no rodent survival; and, there is minimal dependence on fossil fuels as an associated energy resource.

I have some notes concerning the bulk handling authorities in each State where there is a company which is paid a fee by the Australian Wheat Board to receive, store and deliver wheat. Unfortunately, all these bodies are autonomous and the Wheat Board has no jurisdiction over them. Consequently, the industry is most fragmented. I have other notes that I think are of interest. In the interests of saving time I seek leave to have this information incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Bulk Handling Bodies

In each State there is a company which is paid a fee by the Australian Wheat Board to receive, store and deliver wheat. Unfortunately, all of these bodies are autonomous and the Wheat Board has no substantial jurisdiction over them, and consequently the industry is a most fragmented one. Such elementary policies as there being no standard design for silos and although CSIRO have recommended Nitrogen to be used, there are still silos under construction which would be almost impossible to make gas tight.

The CSIRO has suggested to all of the Bulk Handling Authorities, that they use at least two silos with an atmosphere of Nitrogen during this year. To date Victoria, South Australia and Queensland have done that.
CSIRO Trials

The first silo to be used for trials was in a flour mill at Port Adelaide of 5,000 bushel capacity. This was an outstanding success and so it was decided that the next trial in conjunction with CSIRO would be at Bordertown to be followed up at Balaklava-both in South Australia. These silos were both of 7,000 tonne capacity or 250,000 bushells.

The dimensions of the silo being about 90 feet high by 75 feet diameter. The temperature of the grain ranged from 24*C-34*C, with a moisture content of 11.5 per cent. About thirty polythene tubes were lowered into the silos at various depths and different placements so that when the grain was put into the silo, it would enable us to get the various atmosphere readings in the different situations. At the time of the PVC tubes going in, cages of infested grain and the whole life cycle of the weevil were also lowered at different spacings.
The reasons for getting the various atmospheric readings, was to check on the convection currents in the grain where there is a 40 per cent air space.
Oxygen Content
It is desirable to have the oxygen content below 2 per cent. The maximum allowable amount to kill is presently 1 per cent, where it can be achieved.
Insect Pests Regeneration

Given the ideal conditions, it is possible for a pair of weevil to produce about 220,000 progeny in the life cycle of the pair of sixteen weeks. The female weevil becomes sexually mature in the first week of her life and she lays her first eggs in one month.
Insects' Habits

The weevil eats a hole into the grain, she then backs into the hole, lays her eggs and seals the grain with saliva. The progeny then emerges about one month later, but during that period and the whole life cycle of the weevil, it breathes oxygen and so by denying them the said oxygen, a complete kill is assured.
Silos

Australia has about 2,500 vertical concrete structures which equals one-third of the total storage only. Many of these are very old, and consequently of poor concrete, and a large number of them have had the tops put on them in fairly recent times. In consequence, none of them are gas or air tight and so we are now in throes of doing just that.
Sealing of silos

Fortunately, whilst negotiating with Dunlop for the re-cycling of rubber crumbs, I found that they had through their subsidiary company, Beta Chemical Companies, a water soluble neoprin rubber solution. This, when sprayed onto concrete is absorbed into the pores and remains in an elastic condition for a very long period. It has a 200 per cent stretch and so when a silo is under stress, the seal moves with the silo and does not break.
Introduction of Nitrogen

The photographs will show how the liquid is placed in position and there are two methods of distribution of the gaseous nitrogen in the silo-from the manhole where a 2'' line is clearly seen. In one case we connected a 2'' perforated polythene tubing about 4 feet in from the wall of the silo with the holes pointing down to the floor so that when the gas was put in at about 50,000 cubic feet per hour, it would hit the floor and it would then be deflected upwards through the grain. The second method was to have two inlets at different manholes with a free flow of gas at again about 50,000 cubic feet per hour.

In a silo of 250,000 bushells, it takes about 24 hours for a complete diffusion to get the atmosphere down to under 1 per cent. The convection currents played peculiar tricks, however, in the 24 hours the atmosphere stabilises and we finish with the said 1 per cent of oxygen only.
Distribution

In Australia nearly all silos are located on railway lines and in some centres batteries of silos so that it is conceivable that we place an evaporator in a central position and the gas can be piped into each silo. The evaporator can then be filled either from a road tanker or as is done in the United Kingdom, from a nitrogen train.
Farm Silos

The CSIRO is anxious that the Australian Wheat Board, through the Bulk Handling Authorities, insist on the farmers having their own storage and endeavouring to kill the insect pests before they are delivered to the rail siding. When this happens it will be wonderful business for us as each farmer would need gas in cylinders and appropriate equipment. At this moment, the South Australian Department of Agriculture has set a pattern which could be adopted by all other State Departments of Agriculture whereby grain will be inspected at the siding silo, and if it is infested the grower will be either forced to have his grain fumigated or will have a substantial amount docked from his proceeds by the Bulk Handling Authority.
Gas Mixtures

Some 2 or 3 years ago, I asked Bill Bailey, the Chief Scientist in charge of grain storage, if the metabolism of the insect pests is upset by having them in an atmosphere with a minimum of oxygen and, if so, we may be able to combine some other poison which would kill the insects in a shorter period. He agreed that this would be desirable and so I feel that our Pestigas (which contains pyrethrin in a Carbon Dioxide propellant) and Insectigas (which is dichlorhos) will be very much in demand under the South Australian grain hygiene program.
Samoa

Whilst in Samoa in December, I learned that they are having considerable problems with the storage of coffee, cocoa, and copra from their own production and imported hops and barley for a brewery which is about to be built and also stock feeds.
I have put the Samoan authorities in touch with CSIRO who have had experience with these commodities and I think it is likely that gas tight silos will be built.
Pacific Area

From what I could see in Samoa with foodstuff shortage, there must be an equivalent problem in other areas. The extract from the Financial Review on Friday, 13 May 1977, is a most interesting one so far as Papua New Guinea is concerned, but the indication that coffee prices are going to boom for some time may be a sufficient enticement to get the local authorities in each country where you are located, to take some action in storage, and I think I could probably be of some assistance from my experience with grain, which after all is a parallel case.
S.E. Asia
Figures taken from the United Nations Statistical Year Book 1969 giving the production of rice grain of 24 nations, and in the last year showing China's crop.
The loss in the rice crop is up to 50 per cent annually due to weevil, rodents, insects, birds and rain.

Let us be conservative and allow a loss of only 10 per cent, this means that of a total of 247,557,000 metric tons, and allowing the conservative amount of 1 lb of rice per Asian per day (when in actual fact the minimum for existence is 15 ounces) the loss incurred would provide food for 147 million people.

Our nearest neighbour, Indonesia, has a production of 15,500,000 metric tons of rice per year, and based on the same forumla they could provide food sufficient for 9,500,000 additional Indonesians or, at 50 rupiah per litre, this would return them about $213m per year.
According to the United Nations, 1,000 million of the world's population of 3,700 million live in dire poverty.
Why send tractors under our aid programme to increase food production, when it is consumed by pests?

My idea is to spend the money on building gas tight silos with an indefinite life, so that the rice can be stored in them and then when they require wheat they purchase ours. This would be conditional when we build the silos, either prefabricated in Australia and welded on site, or concrete ones erected in each country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another point I suggest in the whole context of silo treatment is that it may well be appropriate for the Government to consider making this part of a foreign aid program. When I was in Canada just before Christmas at a science and technology policy conference one country represented was Kenya. Kenya is a very unsophisticated country technologically. One of its main problems seems to be how it can store grain because weevil and other infestations that tend to contaminate the food. I know we provide help on silos in certain countries. It occurred to me that it may well be very appropriate to consider a program of constructing, in some countries in Africa and South East Asia, silos which can be insulated and treated with nitrogen so as to guarantee that the grain made available in those countries for the food of the people is protected adequately. I hope that one or two of those suggestions might attract the attention of the Government and that some action might be forthcoming.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to use the debate on the first reading of these Bills to raise two matters which I believe need airing in the Federal Parliament. One of the matters relates to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and the other matter relates to social security. Both matters have strong connections. Both indicate that some sections of the bureaucracy take it upon themselves to adopt a big brother attitude. I mention first the matter relating to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme which I will refer to as TEAS from now on. I was most surprised to read in yesterday's edition of the Courier-Mail a suggestion that the Federal Government might set up a force to track down students who were overpaid under TEAS. I would like to quote some parts of the report in the Brisbane Courier-Mail. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government might set up a force of people trained in self defence and social work to track down students who were overpaid under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme.
The Federal Education Department's state assistant director, Mr Joe Kelly, said federal police used to do the job but found they already had too much work.
The article states further:
The department was trying to resolve the issue and a force of people trained in recovering over-payments seemed the best solution.

This seems to me to be an amazing suggestion. In recent times we have been told that there will be a reintroduction of fees for certain students at universities and colleges of advanced education. Secondly, we have been told that a student loans scheme will be introduced. Due to the introduction of the student loans scheme the real value of TEAS will probably decrease as time goes by. Thirdly, it has been suggested that the Government should set up a force of people trained in self-defence and social work to track down students who have been overpaid. I do not know whether the person who made this suggestion was making it as an official suggestion, one that is the official policy of the Government. If it is official policy, I ask the Government to look at it to see whether it can reverse this decision. If it is not official policy of the Government, I suggest that the Government dissociate itself from this almost unbelievable suggestion that it should set up a force of people trained in self-defence and social work to track down students who have been overpaid.

The second matter I wish to raise is concerned with the Department of Social Security. In particular, I refer to the area of responsibility of field officers. It has always been my belief that the primary role of field officers in the Department of Social Security is to assist social security beneficiaries. However, I have been informed that some field officers-I am not sure how widespread this practice is-are maintaining what would be called in police parlance a kill sheet. The field officers concerned are using a more euphemistic term than a kill sheet. They are calling it a savings book. The idea of a savings book apparently is that when they detect someone who is on a benefit but who should not be receiving it and they are successful in taking that person off that benefit, they enter in their savings book how much they have saved for the Government by having that person taken off the benefit. For instance, if a person is receiving a supporting parent's benefit and the field officer is successful in taking that person off the supporting parent's benefit the field officer enters a certain amount in his savings book. He might enter the amount of $5,000 or $4,000 or whatever the cost might have been for the whole year. If a person is taken off the unemployment benefit for some reason the field officer would then enter a certain amount. It would not be based on a yearly figure; I am told that it is probably based on a four-monthly figure, the idea being that the person would probably have continued on the unemployment benefit for another four months.

It seems to me that having a savings book-this is the parlance used in the Department of Social Security-is in direct conflict with the philosophy of social welfare. I am not quite sure what use is to be made of the material put in the savings book. I do not know whether these details are entered so that some statistics can be developed within the Department of Social Security to indicate that these field officers are in fact worth while in an economic sense because they save the Government so much a year. I mentioned earlier that I believe the field officers' primary role should be different from that. It should be to assist social security beneficiaries.

I know from the short time that I worked as a public servant in the police department that the kill sheet is a very important record. The kill sheet is looked at when people come up for promotion, especially plain clothes police officers. If their kill sheet is a good one it indicates that their clear-up rate is good, although that might be debatable. It is a measure of their clear-up rate and if they have a good kill sheet, they are then considered for promotion. I am not sure whether the same thing is happening in the Department of Social Security if these savings books are in fact kept. I would not say that it would be an official policy that one would have a look at a person's savings book record when he or she comes up for promotion. But if that savings book is there the possibility exists for a supervisor to look at it to get some idea of the work value of the person who is looking for promotion. I ask the Government whether it can have a look at these savings books to see whether they are of any use to the Department and whether they are providing statistics that the Department definitely needs. If they are not, I suggest that the use of the savings books be discontinued.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The speeches read as follows-
Dried Fruits (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1981

This Bill is associated with other Bills just introduced for export inspection charges on fishery products. The purpose of this Bill is to impose charges for the export inspection of dried fruit, from 1 July 1981. The Government's intention is to recover approximately half the total inspection costs of these products. A maximum rate of charge is specified, namely $11.00 per tonne. The actual rate of charge will be specified in regulations. It is proposed that a rate of $5.50 per tonne for exports in 1981-82 be recommended to the Governor-General for promulgation in regulations. On the basis of long term export averages, charges at this rate will yield approximately $259,000 in a full year. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Dried Fruit (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill 1981

This Bill is associated with the Dried Fruit (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1981 just introduced. It is designed to provide for the collection of charges proposed in that Bill. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Fish (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1981

The purpose of this Bill is to introduce, as from 1 July 1981, charges to recoup part of the cost borne by the Commonwealth for inspecting fish for export. This is part of the Government's program to recover costs of providing export inspection for certain agricultural and fishery products. Export inspection is designed to ensure that products meet minimum standards of quality, hygiene and presentation when exported. In 1979 the Government introduced charging for meat, grain and wool inspection aimed at recovering approximately 50 per cent of the inspection costs of the Commonwealth. The Government proposes that fees aimed at a similar level of recovery should be imposed for similar services provided by my Department to seafood exporters.

Turning to specifics in this Bill, honourable senators will see that it provides for the recovery of fish export inspection costs to be achieved through charges on fish inspected for export and for which an export permit has been issued under the Exports (Fish) Regulations. The Bill provides that the person to whom an export permit is issued under the Exports (Fish) Regulations is liable to pay the charge. Exemptions may be provided in the regulations.

To achieve the 50 per cent cost recovery, it is proposed that the following rates be recommended to the Governor-General for promulgation by regulation; rock lobster-3.9c per kilogram; all other shellfish except oysters, squid, cuttlefish and octopus-2.5c per kilogram; all other fish except oysters in the shell or half shell-0.34c per kilogram; oysters in the shell or half shell-1c per dozen. On current estimates of fish exports for 1981-82 these rates will yield approximately $1m in a full year. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Fish (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill 1981

This Bill is related to the Fish (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1981 just introduced. Its purpose is to provide for the collection of charges proposed in that Bill. It follows the provisions for the collection of levies in other export inspection charge legislation. Specifically, provision is made for exporters to pay charges due to the Commonwealth for the inspection of fish for which an export permit has been issued under the Exports (Fish) Regulations. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.
