TALK.START.PARA: —The Statute Law Revision Bill is a fascinating Bill, for the contents of which the Government is to be much congratulated. I say at the outset, however, that the Government is not to be especially congratulated for insisting on the debate on this Bill being brought on just 24 hours after its introduction without the Opposition having been given an opportunity to go through the normal procedure of debate in party committees, the party executive and the party room. Nor has there been an opportunity for the meaning and implications of what are in some respects quite unfamiliar new concepts in the Bill to be explained to one's colleagues. Nor has there been an opportunity to make a detailed check of the 50-odd pages of technical drafting to ensure that the Bill does what the Government says it does and that no swifties are being pulled. I make that protest quite genuinely. I appreciate the pressure of parliamentary business and the fact that the Government no doubt anticipated that the Bill would be uncontroversial, but I make more than a merely formal objection because important issues are involved in what I have just said. However, there is nothing I can do about that aspect so I shall move on to the more substantial issues.

SPEECH.PARA: The substance of the Bill involves two quite significant innovations. The first innovation is the very existence of the Bill as a vehicle-a compendious vehicle-for tidying up oversights, errors and oddities that creep into even the best laid drafting plans and also to accommodate minor changes that become necessary because of changing circumstances. The Opposition notes that it is the Government's intention to introduce housekeeping Bills of this kind at least once each year, and perhaps every sitting. I, for one, certainly applaud that as a rational legislative measure aiding in the avoidance of the unnecessary cluttering of the parliamentary process with what are on any view small issues most of the time. However, I believe that a genuine ground for concern has been expressed in a number of quarters-this was adverted to by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in his second reading speech-about amendments accomplished by a Bill of this kind being, as it were, hidden from the eyes of inquiring lawyers and others with an interest in keeping track of the state of statute law at any given time. However, I note his ensuring that the Government Printer is now generating the monthly tables of legislation which will make clearer than such tables have in the past the implications of Bills such as this for changes in statutes that are not overtly identified in the title of the Bill. I am prepared to accept that that measure should be enough to satisfy that concern, but it is a matter that the Opposition will keep under review.

The other innovation accomplished by this Bill, which is otherwise quite uncontroversial and quite uninteresting, is the amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act, accomplished by what is on any view a quite remarkably well hidden clause appearing in small type in the Schedule to the Bill in the form of a two-paragraph amendment to that Act. Indeed, it was so well hidden that had it not been for the Attorney issuing a Press release to draw attention to it it may well have passed unnoticed since he did not even draw the attention of the Parliament specifically to it, at least in his oral remarks as I recall them, the substance of the second reading speech having simply been incorporated. Having emerged into the daylight, by one means or another, the provision is undoubtedly a fascinating one. It is in the form of a new section 15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act, preceded by the marginal heading 'regard to be had to the purpose or object of Act'. Paragraph (1) states:

In the interpretation of a provision of an Act, a construction that would promote the purpose or object underlying the Act (whether that purpose or object is expressly stated in the Act or not) shall be preferred to a construction that would not promote that purpose or object.
Paragraph (2) states:

Nothing in sub-section (1) shall be construed as authorising in the interpretation of a provision of an Act, the consideration of any matter or document not forming part of the Act for any purpose for which that matter or document could not be considered apart from that sub-section.

In paragraph (2) the object is to preserve for the moment the prohibition on the courts having regard to extrinsic materials-although I note that the Attorney clearly foreshadowed a willingness or inclination to get rid of that prohibition and to give some positive statutory encouragement in the future for the courts to look to material of this kind. I will revert to that matter in a moment. The explanation given by the Attorney, in his second reading speech, of this proposed new section, was quite succinct, as is the Attorney's want at least on paper. He said:

The effect of the provision to be inserted in the Acts Interpretation Act will be to confirm that in interpreting provisions regard is to be had to the object or purpose underlying the Act in question.

I am not among those people who would say that the general approach of our courts is at present overly legalistic. I think there is scope for expressly stating that the statutes that we make are to be interpreted in a purposive manner. Tax decisions constitute a topical and important example that will come readily to all senators' minds, but the matter has wide implications and extends to many other statutes. The Attorney is cautious to the last in his acknowledgment of the utility of progressive values being applied in this area of the law, but he is to be applauded, if not for the way he said it then certainly for the fact that he has said it and for what he has done. It is a splendid innovation and one which the Opposition wholeheartedly applauds.

We note that although the Attorney elsewhere in his second reading speech indicated some obeisance, if not obeisance than at least acknowledgment, to suggestions in relation to legislative proposals of this kind in the United Kingdom but which have not yet merged to fruition and although he also paid due regard to the suggestions or noises that have been made in this respect by some distinguished law Lords, including Lord Scarman and Lord Wilberforce, he did not pay due regard to the role that the Opposition has played in suggesting this innovation. I refer in this instance, as I have several times today, to the role of the honourable member for Hawker, Mr Jacobi, who I am delighted to see is in the Gallery. On 2 April in the House of Representatives he put a question to the Treasurer, Mr Howard, which ran in part as follows:

Will the Treasurer now consider an appropriate amendment to oblige Australian courts to alter their canons on the construction or their interpretation of taxation laws so that such laws are applied in accordance with the intent of this Parliament? Does the Treasurer agree that such amendments are necessary to strenghten the redrafted section 260 and section 135 of the Act?
To this very positive and explicit suggestion the Treasurer, Mr Howard, replied as follows:

As to his specific request that legislative action be taken to indicate to the courts what approach they should adopt in interpreting statutes, that sort of issue more properly lies within the responsibility of my colleague, the Attorney-General, to whom I will refer what the honourable gentleman has said.

He expressed a reservation which I will come back to in a moment about the desirability of any such innovation not threatening the independence of the judiciary. Certainly there was a clear acknowledgement of the utility of Mr Jacobi's suggestion. It is evident that that suggestion was passed on to the Attorney-General and has borne fruit. It may be that independent minds, as well-constructed and cast as that of Mr Jacobi, were already working on this suggestion within the Department. I take the point that there is an obvious nexus on the public record between this suggestion and the legislation which now comes forward. I would be interested to know whether the Attorney-General is prepared to acknowledge the contribution that the Opposition has made, through the person of Mr Jacobi, in stimulating this initiative.

There can be no doubt of the very real importance of this amendment and of its potential significance across the whole broad sphere of legal interpretation so far as the Federal statutes to which it immediately applies are concerned but also perhaps beyond that into the whole area of statutory interpretation generally and ultimately even into the area of constitutional law about which I will say something in a moment. Clearly the most revolutionary immediate significance of this Bill and this proposed new section in the Acts Interpretation Act is likely to be in the area of taxation law. I find it difficult to regard it as a coincidence that this measure has been introduced on the same day as the Government's new Part IVA of the tax legislation. I applaud that conjunction of legislative initiatives from the Government, even though it will be necessary to express next week something less than ecstacy about the particular drafting adopted by Mr Howard in the production of Part IVA which seems to the Opposition not to justify the fanfare of enthusiasm which has so far been received.

It is clear that if this new approach is adopted, or this much more explicit parliamentary direction to the courts to adopt this approach becomes law, then we can expect much more explicit attention being paid by the courts in the future to these purposive questions. That is as it should be, because in the past there has been a real problem in this area. The problem arises from the fact that statutory language, like any other kind, is notoriously open-textured, imprecise and ambiguous. Statutes are not and cannot be drafted with mathematical precision to cover all possible contingencies. Traditionally judges get over this difficulty by saying that what they are doing in interpretating statutes is eliciting the intention of the legislature.

When the legislation does not on its face state any positive intention or give any indication as to what its purpose might be, the result is that, quite legitimately-no one believes the Parliament, as distinct from the Executive and its draftsmen' does have a collective intention about anything or if it did have such an intention it would be discoverable in the confused flurries of rhetoric that constitute the Hansard record-judges traditionally, in the absence of directions of the kind now contained in this new measure or in the absence of explicit statutory references to purpose or intention of particular legislative measures, have had to turn for guidance to one or other of two more or less equally time-honoured but nonetheless basically irreconcilable approaches to statutory interpretation. One of those two chosen approaches seems, on the face of it, to depend, as much as on anything else, on the taste, temperament, conscious or subconscious, political prejudice or even the state of the judge's liver on the day. Those two approaches are literalism on the one hand and what can be loosely described as liberalism on the other.

The literalist approach, in essence, amounts to this, and it has been a very familar game played by certain High Court judges in recent years. Take the literal words of the statute absolutely at their face value, ignore any absurdity, manifest inconvenience or even inconspicious injustice that would flow from their literal application and if all this creates a mess then leave it to Parliament to sort out. The alternative route is the liberal approach for which lawyers have a variety of more highfalutin expressions, but in essence this is the kind of approach which allows the plain meaning of words to be qualified or extended if a strictly literal interpretation would lead to absurd or mischievous consequences or thwart what appears to be the manifest purpose of the statute in question. The fact that these two approaches are on the face of it more or less flatly contradictory is bad enough, but what really bemuses successive generations of law students--

TALK.START.PARA: —And others.

—And others. What really bemuses successive generations of law students in particular, and I speak from that experience, and successive generations of parliamentarians, and Senator Georges can speak with ample authority on that score, at least until they come to recognise the whole judicial non-creativity argument to be the racket or charade that it is, because we all know that judges are creative in the way they make law, is to find one and the same judge very often in successive judgments-in the case of Sir Garfield Barwick it was not unknown for it to happen within the course of the same judgment-applying those two opposite techniques. One picks one's technique in order to get the result that one intuitively perhaps thinks is appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: The classic recent demonstration of these two quite distinct judicial styles at work, between the literalist on the one hand and the liberal on the other, was, of course the 1980 Westraders case which has become something of a classic in this respect in which the High Court, by a three to two majority, held that a share trading partnership was entitled to manipulate the price of its trading stock for tax avoidance purposes in such a way as to convert a small real profit into, I think, a $6.4m paper loss. Sir Garfield Barwick, the Chief Justice as he then was, delivering the leading majority judgment, on this occasion chose to wear his literalist hat. Indeed, his literalist hat is the one Sir Garfield was prone to wear on occasions when taxation law was in question. On other matters, he tended to be somewhat more liberal, but that is by the way. Mr Justice Murphy, as usual the leading dissenter, was on this occasion being his more or less consistent liberal self and I think it is a fascinating exercise to juxtapose two key extracts-there are lots more in their judgments-to indicate these two styles of work. This is what Sir Garfield Barwick had to say:

It is for the Parliament to specify, and to do so, in my opinion, as far as language will permit, with unambiguous clarity, the circumstances which will attract an obligation on the part of the citizen to pay tax. It is not for the Court to mould or to attempt to mould the language of the statute so as to produce some result which it might be thought the Parliament may have intended to achieve, though not expressed in the actual language employed . . the citizen has every right to mould the transaction into which he is about to enter into a form which satisfies the requirements of the statute . . Nor can it matter that his choice of transaction was influenced wholly or in part by its effect upon his obligation to pay tax.
Mr Justice Murphy, on the other hand, had a somewhat different approach which can be summarised in this passage:

It has been suggested, in the present case, that insistence on a strictly literal interpretation is basic to the maintenance of a free society. In tax cases, the prevailing trend in Australia is now so absolutely literalistic that it has become a disquieting phenomenon. . . . Progress towards a free society will not be advanced by attributing to Parliament meanings which no one believes it intended so that income tax becomes optional for the rich while remaining compulsory for most income earners.

It need hardly be said which of those approaches I find the more persuasive. Perhaps it also should be said that I believe Mr Justice Murphy's approach to be, even before the enactment of this legislation, better law. Certainly, it would be so regarded in Britain where the courts have in recent years indicated a clear preference for the liberal approach, even in dealing with penal and revenue statutes of the kind where traditionally there has been very narrow construction against the Government. Lord Scarman made the point very effectively, I think, in his Fullagar Memorial Lecture at Monash University in September 1980 when he said:

When I, an English judge, read some of the decisions of the High Court of Australia, I think they are more English than the English. In London no one would dare to choose the literal rather than a purposive construction of a statute, and 'legalism' is currently a term of abuse.

One of the joys, the incidental delights of this particular legislation, not made less piquant by the fact that it is legislation coming from the current Attorney-General is that 'legalism' may well become a term of abuse now here in Australia too.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting I was saying that the kind of literalist approach that had become so characteristic of the Australian courts was in the process of being shown to be the incongruity which it in fact is in terms of the international development of the common law, in that it is an approach which has come in for quite robust criticism in the British courts and by British judges, including Lord Scarman. The best recent demonstation of that is the House of Lords taxation case which was recently widely publicised in this country. It is the case of W. T. Ramsay Ltd v. the Inland Revenue Commissioners in March 1981 in which the House of Lords made it absolutely clear that in the context of contrived artificial taxation avoidance schemes it was absolutely unprepared to accept the traditional literalists sorts of arguments that have been used by tax avoiders from time immemorial in Britain as in Australia, and was prepared to take the plunge of making judgments about the intention, the overriding purpose, of the legislature.

SPEECH.PARA: The dicta-indeed, the statement of law-which emerged from that case are very apt as a backdrop to the measure that is taken here by the Government today. It should serve to concentrate wonderfully the minds of those remaining Australian judges who have been unwilling to exercise their judicial responsibility in the national and community interest and to produce interpretations of legislation which are in conformity with what not only the parliaments but also right thinking members of the community wish to achieve.

I wish to make four remaining points in relation to this Bill. The first is that the enactment of this amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act means that the stage is now set for a much greater exercise in the future by Parliament of its power, and I hope its responsibility, to include within this legislation particular sections or clauses stating clearly the purpose for which the legislation is enacted; in other words, articulating the intention of the Parliament and not simply leaving it to be untangled from the often necessarily abstruse technical language that we have to adopt to communicate our intentions so far as particular provisions are concerned. There is a case for doing this. It is gradually being acknowledged in recent years. One of the best recent examples is the Freedom of Information Bill, which apparently is inevitably due to come before us, albeit in emasculated form, tomorrow. I hope that a further example will prove to be the new Part IVA of the taxation legislation, which, although in its present state of development it lacks a clear statement of purpose or intention and leaves that simply to be intuited or implied, may conceivably, after the parliamentary debate in which the Opposition will expose it in the next couple of weeks or months as the case may be-this parliamentary session is proceeding as long as possible-end up with a clause of that kind which may help judges come to the conclusion that Parliament wants them to come to. I simply state the point that I hope it becomes almost a matter of drafting routine for the Office of Parliamentary Counsel to include, and indeed for departments and Ministers to brief the OPC to include, intention or purpose provisions of that kind that will easily allow the application of the clause that we are enacting here today.

The second point I make is that it is crucially important that the Government now proceed with its announced intention to legislate so as require the courts to take into account not only in general terms their perception of the intention or purpose of the legislation but also the kinds of explanatory memoranda which we are capable of generating in relation especially to complex legislation. This is a suggestion that the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, in fact floated in an address to the Australian Society of Senior Executives in September last year. It is an initiative which was warmly welcomed at that time and has been since, certainly by me, and will be, I assure the Attorney, by the Opposition whenever he chooses to get to the starting line in respect of that further initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Georges might be interested.
—I am interested in the back scratching that is going on, but do not let me interrupt.
—It is entirely a prelude or an overture to the something less than back scratching that can be expected tomorrow.
—Will it deal with Peter Clyne?

—The taxation legislation looks likely to be able to deal with Mr Clyne in a way that its predecessor legislation has not. I do not think the courts have ever had much trouble dealing with Mr Clyne. The main problem with dealing with Mr Clyne is simply to get the executive machinery of government working fast enough to keep up to date with him. My view has always been that the only way one can cope with people who are as blatant and as outrageous in their social irresponsibility as Mr Clyne is in the taxation field is to enact retrospective legislation so that he is not able to get away with even one step down the track at any given point. But Senator Mulvihill is correct in saying that this is the context-taxation legislation-in which this kind of provision, in association with other substantive provisions, will have its major impact. But it will have an even greater impact if it is supported also, as I said, by explanatory memoranda being able to be taken into account. I make it clear to the Government that it will have the full support of the Opposition, I expect, if that initiative is taken, and I hope it is taken in the near future.

SPEECH.PARA: The third point that I make by way of concluding remarks, and it is particularly apt given the presence in this chamber of my learned colleague Senator Georges, is that there has been concern in some quarters that judicial independence may in some way be put at risk by this kind of provision. The Minister, Mr Howard, raised this issue in his answer to Mr Jacobi on 2 April, which I referred to previously. The Attorney adverted in passing to this question in his second reading speech, claiming that there was no question of any such principle being infringed by this legislation. Of course, Senator Georges, with his usual perspicacity, at Question Time today drew attention to this as a possible problem. I make it clear that I believe this kind of concern, although it is perfectly understandable, is in fact unjustified in the context of this legislation. This kind of provision is not a matter of anyone, least of all the Executive, trying to interfere with the way in which the courts adjudicate particular cases. It is not in any way a matter of exercising influence in the sense of making suggestions to the court as to who should win and who should lose a case. What is an issue here is simply the general mode of interpretation, the general criteria of interpretation to be applied by the courts. It in no sense involves an exercise of influence of the kind that has traditionally and quite properly been thought to be utterly unprincipled and out of step with our democratic tradition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will we get long preambles setting out the mischief?

—Indeed, I suggested earlier that I hope this legislation means that the stage will be set for the routine incorporation in legislation of purposive or intention provisions stating the objects and purposes of legislation. Whether they are in the form of preambles or in the form of substantive provisions does not matter technically all that much.
—Based on the presumption that all judges are dills.

—From one point of view it may be based on that presumption, in the sense that some judges have been less keen than others to accommodate themselves to the realities of the twentieth century and to the necessity for detailed and systematic regulation of social misbehaviour. It may be that that is enough to constitute them as dills in the eyes of Senator Georges. Certainly I am not usually heard to defend too vigorously those elements of the legal profession which I regard as behaving socially irresponsibly. I prefer to regard this as an exercise in concentrating the minds of the judges into more correct and sensible channels should they be minded to stray from the path of socially responsible rectitude. I think that is a slightly more apt and respectful way of describing what this legislation is about.

SPEECH.PARA: The object of the exercise is really to reinforce the traditional principle that has been always understood to apply as the basis of statutory interpretation, and that is that Parliament's intention should prevail. This provision is just a machinery way of improving the probability that that will be the case. It is, of course, Parliament's intention that is in issue here. An executive piece of regulation is not involved in our discussion tonight; we are dealing with a provision in an Act of the Parliament. What is in issue is something very different from the kind of influence, for example, which has manifestly been sought to be exercised by Mr Sinclair, the Minister for Communications, and other members of the Executive Government in relation to proceedings currently pending before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal-a quasi-judicial body-in respect of Mr Murdoch's problems with television channels. If we are talking about interference with the independence of judicial and quasi-judicial proceedings, it seems to me that the kind of case where individuals and their rights and potential obligations are in issue is much more to the point than this kind of general guideline provision that is in issue here.

The fourth and final point I make is not unimportant. In one way, regrettably it is the case that nothing that is accomplished in this legislative provision will do anything to govern the interpretation of the Australian Constitution by the High Court or any other court. It is the area of constitutional interpretation, above all others that one can argue is crying out for flexible, purposive, non-legalistic and non-literalistic interpretation. That that is so follows from the fact that the Australian Constitution is not a Commonwealth statute but is rather a statute of the United Kingdom Parliament. Occasions and considerations such as this produce in us the salutory reminder that we are creatures, constitutionally and legally speaking, of our former colonial masters, and that is an unhappy constitutional and legal state of affairs. We realise again the extent of that subjugation when we appreciate how little power we in parliament have to determine the kinds of criteria that should be applied by the High Court in interpreting the Constitution. It is beyond our power to make any such suggestion to the court. The court must treat the situation according to how it sees it. We cannot give the court any guidance in the process. I hope that the habits of mind that seem to be gradually emerging in the present High Court, if not its immediate predecessor, and which can be expected to be encouraged somewhat by this kind of legislation in the context of statutory interpretation generally will continue the process of creating in the High Court a rather more purposive approach, a less legalistic approach, to constitutional interpretation.

The Constitution has always been an area in which there has been some disposition on the part of the High Court to respond flexibly to changing economic and social circumstances, but arguably that has not been sufficiently so. The kind of interpretive approach that is involved in this legislation and which the Government seems anxious to adopt in the text of legislation generally is, I suggest, a perfectly appropriate and sensible interpretive approach to adopt in relation to constitutional law generally as well, even though I notice that the Attorney-General was at pains in his second reading speech to point out how he, for one, was not dissatisfied with the legalistic reputation the High Court and other courts continue to enjoy. I conclude by simply repeating that the Opposition welcomes the Bill and congratulates the Attorney-General on his good sense and his progressive instincts in picking up the Opposition's suggestion which appears to have stimulated the legislation which is before us tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the Opposition for its support of this measure. Although that is a fairly common phraseology to use in situations of this kind, I emphasise it in this case and hope that the Senate will accept it as having real meaning and sincerity. It is vitally important to have a bipartisan approach to a measure of this kind. I had some chiding earlier today from Senator Georges about this matter. I suggested that he readdress his question to his colleague Senator Evans. I suggested that Senator Georges might receive a more forthright answer to the question from his colleague than he would get from me. I think he has had a more forthright answer, and I am sure he has been convinced.
—Having only partly understood, how could I be convinced?

—I mention that because I think Senator Georges would understand this aspect: It is not a matter of the Executive government giving any directions or making any decisions. Much less is it a matter of seeking in any way to direct the independent courts of this country and our judicial system. This Parliament is enacting an amendment to the law relating to statutory interpretation. The Acts Interpretation Act, to which is being added this measure, was first passed by this Parliament in 1901. There is a long history of such Acts being passed not only in this Parliament but also in every other parliament operating under our Westminster system of government. Parliament plays a very long, respected, traditional and influential role by laying down general rules of interpretation for the courts which the courts observe. Although the courts themselves are also obliged to interpret an interpretation Act, I assure the Senate that they are quite familiar with the role of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: This measure may seem to be one for argument by lawyers and one about which many of our colleagues may feel some impatience. But occasionally what lawyers do and say has some major relevance to the community. I venture to suggest that this measure, although it may be very much a lawyer's measure, does have and will have very great relevance. Under our democratic system the measure is enormously important not only to what parliament does but also to what the courts do. The courts' approach and contribution to the development of law historically has been of enormous importance. It is perhaps only in the more recent years of the development of the law, and I am speaking not of decades but of centuries and in particular this country, that the courts have retreated very considerably in their role of developing the law-certainly this has occurred in an overt way-and have left it to parliament.

Parliament has very much asserted its role to the extent where the courts have almost, in theory at least, retreated to the point where they ostensibly claim that any development of the law is not for them but for parliament. That is a most unfortunate trend, which has resulted in Parliament being overwhelmed by legislation of enormous proportions and growing technicality, to an extent that, as honourable senators will agree, it is beyond our capacity as parliamentarians to handle it. Therefore, it is time to take corrective measures and the proposal before us represents a first and very important step to that end. I hope that it will prove to be a catalyst in correcting the imbalance that has developed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that it would add to it rather than diminish it.

—No. Many judges have said that they are obliged to interpret legislation literally and may not look beyond that. That approach, if taken to its logical conclusion, as unfortunately occurs quite often, obliges parliament to attempt to produce legislation which will cover every conceivable situation that may arise. I see the role of parliament as much more than one of laying down broader principles and relying on the courts to apply them to those manifold situations which develop and which parliament cannot, despite its best efforts, always anticipate. Parliament's role will be much better served if it can concentrate on laying down more general principles, policies and so on and leave to the courts their application to the specific cases with which they have to deal. The measure represents a first step, because courts do need more guidance than traditionally we have given them. I repeat, we will have to supplement it with better signals than traditionally we have given the courts as to our intentions and purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent years some very interesting suggestions have been made as to how we might do that. The matter has been the subject of a good deal of debate, largely of course in the legal profession, but very little that is as specific as is the proposal before us tonight has actually been done about it. The additional measures that I propose to bring forward will give the courts better and clearer signals as to the way in which they can apply the general principle that is embodied in the measure before us. I do not want to rush the matter because it warrants a good deal of care and consideration, which I am not satisfied that I have yet been able to devote to it. Certainly, many suggestions on the subject have been made. My Department and I are in the process of giving them consideration. I hope that will result in additional measures being introduced in the near future.

The Parliament of the United Kingdom will probably be passing legislation on the same subject in the near future and its actions will be of great interest and assistance to us. It is for these reasons that I welcome particularly the support of the Opposition in what is proposed and am encouraged to persevere with my ideas on the matter and bring forward additional proposals in the near future.

I do not want to do any point scoring in relation to this subject. I am very pleased that members of the Opposition have had similar ideas. I pay full tribute to the fact that the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) has raised the matter in recent months, but it is a subject in which I have been interested for a considerable period. I opened up the question in a speech in September of last year, but even that was not the first occasion on which I thought of it. It is one about which I have been very concerned for many years. I am pleased to have had the opportunity to bring forward this measure and to start the ball rolling. I hope that it will lead to more detailed and effective methods of redressing the imbalance which has developed between the courts and the Parliament in relation to the details of law making. A great deal remains to be done. I hope that from time to time the Parliament will address the problem and make some contribution towards resolving it.

Senator Evans mentioned the matter of constitutional interpretation. It is true to say that the Acts Interpretation Act cannot apply to the Constitution. Suggestions cannot be made to the High Court by way of Act of Parliament, as to how it should address the interpretation of the Constitution. Nevertheless, I believe that an amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act of the kind proposed will indicate to that court, and to other courts, the preferences of the Parliament as to how the courts should approach even that document.

At present we are engaged in important discussions with the States with a view to eliminating what one might call the residual constitutional links with the United Kingdom-as Senator Evans has put it in more colourful language, cutting the knot of our colonial past. Admittedly, that is not directly concerned with the matter that the Senate is now discussing. Nevertheless, if we can resolve such questions we will have a uniquely and clearly Australian constitutional base. When that has been finally achieved, some of the questions and problems that Senator Evans has mentioned in relation to constitutional interpretation will also disappear. For those reasons I believe it is an important measure. I am most gratified and encouraged by the support that has been given to it by the Opposition. I believe this is a first step in some very important developments which in the not too distant future will be taken by this Parliament in an area of great significance not only for lawyers but also for all those who are affected by what lawyers and courts do.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The point I was making last night was that if those planes were sold and if the BAC 111s were modified, we would still have an adequate VIP fleet, we would still be able to fly to most places in the world with it and we would not face the catch-22 situation whereby every time we train a crew to fly the 707s we run the risk that a commercial airline may offer them a position and we would therefore lose them. That is all I want to say on that issue.

I would like to make a number of comments about the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, which was also concerned in Estimates Committee D. During the hearings I asked for a list of overseas posts where the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is represented. I was quite astonished to hear evidence about the situation in Africa, because the Department is represented in Pretoria and Cape Town in South Africa and in Nairobi. Only one out of the three posts that we have in Africa is in a black African state. The other two are in a country the policies of which the Australian Government has certainly no support for and with which we have had a minimum of contact for a number of years. I believe the Department should seriously assess where its priorities lie. I do not believe we should have a post of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in Zimbabwe. I believe a different situation exists there and that it would be wrong at this stage of that country's development for us to look for people to leave the country. We have a government which opposes the political stance of the South African Government, which opposes sporting links with South Africa and which completely opposes the system of apartheid that South Africa has at the moment. Yet when we look at where we have posts to encourage people to come here, we see that we have two posts in South Africa and only one post in the rest of Africa.

The same situation occurs on the American continent. We find from the list we were given that we have only two posts in South America. Yet in North America-the United States of America and Canada-there are seven posts. I hope that there will be government initiatives in looking for immigration from South American countries, but when I look at the list I gain the impression that the Department may be more interested in encouraging the more affluent North Americans to come and settle in Australia than it is in encouraging people from South America. We have only two posts in South America where there are a number of countries in political turmoil and with a depressed standard of living. Yet we have three posts in the United States and Canada. I believe we ought to reassess our priorities.

The last point concerning the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs deals with the status of refugees. We have a particularly disturbing situation at the moment. We are taking in a large number of Indo-Chinese and east European refugees. I want to make it quite clear that I do not oppose the Government policy of accepting refugees from these countries. In 1978-79, of 14,000 refugees only 43 came from the Lebanon. In 1979-80, of approximately 20,000 refugees 13 came from the Lebanon. That is 0.06 per cent of the refugees came from the Lebanon, a war-torn country in which people are being killed. There are 200,000 Lebanese living in Australia who have a number of relatives there. They are suffering great hardship. Yet we are accepting into this country as refugees a number of people from East European countries.

I know they come from Poland, Czechoslovakia and some of the other countries behind the Iron Curtain. I am not disagreeing that, in fact, they are political refugees. But countries in Western Europe are accepting refugees from Indo-China. I just wonder whether we have the right priorities and whether it would not be right for Australia to be saying: 'The countries of Western Europe should be accepting the refugees from Eastern Europe'. I am wondering whether it is right that some of the refugees coming into Australia come from Eastern Europe. We should be saying: 'This is the number of Indo-Chinese refugees coming to Australia and we will fill the rest of the quota with people from the Lebanon, where a war is going on. We will put the pressure on the Western European countries to take those genuine refugees coming from Eastern Europe'.

I wish to amplify what I said to Senator McLaren on one of the other occasions on which he raised this matter. A concept prevails in large areas of communications in business that there is some advantage in having a shorthand identification of an operation. That is why all sorts of people in business, politics and other areas of activity endeavour to have a name to which people can learn to relate which is simple and easy. That is why, for instance, the Myer Emporium Ltd changed its trading name to Myer. If one looks at the bills one receives from Myer if one deals with that company, or at the outside of one of its buildings, one sees that one of the very large retailers in Australia trades under the name of Myer although its full name is the Myer Emporium Ltd. We see the name Shell because the company has developed a situation where people relate to--
—That is because it is common usage, not because we pay $409,000 to an organisation to change its name. It is common usage.

—If it is a matter of common usage, how did it become a matter of common usage? Because the company decided to trade under an identifiable, simple shorthand name. Apparently it is a little beyond the wit of Senator McLaren to be able to identify that what has been successful in corporate business activity in a very large cross-section of both public and private sector of corporate business activity-apparently Senator Coleman cannot understand this-that an identification and an association can be built up so that a stage is reached where people can relate, for example, Shell to the Shell Co. of Australia Ltd or Myer to the Myer retailing store. SPEECH.PARA: It is a concept of a development of a corporate image. It is not just related to names and logos, it is related to an analysis of an organisation and to a form of super-management consultancy-cum public relations or an integration of the two. Without asserting that Australian National got value for money for the $409,000 or whatever the exact amount was, it is not uncommon for major business enterprises of this country and other countries to engage the management and public relations consultants to advise how to structure an operation, so that people can relate to a business undertaking. Employees, customers and would-be customers can all relate to it. It has been adopted by a large cross-section of business-public and private-in Australia and elsewhere.

As I have said on a previous occasion, I think it is unfair for Senator McLaren to imply that there is something sinister in the change of name. I believe the new management of the Australian National Railways Commission has done a very significant job in trying to bring that organisation into the twentieth century. It had its difficulties. Railways around the world have tended to have difficulties because they stagnated in what tended to be a nineteenth century attitude in relation to management and organisation. Endeavours are being made to overcome that situation by the new management of Australian National Railways Commission. If it chooses to engage consultants to assist in developing management, structure and public relations techniques, then let us await the result before we start to criticise. I wish the management luck. I believe railways can be one of the important aspects of public transport in Australia. I defend the decisions which have been taken by people who have been appointed to do the job. In no way, as I understand it, has there been interference or direction from the Government of the day in relation to this aspect. I apologise to the Senate for taking a little time, but Senator McLaren has repeatedly raised the matter. I wish to ensure that the Australian National Railways Commission trading as Australian National, gets a fair chance to do its job.

—The honourable senator is perfectly free to speak further on that matter also. Senator Grimes asked about the changed work test arrangements following the Review of Commonwealth Functions. Under the new arrangements, unemployment benefit claim forms and fortnightly applications for continuation of unemployment benefit will be lodged direct with the Department of Social Security, not the Commonwealth Employment Service. Personal lodgment of the forms will not be necessary. The CES will continue to act as agent for the Department of Social Security in the administration of the work test and will report work test failures to the Department. That will mean that the CES will report on the following matters: Where a claimant fails to maintain registration with the CES; where a claimant fails, without good reason, to respond to a request from the CES to attend for an interview; where a claimant declines referral to a suitable job vacancy; or where a claimant fails to accept the offer of suitable work or does not commence duty in a suitable job that he has accepted. On receipt of adverse work test reports from the CES the Department of Social Security will review eligibility. Decisions under the Social Services Act will remain the sole responsibility of the Department of Social Security.

Present planning is that the Department of Social Security will begin to accept claims for the new health cards from early in August 1981 so as to be able to issue the first cards to coincide with the commencement of the scheme on 1 September 1981. Special attention will be paid to advising the different categories of social security pensioners and beneficiaries of their entitlements.

Is the expenditure just by the Department of Industry and Commerce or is it split amongst other departments so that it will be very difficult to find the amount?

—There will not be any difficulty. The total appropriation will be through the Department of Industry and Commerce and I understand that the total is slightly in excess of $500,000. My advice is that the reason it is shown as only $260,000 this year is that the balance of the accounts will not be payable until next financial year. The accounts will be shown in the appropriations for the Department of Industry and Commerce which will be before the Senate in the post-August period.

—I understand from the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) that the bulk of the advertising is to be carried out by the Department of Industry and Commerce. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 31 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Minister for Social Security aware of a retirement plan advertised by the Australian Retired Persons Association Friendly Society in which it is claiming that regular periodical bonuses paid by the plan 'are not regarded as income by the Taxation Department and that they are excluded from the income test applied by the Social Security Department for the age, invalid and widows' pensions, etc.'; if so, (a) is this advertisement factual; (b) how can such payments be excluded from consideration as taxation or as part of the income test applied by the Social Security Department; and (c) are similar benefits from other organisations excluded in this way.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The retirement plan has been brought to my notice. The Minister representing the Treasurer has already replied to the taxation aspects of the honourable senator's Question No. 566 (Hansard, 29 April 1981, Page 1539) which is in the same terms. Answers to those aspects falling within the responsibility of my portfolio are as follows:
(a) I have seen an extract from a publication by the Australian Retired Persons Association and, as far as it applies to social security pensions, the information is correct.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current rate of supplementary assistance.
(2) When was supplementary assistance set at this amount.
(3) What would be the current rate of supplementary assistance if it had been adjusted in accordance with Consumer Price Index movements since the date mentioned in (2).
(4) What would be the annual cost of:
(a) doubling the current rate of assistance; and
(b) increasing the assistance to an amount equal to that mentioned in (3).
(5) What income test is placed on the payment of supplementary assistance.
(6) When was this income test last adjusted.
(7) What would the income test now be if it had been adjusted in accordance with movements in the Consumer Price Index since the date mentioned in (2).
(8) What would be the annual cost of:
(a) paying the current rate of assistance;
(b) doubling the rate of assistance; and
(c) increasing the benefit to an amount equal to that mentioned in (3)-using the income test mentioned in (7).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) $5.00 a week ($260 per annum) for a single pensioner, a supporting parent beneficiary and a married pensioner couple. A similar payment called supplementary allowance is payable at the same rate to sickness beneficiaries after six weeks.
(2) November 1974.

(3) If the present rate of supplementary assistance were increased by the movement in the Consumer Price Index from the December quarter 1974 to the December quarter 1980, it would become $9.25 a week (rounded to the nearest five cents), equivalent to $481 per annum.
(4) It is estimated that:
(a) doubling the current rate of supplementary assistance/allowance would cost $110 million in a full year;
(b) increasing the current rate of supplementary assistance/allowance to $9.25 a week would cost $90 million in a full year.

These costs are based on numbers in December 1980 and include an estimate of the cost in respect of pensioners who would become newly eligible for supplementary assistance/ allowance as a result of the increased rate of payment.

(5) In the case of a single pensioner, the maximum rate of assistance is reduced by the excess of his or her income as assessed over $1.00 a week ($52 per annum). In the case of a married pensioner couple, the reduction is one-half of the couple's combined income as assessed in excess of $2.00 a week ($104 per annum). In determining income as assessed, up to $6.00 a week ($312 per annum) is disregarded for each child. The income test applied to supplementary allowance is similar except that there is no 'disregard' for children.
(6) October 1965. Between then and November 1976, the test was applied to a combination of income and property. Since November 1976 it has been a test on income alone.

(7) If the income above which reductions commence were increased by the movement in the Consumer Price Index from the December quarter 1974 to the December quarter 1980, it would now be $1.85 a week ($96.20 per annum) in the case of a single person, and $3.70 a week ($192.40 per annum) in the case of a married couple.
(8) It is estimated that:
(a) amending the present income test to that outlined in (7) without changing the present rate of supplementary assistance/allowance would cost $3 million in a full year;
(b) doubling the present rate of supplementary assistance/allowance and amending the income test to that outlined in (7) would cost $115m in a full year; and
(c) increasing the present rate of supplementary assistance/allowance to $9.25 a week and amending the income test to that outlined in (7) would cost $95m in a full year.

These costs are based on numbers in December 1980 and include an estimate of the cost in respect of pensioners and beneficiaries who would become newly eligible for supplementary assistance/allowance as a result of the new income test or the increased rate of payment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is Americium-241 a highly dangerous derivative of Plutonium.
(2) What was Gulf Oil Corporation, Gulf Nuclear of Texas, United States of America, doing with the material in New South Wales when it was spilt onto a road near Port Macquarie in New South Wales.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Americium-241 is a derivative of plutonium. Its use in Australia is subject to State legislation controlling radioactive materials. Americium-241 may be safely handled when the appropriate precautions are applied and it is used safely throughout the world in the commonplace geophysical application of borehole logging.

(2) I am advised that no radioactivity was spilt onto a road near Port Macquarie in New South Wales. A package containing radioactive sources fell onto a roadway near Port Macquarie as the result of a road accident. Although the outer packaging was broken, no radioactive material escaped from the inner containers.

The Americium-241 source was on consignment to a geophysical contracting company in Queensland from suppliers in the United States of America. It comprised part of a neutron logging tool used in downhole logging of boreholes to determine the porosity of rocks.
